headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext:
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for participating in the MAA Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. 
At this time, we would like to turn the conference over to Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance. Mr. Argo, you may begin.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Priscilla. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO. Before we begin, with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out t
componenttext:
Thanks, Priscilla. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO. 
Before we begin, with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the discussion, company management will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from our projections. We encourage you to refer to the Safe Harbor language included in yesterday's press release and our '34 Act filings with the SEC, which describe Risk Factors that may impact future result. These reports, along with a copy of today's prepared comments and an audio copy of this morning's call, will be available on our website.
During this call, we will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures can be found in our earnings release and supplemental financial data. When we reach the question-and-answer portion of the call, I would ask for everyone to please limit their questions to no more than 2 in order to give everyone ample opportunity to participate. Should you have additional questions, please reenter the queue or you're certainly welcome to follow up with us after we conclude the call. Thank you. 
I'll now turn the call over to Eric.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. MAA wrapped up calendar year 2015 with another quarter of strong performance. Importantly, we expect the favorable leasing conditions across our region and the trend supporting a record high occupancy and solid momentum in rent growth to cont
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. MAA wrapped up calendar year 2015 with another quarter of strong performance. Importantly, we expect the favorable leasing conditions across our region and the trend supporting a record high occupancy and solid momentum in rent growth to continue in 2016. As outlined in our earnings release, our forecast for MAA for the coming year is defined by continued record occupancy results, consistent with what was captured in 2015, and rent growth that is also consistent with the strong momentum from last year and that remained well above long-term averages. Operating expenses are expected to remain well in check, with real estate taxes being the only item driving any pressure and reflecting the continued strong valuation and leasing fundamentals, that are supporting the apartment market.
During the fourth quarter, we captured positive pricing momentum across the portfolio, above the year-over-year and sequential quarterly basis. Tom will provide you with more detail surrounding leasing conditions across our markets, but overall we believe the supply and demand dynamics across our high-growth Sunbelt region, coupled with a portfolio that is uniquely diversified across both large and secondary markets and that offers a price point appealing to the largest segment of rental market will drive solid results in 2016. 
As noted in yesterday's earnings release, we were successful in securing a couple of acquisitions in the fourth quarter, both of which have an efficient and accretive Phase II benefit to them, which enabled the deals to work within our disciplined underwriting model. We expect the transaction market in 2016 will be similar to 2015, with robust transaction activity fueled by high level of new development and lease-up projects being brought to market.
With the continued high level of investor and buyer interest surrounding current valuations, we remain disciplined in our approach and have forecasted 2016 a comparable volume of acquisitions and new development funding as compared to 2015, that we plan to match fund with the disposition activity and internally generated free cash flow. Start expansion at our newly acquired The Denton property that Kansas City, we now have $117 million of new on development underway with each of the 5 projects representing highly accretive Phase II expansions of existing successful properties. 
During 2016, we also anticipate another active year of redevelopment through our very accretive kitchen and bath remodeling program. I'll recap for you the changes in our balance sheet and transactions completed in the fourth quarter, which further expands our growth capacity. As noted in our earnings release, through a combination of capital recycling completed last year and the free cash flow now being generated, the balance sheet was further deleveraged in 2015, with day to market cap at 32.2% by year end. We anticipate continued strengthening of the balance sheet in 2016. In summary, we believe MAA's balance sheet is well positioned for future opportunities as they emerge.
Before turning the call over to Tom, I want to say to all our MAA Associates, how much I appreciate all of your hard work and tremendous results in 2015. Thanks to your efforts, MAA produced pop it is for our shareholders in calendar year 2015, and we are well-positioned to continue our legacy of outperformance over the full cycle, as we head into 2016. 
And with that, I'm going to hand it over to Tom. Tom?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our fourth quarter NOI performance of 7.3%, was driven by revenue growth of 5.4% of prior year. We have good momentum in rents and so our effective rents increased 4.4% on year-on-year basis and 70 basis points
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our fourth quarter NOI performance of 7.3%, was driven by revenue growth of 5.4% of prior year. We have good momentum in rents and so our effective rents increased 4.4% on year-on-year basis and 70 basis points sequentially. Strong average physical occupancy contributed 70 basis points over the prior year. Overall expenses remain in line, just 2.4%. Expense discipline has been a hallmark of our operations for years. Our industry-leading initiatives such as our vendor owned inventory shops talking program, which will be completed this year, have allowed us to keep the expense line consistently in check. 
January demand trends continue to positive momentum. Average physical occupancy of 96.1 ran 94 basis points ahead of last year. Our 60-day exposure, which is current vacancy plus all notices for 60-day period, is just 7%. This is a 120 basis points stronger than same time last year. January rents on a year-over-year basis were up 5%. Occupancy exposure critical beginning of the year better than we've seen in recent years. 
On the market front, the growth of the large markets is driving strong revenue results. They were led by Orlando, Fort Worth, Atlanta and Phoenix. The secondary markets achieved 4.4% revenue growth. And these markets were benefiting from improved job growth as well as sophisticated operating platform, that has a competitive advantages across our footprint and markets.
Revenue growth in Charleston, Greenville, Savanna and Jacksonville all stood out. As mentioned above, momentum is strong across our markets, with occupancy, rent growth and exposure all showing positive trends. For our market in Houston, which represents just 3.5% of our portfolio. We will continue to monitor closely and protect occupancy in this market. 
Turnover for the quarter was down by 7.5% and down 180 basis points on a rolling 12-month basis to 52.5%. Moveouts to home buying was down 100 basis points and remained below historic norms. Moveouts to home rentals was down 6% and represents just 7% of our total moveouts. Our focus on minimizing the time between occupancy again paid off. The improvement in average days between occupancy for the quarter of 2.5 days, help drop-down the fourth quarter average physical occupancy or a record average physical occupancy to 96.1.
During 2015, we have completed 5,781 interior unit upgrades, 3,200 of those were on legacy COP communities. We expect to redevelop 5,000 units next year and expect the mix to continue to favor legacy COP portfolio. As a reminder, on average, we spent $4,500 per unit and received a $95 increase over comparable non-renovated unit, generating a year 1 cash return of well over 20%. Our active lease-up communities are performing well and we completed construction of 220 Riverside in Jacksonville in the fourth quarter. As you will notice in our release, we moved the stabilization of this community up to Q1 of '16, rather than Q2, because of better than planned lease-up supported by rents about pro forma. Colonial Grand at Bellevue II and West Creek 1 both stabilized on schedule for the fourth quarter. Station Square and Corner II and Cityscape at Market Center II are currently 67.5% and 82.1% leased and expected to stabilize in the fourth and third quarters of this year, respectively. We ended 2015 in strong fashion and are well-positioned for 2016. 
Al?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I will provide some additional commentary on fourth quarter earnings performance, balance sheet activity and then finally, of initial guidance for 2016. The record occupancy levels, continued pricing momentum and
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I will provide some additional commentary on fourth quarter earnings performance, balance sheet activity and then finally, of initial guidance for 2016. 
The record occupancy levels, continued pricing momentum and solid expense control during the fourth quarter produced record levels of core FFO per share for both the quarter and full year 2015. Core FFO, which excludes certain noncash and nonroutine items were $1.45, representing a 10% increase over the prior year. The current capital 20 just for the quarter were $8.6 million or $0.11 per share, which produce Core FFO about $1.34 per share, strong coverage of our $0.82 per quarter dividend. Core FFO for the full year, was 551 per share, also representing 10% increase over prior year. Our core AFFO for the year was 4.8 per share representing a 12% increase over the prior year. Down performance for the quarter was primarily produced by same-store NOI growth, driven by continued record high average occupancy levels during the quarter 70 basis points above the prior year. Our operating expenses also remained well under control in the quarter, increasingly 2.4% over the prior year, with favorable real estate tax some benefit in the fourth quarter.
During the fourth quarter, we acquired 2 new communities for a total investment of $79 million, including land parcels for 2 Phase II expansions, which both started during the quarter. These purchases being our full year acquisition investment to $327 million for 7 new communities, containing 1,782 units. We also funded an additional $13.6 million of development cost for the 5 committees under construction during the quarter, all Phase II expansions, leaving $74 million of $117 million total projected cost to be funded as of year end. We expect NOI yields in 7% to 7.5% range for these communities once they are completed and stabilized. We also invested $8.3 million in our redevelop program during the fourth quarter, bringing our full year investment and program to about $31 million. We continue to capture increases of 10% of units rom this program. 
During fourth quarter, we completed several important financial goals for the year. We recast our unsecured revolving credit facility, increasing including our borrowing capacity to $750 million to $500 million, extending maturity to 4.5 years in equivalent terms to reflect our stronger credit profile.
We also refinanced $150 million term loan, including the rate by 25 basis points, extending the maturity and modifying the terms to be consistent with our new credit facility. Of course, we also executed very successful bond issuance during the fourth quarter, issuing $400 million of 10 year notes at a coupon rate of 4%, price of 98.99%, which completed our refinancing plans for 2015 debt maturities. We're very pleased with the investor support and execution of this issue as we think it provides further confirmation the strength of our balance sheet. 
At year end, our leverage defined as net debt to gross assets was 190 basis points below the prior year, 40.6%. Our recurring EBIT continues to grow and affected quality of our earnings profile, covering fixed charges of about 4.5x. At year end, 96% of our that debt fixed was fixed or hedged against rising interest rates and average effective rate of 3.8%, with well maturities averaging 5 years. We also have a $700 million of total cash and credit available at year end. 
Finally, we did provide an issue always guidance for 2016 with the release, Core FFO is projected to be 5.68 to 5.88 per share or 5.78 at the midpoint based on average shares outstanding about $79.6 million. Core AFFO is projected to be 4.98 to 5.18 per share or 5.08 at the midpoint, representing about 6% growth over prior year.
The primary driver of 2016 performance is expected to be same-store NOI growth, which is forecasted to be 4% or 5%, based on 3% and 3.75% to 4% growth in revenues and 2 or 3 quarters growth in operating expenses. Our revenue projections included expectation of continued record high occupancy levels, averaging 96.1% through 2016, combined with continued rental pricing above long-term trends similar to 2015 levels, ranging 4%, 4.5%. We expect operating expenses to remain well under control with the real estate taxes continuing to present all year pressure and operating performance pushes valuations higher. We expect acquisition volume to be similar to 2015, with $300 million to $400 million of purchases including our projections. We also expect to fund an additional $50 million to $60 million of construction cost to the completion of 5 committees under development. We plan to essentially match fund these investments with $200 million to $300 million of multi payment dispositions, $30 million to $60 million of commercial assets and positions and with $90 million to $95 million of internally generated free cash flow. And due to the timing required to recycle assets along with the initial loss of NOI deals, our forecast for the full year, includes $0.04 to $0.06 per share of dilution related to these 2016 disposition plans. Our current plans do not include the need for new equity during 2016, and we expect to end the year with our leverage, and another flat year of reduction from prior year.
That's all we have in the way of fair comments. So Priscilla, we'll now turn the call back over to you for questions.

componenttext: Eric, quick question for you. Unlike many of your peers, the company appears to be projecting pretty decent acquisition volume in the year ahead. Can you give us a little bit more thought as to where you see attractive opportunities in the market? Is it because you're largely in markets with competing? Are you seeing yields become more attractive, what's the motivation for that particular volume?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, it's pretty consistent with what we did this year. And we think the conditions in the marketplace in 2016 are going to be somewhat similar to what they were in 2015, if not more robust. As we get later in the cycle, we just see more de
componenttext: Well, first of all, it's pretty consistent with what we did this year. And we think the conditions in the marketplace in 2016 are going to be somewhat similar to what they were in 2015, if not more robust. As we get later in the cycle, we just see more development projects and lease-up committees been brought to market. And our deal flow is running higher this time this year than it was at the same point last year. So we think the transaction market is going to be very active over the course of the year. And so we put a number out there, $300 million to $400 million, which is consistent with -- we did over a little over $300 million this year and we will see what happens. I'm optimistic that we'll see some things that are become increasingly compelling and we may find some situations, where we have these Phase 2 opportunities associated with like we did in December. And I think that we'll see how things play out over the course of the year. We have assumed in our guidance that we will do $200 million or $300 million dispositions, so we're going to wait on that, that will be more backend loaded over the course of the year, depending on what opportunities emerge on the acquisition front. So David, it's not specific detailed answer to you, but it's really more just a reflection of the thing conditions are going to be consistent, if not a little bit more robust from an activity perspective, and that may yield some opportunities for us.

The stock has been a top performer. So if the guidance process this year changed at all relative to how you've said it in the past? headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick, this is Al. I will tell you how, it was prepared this year, no real change is there. I'll tell you, what you're expecting for 2016 first and foremost is not any deceleration in momentum in our business. And what we're projecting is for occup
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick, this is Al. I will tell you how, it was prepared this year, no real change is there. I'll tell you, what you're expecting for 2016 first and foremost is not any deceleration in momentum in our business. And what we're projecting is for occupancy level of 96.1%, which is by the way a record high for the company that we had in 2015, to carry through 2016. And I'm talking about average 365 a year, for the year, which is pretty strong. 
So on top of that, and so you flatten 2015 to hold that level. On top of that, we expect pricing levels to be consistent with 2015. Again, well above long-term averages or norms. We expect pricing of about 4% to 4.5%, so that really revenue growth and then we have expense control we talked about the bottom line of NOI. The comparison to 2015, I think the challenge there is that we had about 150 basis points of things in our 2015 revenue, that were unusual, has it called one-time are similar to that one-time items, such as we beat our occupancy 75 basis points in the year, get into that 96.1% with an average of 75 basis points revenue of about the prior year. And then related to that, while we were building occupancy, we also had a higher fee performance related to some occupancy. Fee that you have processing fees, pet fees all those things. And also, as we talked about, we had little better performance in '15 in capturing some of the final remaining portions of the synergies from our margin. We really had a strong performance in 2015 and the fees to give you context, 15% in 2015 over '14. We certainly expect the whole majority of those fees and clear that in '16, but that growth rate it will be more on a normalized growth going forward. So hope that gives you the...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, the takeaway from that Nick is, when you look at 2015, the surprise factor was occupancy and we had anticipated that coming out of 2014, that we would hold the 2014 occupancy, which was pretty strong and we did really contemplate seeing occupancy li
componenttext: Nick, the takeaway from that Nick is, when you look at 2015, the surprise factor was occupancy and we had anticipated that coming out of 2014, that we would hold the 2014 occupancy, which was pretty strong and we did really contemplate seeing occupancy lift as much as it did over the course of 2015. And we and frankly I think many in the sector were surprised how strong the markets were last year, and I think everybody for the most part was raising the guidance for the course of the year. As we got into 2016 guidance, we're coming off a year, where average daily physical occupancy was higher than we have seen in our 22-year history. We ended the fourth quarter with highest average daily physical occupancy we're ever had. So to go into 2016, with an anticipation that we're going to beat that again and get about average daily physical occupancy of 96%. We just -- we're little hesitant to take that back and we think we're going to hold it. We think that the conditions are great in our markets and great in our region and we think we're going to hold that record occupancy. And we think we're going to get very solid rent growth of 4% to 4.5% as well, again in line with past year. But just the incremental lift in occupancy is not expected to repeat itself again in 2016. And that's the big difference between '16 and '15.

componenttext: Yes. I think what we would expect to see is the job growth in the large markets continue to lead the way, absent some sort of macroeconomic change on the demand side. We are expecting those to lead and expecting the Altanta, Orlando, Phoenix probably to perform top side of that group in the secondary markets, when we get a little less supply, we're seeing job growth build there and we would expect to see places like Charleston, Greenville and Jacksonville do well. But we would expect that larger markets continue to outperform secondary markets at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Where the secondary markets really make a huge positive impact to our performance, Nick, is if you want to start looking at a real sort of see change and sort of the leasing environment, whether either we see supply get way out of hand relative to the dem
componenttext: Where the secondary markets really make a huge positive impact to our performance, Nick, is if you want to start looking at a real sort of see change and sort of the leasing environment, whether either we see supply get way out of hand relative to the demand and we can do recessionary environment or will see job growth really start to pull back, that's where the secondary markets really start to hold up a whole lot better than what you typically see in the larger markets. But at this point, with fundamental still being the strong as Tom is outlined, we think there is still will be a reason for the large markets to continue to outperform at this point secondary markets.

componenttext: Well, if you look at it on a cash flow cap rate basis, certainly just looking at what we sold this past year, 21 properties that we sold, the cash flow cap rate was around 5.8. I mean, we are buying at around 5, 5.5, so from a cash flow perspective it's pretty close. When you look at sort of NOI yield, initial NOI yield, particularly if you assume, as we do that some of the acquisitions that we make are still in lease-up and not yet fully stabilized, gassed out more so. It can be 150 basis points or so. And therefore, that's from an earnings perspective, we've assumed $0.04 to $0.06 of earnings dilution in our guidance predicated on that GAAP and NOI yield, but it was a function of higher yielding assets that we're selling, coupled with the non-stabilized nature of what we assume we'll be buying.

componenttext: First question, you guys have obviously made some significant improvement in physical occupancy in the secondary markets over the last year. But looking at average per unit, obviously, outpace secondary by pretty wide margin. I'm just wondering is there some limited in factors in secondary markets, I think or is that a strategic decision on your part to keep secondary markets grow little bit lower to push occupancy this year and is that something we could expect to see you guys push on the rent side, now that occupancy is 96%?

componenttext: Sure. Tom, secondary is nonissue. It's actually we've better rent income ratios in secondary than in large, in both -- I mean we're talking 100 basis points difference, roughy 17.5 116.5 so not materially different, but that's a nonissue there. And I think now that -- there is -- it's a real balance on rent in occupancy and 1 relates to the other, as you know. Demand in secondary looks very good at this point. Occupancy in January average physical is actually higher now in secondary than large. And we're in very good shape on our exposure. So we're optimistic about rents in secondary at this point.

componenttext: What I would also tell you Tom is that, to some degree the spread in average rents large and secondary portfolios the function of the fact that we have, I think, a higher percentage of older properties, some of the legacy assets that we've owned for some time on in some of the secondary markets, that's changing and that's evolving as we continue to build out our presence in markets like Kansas City, San Antonio, some of these newer markets that we have been getting into with newer assets. But when you look at the age of the assets across the portfolio, we have a percentage wise a higher concentration of older legacy assets in some of the secondary markets. And I think that probably accounts for some of that pricing spread that you're mentioning.

I'll try to give you some color on that Drew, information go on, you kind of have to give feel for, what's happening in each jurisdiction and you start your estimates. And in 2015, really high numbers coming on Texas, what in the second in particular the third quarter, we started to get some information, that is going to moderate a little bit in fourth quarter. We got that finalized notice and so that's white came down in '15. 
Looking into '16, we're still getting very high numbers out of Texas and we've been we got some evaluation in Georgia and some in Florida. So I would tell you where we sit today, we expect to think about what they do, they're doing their valuation or the assessment in 2016, looking backwards 2015, record year for the company in many areas. And so we expect those initial evaluation is come out high and we expect to jump on early. Hopefully, we have some success. We have some success in what we think will come out building our numbers, but hopefully we'll meet there and even be able to have more success. But I'll you right now, given performance we had in '15, the valuations are based off of income, it's hard to see those taxes begin to moderate significantly until the cycle changes. componenttext: Okay. And one more. Despite the cause that, that cost us like a bottom, both on secured and unsecured side, private equity remains pretty aggressive and really cap rates. I'm just curious if you have any color there or anything that you're looking at acquisitions obviously, with lower leverage levels?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean we continue to see private capital securing loan-to-values and 70%, 75% range pretty easily. And the agencies remain very active and coming out of the National Housing Council's Annual Meeting back in January, that mean all the feedback and al
componenttext: Yes, I mean we continue to see private capital securing loan-to-values and 70%, 75% range pretty easily. And the agencies remain very active and coming out of the National Housing Council's Annual Meeting back in January, that mean all the feedback and all the information that we got, is that private capital, both domestic and foreign, indicates a huge appetite for multi family real estate. It appears it's financing Windows are wide open very much from loan to value prospective very much consistent with what we saw in 2015. I think that despite slight defense in rates, made in interest rates earlier, the expectation is that rates are going to continue to remain pretty low this year. So from our perspective, it's really hard to see how the valuation market is going to change much. I think it's going to be another active year, another fueled by a lot of investment interest. I think the only thing that potentially is going to evolve is I just think there maybe more deal flow. I think there maybe more transactions in the market than we've seen in 2015. But I think it will still be a very robust environment.

componenttext: Okay. And you mentioned, more deal flow on the acquisitions, now would this more the urban core properties that you're looking for and are you seeing any developers get in trouble yet or they just seem capital markets, seen the stock market and that might to the table?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not particularly targeting more sort of urban core, what I would tell you is that that's where so much of a supplying is being delivered, that I think that's where the opportunities will emerge. As some of these lease-ups run into trouble or t
componenttext:
Well, we're not particularly targeting more sort of urban core, what I would tell you is that that's where so much of a supplying is being delivered, that I think that's where the opportunities will emerge. As some of these lease-ups run into trouble or they're not leasing it at either the velocity or the rent that they had performed. So I think as the cycle continues to play out, it's more than likely where the opportunities will emerge.
We're not seeing, what I would consider to be real operating to stress, or lease-up to stress. I mean frankly, where we see our opportunities are, where we see private capital come in, tie up the date on very, very aggressive terms and then run into some kind of a problem and getting their financing or they don't get loan proceeds, equivalent to what thought they were going to get and they go back to developer to try to reiterate the deal and the developer sort of blows up and then they come back to us. And so I mean every deal we bought last year was on a rebound. And I think that from an operating perspective, we're not seeing any real weakness yet. But I just think as the deal flow kicks up, we think that may very well yield some increased opportunity.

componenttext: Tayo, it's a good observation that they transition from third quarter to fourth quarter a little bit lower in revenue, but there is a seasonal factor to these markets. There is lower demand and that pattern has repeated itself over the years with us. And as usual, we see a tick back up at the beginning of the year and those markets, the secondary markets average physical occupancy for January is 96.3. So we've seen sort of a popup there. componenttext: Charlotte in particular is an urban suburban story a little bit. And looking at the amount of product that's coming in South and South Church area, is noticeable. componenttext: We take a look every year at every individual investment we have and we look at sort of the after-CapEx cash flow been generated of the investment and what likely is going to trend out at over the next few years and make a decision on which ones do we think are going to yield us the weakest or declining, if you will cash flow. And target those as ones that we need to recycle cap out of the something more compelling. I think that we do this every year and so we've sold over 13,000 apartments in the last 5 years. And so we take a very sort of proactive approach to keeping certain level of recycling taking place every year. As we look at 2016, should the investment opportunity show up and it then presents an opportunity to recycle money out of some investments, I would expect '16 to be sort of evenly spread between both large and secondary markets. We have a good mix in both.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Priscilla. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO. Before we begin, with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out t
componenttext:
Thanks, Priscilla. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO. 
Before we begin, with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the discussion, company management will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from our projections. We encourage you to refer to the safe harbor language included in yesterday's press release and our '34 Act filings with the SEC, which describe risk factors that may impact future results. These reports, along with a copy of today's prepared comments and an audio copy of this morning's call, will be available on our website.
During this call, we will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures can be found in our earnings release and supplemental financial data. When we reach the question-and-answer portion of the call, I would ask for everyone to please limit their questions to no more than 2 in order to give everyone ample opportunity to participate. Should you have additional questions, please reenter the queue or you're certainly welcome to follow up with us after we conclude the call. Thank you. 
I'll now turn the call over to Eric.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. MAA wrapped up calendar year 2015 with another quarter of strong performance. Importantly, we expect the favorable leasing conditions across our region and the trend supporting record-high occupancy and solid momentum in rent growth to contin
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. MAA wrapped up calendar year 2015 with another quarter of strong performance. Importantly, we expect the favorable leasing conditions across our region and the trend supporting record-high occupancy and solid momentum in rent growth to continue in 2016. 
As outlined in our earnings release, our forecast for MAA for the coming year is defined by continued record occupancy results, consistent with what was captured in 2015. And rent growth that is also consistent with the strong momentum from last year, and that remained well above long-term averages. Operating expenses are expected to remain well in check, with real estate taxes being the only item driving any pressure and reflecting the continued strong valuation and leasing fundamentals that are supporting the apartment market.
During the fourth quarter, we captured positive pricing momentum across the portfolio on both the year-over-year and sequential quarterly basis. Tom will provide you with more detail surrounding leasing conditions across our markets. But overall, we believe the supply and demand dynamics across our high-growth Sunbelt region, coupled with a portfolio that is uniquely diversified across both large and secondary markets and that offers a price point appealing to the largest segment of the rental market, will drive solid results in 2016. 
As noted in yesterday's earnings release, we were successful in securing a couple of acquisitions in the fourth quarter, both of which have an efficient and accretive Phase II benefit to them, which enabled the deals to work within our disciplined underwriting model. We expect the transaction market in 2016 will be similar to 2015, with robust transaction activity fueled by a high level of new development and lease-up projects being brought to market, with the continued high level of investor and buyer interest surrounding current valuations. 
We remain disciplined in our approach and have forecasted 2016 a comparable volume of acquisitions and new development funding as compared to 2015 that we plan to match fund with the disposition activity and internally generated free cash flow. 
With the start of expansion at our newly acquired Denton property in Kansas City, we now have $117 million of new development underway, with each of the 5 projects representing highly accretive Phase II expansions of existing successful properties. During 2016, we also anticipate another active year of redevelopment through our very accretive kitchen and bath  remodeling program. 
I'll recap for you the changes in our balance sheet and transactions completed in the fourth quarter, which further expands our growth capacity. As noted in our earnings release, through a combination of the capital recycling completed last year and the free cash flow now being generated, the balance sheet was further deleveraged in 2015, with debt-to-market cap at 32.2% by year end. We anticipate continued strengthening of the balance sheet in 2016. In summary, we believe MAA's balance sheet is well positioned for future opportunities as they emerge.
Before turning the call over to Tom, I want to say to all our MAA associates how much I appreciate all of your hard work and tremendous results in 2015. Thanks to your efforts, MAA produced top tier total investment returns for our shareholders in calendar year 2015, and we are well positioned to continue our legacy of outperformance over the full cycle as we head into 2016. 
And with that, I'm going to hand it over to Tom. Tom?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our fourth quarter NOI performance of 7.3% was driven by revenue growth of 5.4% of the prior year. We have good momentum in rents. And so our effective rents increased 4.4% on a year-on-year basis and 70 basis
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our fourth quarter NOI performance of 7.3% was driven by revenue growth of 5.4% of the prior year. We have good momentum in rents. And so our effective rents increased 4.4% on a year-on-year basis and 70 basis points sequentially. Strong average physical occupancy contributed 70 basis points over the prior year. 
Overall expenses remained in line, up just 2.4%. Expense discipline has been a hallmark of our operation for years. Our industry-leading initiatives such as our vendor-owned inventory shop stocking program, which will be completed this year, have allowed us to keep the expense line consistently in check. 
January demand trends continued the positive momentum. Average physical occupancy of 96.1% ran 94 basis points ahead of last year. Our 60-day exposure, which is current vacancy plus all notices for a 60-day period, is just 7%. This is 120 basis points stronger than the same time last year. January blended rents on a year-over-year basis are up 5%. Occupancy exposure at the critical beginning of the year are better than we've seen in recent years. 
On the market front, the vibrant job growth of the large markets is driving strong revenue results. They were led by Orlando, Fort Worth, Atlanta and Phoenix. The secondary markets achieved 4.4% revenue growth, and these markets were benefiting from improved job growth as well as sophisticated operating platform that has the competitive advantages across our footprint end markets.  Revenue growth in Charleston, Greenville, Savannah and Jacksonville all stood out. 
As mentioned above, momentum is strong across our markets, with occupancy, rent growth and exposure, all showing positive trends. Our market worry bead is Houston, which represents just 3.5% of our portfolio. We will continue to monitor Houston closely and protect occupancy in this market. 
Turnover for the quarter was down by 7.5% and down 180 basis points on a rolling 12-month basis to 52.5%. Move-outs to home buying was down 100 basis points and remained below historic norms. Move-outs to home rentals was down 6% and represents just 7% of our total move-outs. Our focus on minimizing the time between occupancy again paid off. The improvements in average days vacant between occupants for the quarter of 2.5 days helped drive down the fourth quarter average physical occupancy or drove the record average physical occupancy to 96.1%.
During 2015, we've completed 5,781 interior unit upgrades. 3,200 of those were on legacy CLP communities. We expect to redevelop 5,000 units next year and expect the mix to continue to favor legacy CLP portfolio. As a reminder, on average, we spend $4,500 per unit and receive a $95 increase over our comparable nonrenovated unit, generating a year 1 cash return of well over 20%. 
Our active lease-up communities are performing well, and we completed construction of 220 Riverside in Jacksonville in the fourth quarter. As you will notice in our release, we moved the stabilization of this community up to Q1 of '16 rather than Q2 because of better-than-planned lease-up, supported by rents above pro forma. Colonial Grand at Bellevue II and Retreat at West Creek I both stabilized on schedule for the fourth quarter. Station Square at Cosner's Corner II and and Cityscape at Market Center II are currently 67.5% and 82.1% leased and expected to stabilize in the fourth and third quarters of this year, respectively. We ended 2015 in strong fashion and are well positioned for 2016. 
Al?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's fourth quarter earnings performance, balance sheet activity, and then finally, on initial guidance for 2016. The record occupancy levels, continued pric
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's fourth quarter earnings performance, balance sheet activity, and then finally, on initial guidance for 2016. 
The record occupancy levels, continued pricing momentum and solid expense control during the fourth quarter produced record levels of core FFO per share for both the quarter and the full year 2015. Core FFO, which excludes certain noncash and nonroutine items, was $1.45, representing a 10% increase over the prior year. The current capital expenditures for the quarter were $8.6 million or $0.11 per share, which produced core FFO of $1.34 per share, providing strong coverage of our $0.82 per share quarterly dividend. 
Core FFO for the full year was $5.51 per share, also representing a 10% increase over the prior year. And our core AFFO for the year was $4.80 per share, representing a 12% increase over the prior year. The outperformance for the quarter was primarily produced by same-store NOI growth, driven by continued record-high average occupancy levels during the quarter, 70 basis points above the prior year. And our operating expenses also remained well under control during the quarter, increasingly only 2.4% over the prior year, with favorable real estate tax appeals providing some benefit in the fourth quarter.
During the fourth quarter, we acquired 2 new communities for a total investment of $79 million, including the land parcels for 2 Phase II expansions, which are both started during the quarter. These purchases bring our full year acquisition investment to $327 million for 7 new communities containing 1,782 units. We also funded an additional $13.6 million of development cost for the 5 committees under construction during the quarter, all Phase II expansions, leaving $74 million of the $117 million total projected cost to be funded as of year end. We expect NOI yields in 7% to 7.5% range for these communities once they are completed and stabilized. We also invested $8.3 million in our redevelopment program during the fourth quarter, bringing our full year investment and program to about $31 million. We continue to capture rent increases of 10% above the nonrenovated units from this program. 
During the fourth quarter, we completed several important financing goals for the year. We recast our unsecured revolving credit facility, increasing our borrowing capacity to $750 million from $500 million, extending maturity to 4.5 years and the improving the terms to reflect our stronger credit profile. We also refinanced $150 million term loan, improving the rate by 25 basis points, extending the maturity and modifying the terms to be consistent with our new credit facility. And of course, we also executed very successful bond issuance during the fourth quarter, issuing $400 million of 10-year notes at a coupon rate of 4% priced at 98.99%, which completed our refinancing plans of 2015 debt maturities. We're very pleased with the investor support and execution of this issuance, which we think and we believe provides further confirmation of the strength of our balance sheet. 
At year end, our leverage, defined as net debt to gross assets, was 190 basis points below the prior year, 40.6%. Our recurring EBITDA continues to grow and reflect the quality of our earnings profile, covering fixed charges about 4.5x. At year end, 96% of our debt was fixed or hedged against rising interest rates at an average effective rate of 3.8%, with well laddered maturities averaging 5 years. And we also have a $700 million of total cash and credit available at year end. 
Finally, we did provide and issue earnings guidance for 2016 with the release. Core FFO is projected to be $5.68 to $5.88 per share or $5.78 at the midpoint based on average shares and units outstanding of about 79.6 million. Core AFFO is projected to be $4.98 to $5.18 per share or $5.08 at the midpoint, representing about a 6% growth over the prior year.
The primary driver of 2016 performance is expected to be same-store NOI growth, which is forecasted to be 4% to 5% based on a 3.75% to 4.25% growth in revenues and 2.75% to 3.75% growth in operating expenses. Our revenue projections include expectations of continued record-high occupancy levels averaging 96.1% through 2016 combined with continued rental pricing above long-term trends, similar to 2015 levels, ranging 4% to 4.5%. We expect operating expenses to remain well under control, with the real estate taxes continuing to present the only pressure, and strong operating performance pushes valuations higher. 
We expect acquisition volume to be similar to 2015, with $300 million to $400 million of purchases included in our projections. We also expect to fund an additional $50 million to $60 million of construction cost through the completion of the 5 committees under development. We plan to essentially match fund these investments with $200 million to $300 million of multi-payment dispositions, $30 million to $60 million of commercial assets and land dispositions and with $90 million to $95 million of internally generated free cash flow. And given the timing required to recycle assets along with the initial loss of NOI yields, our forecast for the full year includes $0.04 to $0.06 per share of dilution related to these 2016 disposition plans. Our current plans do not include the need for new equity during 2016, and we expect to end the year with our leverage, and another flat year of reduction from the prior year.
That's all we have in the way of prepared comments. So Priscilla, we'll now turn the call back over to you for questions.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, a quick question for you. Unlike many of your peers, the company appears to be projecting a pretty decent acquisition volume in the year ahead. Can you give us a little bit more thought as to where you see attractive opportunities in the market? Is
componenttext: Eric, a quick question for you. Unlike many of your peers, the company appears to be projecting a pretty decent acquisition volume in the year ahead. Can you give us a little bit more thought as to where you see attractive opportunities in the market? Is it because you're largely in markets where the REITs aren't competing? Are you seeing yields become more attractive? What's the motivation for that particular volume?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, it's pretty consistent with what we did this year, and we think the conditions in the marketplace in 2016 are going to be somewhat similar to what they were in 2015, if not more robust. As we get later in the cycle, we just see more de
componenttext: Well, first of all, it's pretty consistent with what we did this year, and we think the conditions in the marketplace in 2016 are going to be somewhat similar to what they were in 2015, if not more robust. As we get later in the cycle, we just see more development projects and lease-up communities being brought to market. And our deal flow is running higher this time this year than it was at the same point last year. So we think the transaction market is going to be very active over the course of the year. And so we put a number out there, $300 million to $400 million, which is consistent with -- and we did over a little over $300 million this year. And we'll see what happens. I'm optimistic that we'll see some things that are -- have become increasingly compelling, and we may find some situations where we have these Phase II opportunities associated with them like we did in December. And I think that we'll see how things play out over the course of the year. We have assumed in our guidance that we'll do $200 million to $300 million of dispositions. We're going to wait on that. That will be more back-end loaded over the course of the year, depending on what opportunities emerge on the acquisition front. So that -- David, it's not a specific detailed answer to you, but it is really more just a reflection of -- we think conditions are going to be consistent, if not a little bit more robust, from an activity perspective. And that may yield some opportunities for us.

And how do you think about the opportunity and what you would need to see in order to exceed initial guidance similar to what you saw last year?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Al. I'll tell you a bit how it was prepared this year. No real changes there. I'll tell you, what we're expecting for 2016 first and foremost is not any deceleration in momentum in our business. And what we're projecting is for occupancy level of
componenttext: This is Al. I'll tell you a bit how it was prepared this year. No real changes there. I'll tell you, what we're expecting for 2016 first and foremost is not any deceleration in momentum in our business. And what we're projecting is for occupancy level of 96.1%, which is, by the way, a record high for the company that we had in 2015, to carry through 2016. And I'm talking about average 365 days a year -- for the year, which is pretty strong occupancy that's full. And so on top of that -- and so you're flat with 2015 to hold that level. On top of that, we expect pricing levels to be consistent with 2015, again well above long-term averages or norms. We expect pricing to go up 4% to 4.5%. And so that really is producing revenue growth. And then we have the expense control we talked about that drops to the bottom line of NOI. The comparison to 2015, I think the challenge there is that we had about 150 basis points of things in our 2015 revenue that were unusual. I won't hestitate to call them one-time, but similar to that one-time items, such as we built our occupancy 75 basis points in the year, getting to that 96.1% with on average 75 basis points in revenue above the prior year. And then related to that, we -- while we were building occupancy, we also had higher fee performance related -- some of it related to building our occupancy. Fees, as you have app fees, processing fees, PEP fees, all those things. And also, as we've talked about, we had a little better performance in '15 in capturing some of the final remaining portions of the synergies from the -- from our merger. We really had a strong performance in 2015 in the fees. To give you context, they grew 15% in 2015 over '14. We certainly expect to hold the majority of those fees and carry that in '16, but that growth rate, that -- it will not -- it will be more of a normalized growth rate going forward. So hope that gives you the...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay, nick. I mean, the takeaway from that is that when you look at 2015, the surprise factor was occupancy. And we had anticipated that coming out of 2014 that we would hold the 2014 occupancy, which was pretty strong, and we did really contemplate
componenttext: Yes, okay, nick. I mean, the takeaway from that is that when you look at 2015, the surprise factor was occupancy. And we had anticipated that coming out of 2014 that we would hold the 2014 occupancy, which was pretty strong, and we did really contemplate seeing occupancy lift as much as it did over the course of 2015. And we, and frankly, I think many in this sector, were surprised at how strong the markets were last year. And I think everybody, for the most part, was raising guidance over the course of the year. As we got into 2016 guidance, we're coming off a year, where average daily physical occupancy was higher than we've seen in our 22-year history. We ended the fourth quarter with the highest average daily physical occupancy we've ever had. So to go into 2016 with an anticipation that we're going to beat that again and get above average daily physical occupancy of 96%, we just -- we're a little hesitant to take that back. And we think we're going to hold it. We think that the conditions are great in our markets and great in our region, and we think we're going to hold that record occupancy. And we think we're going to get very solid rent growth of 4% to 4.5% as well, again in line with what we saw this past year. But just the incremental lift in occupancy is not expected to repeat itself again in 2016. And that's the big difference between '16 and '15.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what we would expect to see is the job growth in the large markets continue to lead the way, absent some sort of macroeconomic change on the demand side. We're expecting those to lead and expecting the Altanta, Orlando, Phoenix probably to pe
componenttext: Yes. I think what we would expect to see is the job growth in the large markets continue to lead the way, absent some sort of macroeconomic change on the demand side. We're expecting those to lead and expecting the Altanta, Orlando, Phoenix probably to perform top side of that group. In the secondary markets, where we get a little less supply, we're seeing job growth build there. And we'd expect to see places like Charleston, Greenville and Jacksonville do well. But we would expect that large markets continue to outperform secondary markets at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Where the secondary markets really make a huge positive impact to our performance, Nick, is if you want to start looking at a real sort of sea change in sort of the leasing environment, whether either we see supply get way out of hand relative to the dema
componenttext: Where the secondary markets really make a huge positive impact to our performance, Nick, is if you want to start looking at a real sort of sea change in sort of the leasing environment, whether either we see supply get way out of hand relative to the demand and we get into a recessionary environment or we see job growth really start to pull back. That's where the secondary markets really start to hold up a whole lot better than what you typically see in the larger markets. But at this point in the cycle, with fundamental still being as strong as Tom is outlining, we think that there's still will be a reason for the large markets to continue to outperform at this point in the secondary markets.

componenttext: Just want to go back to your comments on acquisitions and dispositions. Can you speak about the cap rate spread that you're expecting between you're selling and what you're buying?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at it on a cash flow cap rate basis, certainly just looking at what we sold this past year, 21 properties that we sold, the cash flow cap rate was around 5.8%. I mean, we're buying at around 5.5%. So from a cash flow perspective, it's pr
componenttext: Well, if you look at it on a cash flow cap rate basis, certainly just looking at what we sold this past year, 21 properties that we sold, the cash flow cap rate was around 5.8%. I mean, we're buying at around 5.5%. So from a cash flow perspective, it's pretty close. When you look at sort of NOI yield -- initial NOI yield, particularly if you assume, as we do, that some of the acquisitions that we make are still in lease-up and not yet fully stabilized, it gaps out more so. It can be 150 basis points or so. And therefore, that's why, from an earnings perspective, we've assumed $0.04 to $0.06 of earnings dilution in our guidance predicated on that GAAP and NOI yield, both as a function of the higher yielding assets that we're selling coupled with the nonstabilized nature of what we assume we'll be buying.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, when you look at core FFO guidance, when you're sitting here today, what's the difference between core and NAREIT from the things that you know today?
componenttext: Okay. And then, when you look at core FFO guidance, when you're sitting here today, what's the difference between core and NAREIT from the things that you know today?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The biggest thing is fair market value of debt adjustment. And the others are acquisition costs and then gains/loss or extinguishment debts, some small things. But the big number of what's driving that difference is really fair value market of debt. And I
componenttext: The biggest thing is fair market value of debt adjustment. And the others are acquisition costs and then gains/loss or extinguishment debts, some small things. But the big number of what's driving that difference is really fair value market of debt. And I'll tell you, Rob, we chose to -- when we did the merger a couple of years ago, we had that significant number for that. We chose to pull that out of FFO, because noncash, and we're getting a sense of credit and interest, and we just don't like it was better to show it without that, because it's not cash. And so some other people do it differently. We know it's a little bit confusing, but we're -- that's the main difference, and we'll continue to do that until that burned. It will burn off in another couple of years and that significant difference should decline.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, what is the 100 basis points of turnover cost? If turnover goes up 100 or 200 basis points this year, how does that -- how do you think about that impacting the expense side of the equation?
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, what is the 100 basis points of turnover cost? If turnover goes up 100 or 200 basis points this year, how does that -- how do you think about that impacting the expense side of the equation?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's usually about $0.01 to $0.015 per percent on that, Rob. It's not -- I mean, it's meaningful in our business in terms of the actual impact to FFO. Given the size and scale of the company, it's smaller than you would think. So 1% equates to $1.50 rough
componenttext: It's usually about $0.01 to $0.015 per percent on that, Rob. It's not -- I mean, it's meaningful in our business in terms of the actual impact to FFO. Given the size and scale of the company, it's smaller than you would think. So 1% equates to $1.50 roughly of FFO.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was wondering if you can talk a little bit more in terms of large and secondary markets. I think the comment about large performing here in '16, certainly I think people can look at some of the trends recently in terms of that and think that will continue
componenttext: Was wondering if you can talk a little bit more in terms of large and secondary markets. I think the comment about large performing here in '16, certainly I think people can look at some of the trends recently in terms of that and think that will continue. But you mentioned Houston in terms of challenges, but there are a number of other larger markets where there is more supply coming. And so wondering how you think about that in terms of not so much as the absolute level, but the level of deceleration that could come through in large markets versus secondary markets?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Dan, since we're always saying -- or what we're seeing is in large, that '15 looks an awful -- '16 looks an awful like '15. It should pull down the way we keep -- try to keep in mind the balance between demand and supply is the job's completion r
componenttext: Yes. And Dan, since we're always saying -- or what we're seeing is in large, that '15 looks an awful -- '16 looks an awful like '15. It should pull down the way we keep -- try to keep in mind the balance between demand and supply is the job's completion ratio. And they're about 7 for both years in a row. And job growth 15' for that combination of markets is 2.7, and it's about the same for '16. I think related to our portfolio specifically, this has been worn out [indiscernible], I think, a little bit. But it is true that demand in some of these large markets is coming into the urban areas, where we have a little less -- excuse me, the supply is coming in with a little less exposure, an important clarification there, Eric, is where we've got a little more and the [indiscernible] satellite cities and suburban exposure.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So we're getting about on -- we're getting about 6% on the renewals through March.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to Tom Lesnick with Capital One.
componenttext: We'll move next to Tom Lesnick with Capital One.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, you guys have obviously made some significant improvement in physical occupancy in the secondary markets over the last year. But looking at average effective rent per unit, obviously, large, so outpaces secondary by a pretty wide margin. I
componenttext: First question, you guys have obviously made some significant improvement in physical occupancy in the secondary markets over the last year. But looking at average effective rent per unit, obviously, large, so outpaces secondary by a pretty wide margin. I was just wondering, is there some limiting factors in the secondary markets like personal income growth that's keeping that number down, or was that a strategic decision on your part to keep secondary market rent growth a little bit lower to push occupancy this year. And is that something we could expect to see you guys push on the rent side now that occupancy is 96%?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Tom, and affordability in secondary is a nonissue. It's actually -- we've better rent income ratios in secondary than in large -- in both -- I mean we're talking 100 basis points difference, one roughly 17.5, one 16.5. So not materially different, b
componenttext: Sure. Tom, and affordability in secondary is a nonissue. It's actually -- we've better rent income ratios in secondary than in large -- in both -- I mean we're talking 100 basis points difference, one roughly 17.5, one 16.5. So not materially different, but that's a nonissue there. And I think now that -- there is a -- it's a real balance on rent and occupancy, and one leads to the other, as you know. Demand in secondary looks very good at this point. Occupancy in January average physical is actually higher now in secondary than large. And we're in very good shape on our exposure. So we're optimistic about rents in secondary at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would also tell you, Tom, is that to some degree, the spread in average rent between our large and secondary segment of our portfolio is a function of the fact that we have, I think, a higher percentage of older properties, some of the legacy asset
componenttext: What I would also tell you, Tom, is that to some degree, the spread in average rent between our large and secondary segment of our portfolio is a function of the fact that we have, I think, a higher percentage of older properties, some of the legacy assets that we've owned for a long time are in some of the secondary markets. Now that's changing, and that's evolving as we continue to build out our presence in markets like Kansas City, San Antonio, Fredericksburg, some of these newer markets that we've been getting into with newer assets. But when you look at the age of the assets across the portfolio, we have, percentage-wise, a higher concentration of older legacy assets in some of the secondary markets. And I think that probably accounts for some of that pricing spread that you're mentioning.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then looking at same-store operating expense, the dispersing of year-over-year comps in secondary markets is pretty wide this quarter. I was just wondering if there was anything particular that was kind of driving the dispersion there across a
componenttext: Got it. And then looking at same-store operating expense, the dispersing of year-over-year comps in secondary markets is pretty wide this quarter. I was just wondering if there was anything particular that was kind of driving the dispersion there across all the secondary markets?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, taxes is one factor in it. And then Charleston obviously stands out. We had a weather event in Charleston, where you've probably read about it, tons of rain there. And we didn't have any material damage, actually no units down or anything li
componenttext: Sure. I mean, taxes is one factor in it. And then Charleston obviously stands out. We had a weather event in Charleston, where you've probably read about it, tons of rain there. And we didn't have any material damage, actually no units down or anything like that. But we did have a fair amount of landscape work that had to occur in that market during the fourth quarter, just trying things out and replacing some damaged stuff.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in aggregate, it was probably real estate taxes drove...
componenttext: I think in aggregate, it was probably real estate taxes drove...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's typically the largest driver of those.
componenttext: That's typically the largest driver of those.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] the credits came in the Texas markets, which are all in our -- except for San Antonio, our large segment.
componenttext: [indiscernible] the credits came in the Texas markets, which are all in our -- except for San Antonio, our large segment.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then one final question. Now that occupancy over 96%, looking at where we stood relative to last year, how has your average days return time changed over the last year or so?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean average days to turn is -- with that is down 2.5 days. We'd expect it to drop another 2 next year. I think the thing that probably bodes the best for revenues is that exposure at the end of January is down 120 basis points. And that's sort of
componenttext: Yes. I mean average days to turn is -- with that is down 2.5 days. We'd expect it to drop another 2 next year. I think the thing that probably bodes the best for revenues is that exposure at the end of January is down 120 basis points. And that's sort of the leading edge of our pricing power.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've move next to Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: We've move next to Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, one [indiscernible] you really outperformed the expectations in '15 with property tax expense growth, units for guidance [indiscernible] same as it was for this year, 4% to 4.5%. You hit the low end of that. I know essentially, in the thir
componenttext: First question, one [indiscernible] you really outperformed the expectations in '15 with property tax expense growth, units for guidance [indiscernible] same as it was for this year, 4% to 4.5%. You hit the low end of that. I know essentially, in the third quarter, you had some successful appeals both in terms of assessment converge rates. What you're assuming for '16 with your forecast in terms of whether you can quantify it as kind of a [indiscernible] percentage on -- in assessments? And could that look at potential for that number to possibly come in at the lower end of the range?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll try to give you some color on that, Drew. I think what happened at the beginning of the year in here, you just don't have a lot of information to go on. You kind of have got to get feel for, and you've talked to assessors, get a feel for what's happe
componenttext: I'll try to give you some color on that, Drew. I think what happened at the beginning of the year in here, you just don't have a lot of information to go on. You kind of have got to get feel for, and you've talked to assessors, get a feel for what's happening in each jurisdiction and you start your estimates. As you move into second quarter, you have a little more information; third, a lot; and fourth, you're finalized. I think as this year -- and so what happened last year is we started out -- the pressure is coming from Texas, Florida, a little bit in George, as we have some revaluations occurring there. But we start out the year with an expectation. And in 2015, really high numbers coming out of Texas. We got in the second and third, particularly third quarter, we started to get some information, believing that, that was going to moderate a little bit in the fourth quarter. We got that finalized notice. And so that's why it came down in '15. Looking into '16, we're still getting very high numbers out of Texas, and then we've got revaluations in Georgia and then -- and some in Florida. So I would tell you, where we sit today, we expect to think about assessors, what they do. They're doing their valuation or the assessment in 2016 looking backwards at 2015. A record year for the company in many areas. And so we expect those initial valuations to come out high, and we expect to jump on early, hopefully have some success. And we have some success in [indiscernible] what we think will come out built in our numbers. But hopefully, we'll meet that and even be able to have more success. But I'll you right now, given the performance we had in '15, the valuations are based off of income, it's hard to see those taxes begin to moderate significantly until the cycle changes. And so that's what we're projecting in '16.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one more. Despite the fact that, thatthat cost has likely bottomed, both on the secured and unsecured side, private equity remains pretty aggressive and really building cap rates well. As we look at the cushion between their cost of capital and
componenttext: Okay. And one more. Despite the fact that, thatthat cost has likely bottomed, both on the secured and unsecured side, private equity remains pretty aggressive and really building cap rates well. As we look at the cushion between their cost of capital and what they're paying for assets, are you hearing anything from private players that you talk to about LTVs, debt rates so that they're able to get the kind of fuel this? Just curious if you have any color there or anything that's maybe a lead to the way that you're looking at acquisitions, obviously, with lower leverage levels?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we continue to see private capital securing loan-to-values in 70%, 75% range pretty easily. And the agencies remain very active and coming out of the National Multifamily Housing Council's annual meeting back in January, that mean all the fee
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we continue to see private capital securing loan-to-values in 70%, 75% range pretty easily. And the agencies remain very active and coming out of the National Multifamily Housing Council's annual meeting back in January, that mean all the feedback and all the information that we got is that private capital, both domestic and foreign, indicates a huge appetite for multifamily real estate. It appears its financing windows are wide open very much from a loan-to-value prospective, very much consistent with what we saw in 2015. I think that despite the slight bump that the Fed has made in interest rates earlier, the expectation is that rates are going to continue to remain pretty low this year. So from our perspective, it's really hard to see how the valuation market is going to change much. I think it's going to be another active year, another -- fueled by a lot of investor interest. I think the only thing that potentially is going to evolve is I just think there may be more deal flow. I think there may be more transactions in the market than we've seen in 2015. But I think it will still be a very robust environment.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Wes Golladay from RBC Capital Markets.

componenttext: Okay. And then you guys mentioned a record occupancy. Do you plan to be more aggressive on the renewal leasing, I guess, at least in the near term? And can you verify -- you guys are baking in essentially flat rate growth -- or the similar rate growth versus last year?

componenttext: Yes, our growth rate we expect to be very much in line with 2015 and that's sort of baked in, in that.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then our pricing approach is more aggressive at this time this year than it was last year, both because of the factor of lower exposure and system automatically relates that, but we are also managing the system at a property level, at a market level,
componenttext: And then our pricing approach is more aggressive at this time this year than it was last year, both because of the factor of lower exposure and system automatically relates that, but we are also managing the system at a property level, at a market level, at a floor plan level, depending on the time of the year and the cycle. And we are more aggressive on our settings this year than we were at this time last year.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if we were to pick a point where you guys are probably surprised to the upside, would that be there, do you think, will come from?
componenttext: Okay. So if we were to pick a point where you guys are probably surprised to the upside, would that be there, do you think, will come from?
