componenttextpreview: We are expecting really more toward the back half of the year, starting in July through the rest of the year. Usually as Eric mentioned, the activity picks up as people are planning for their portfolios for the year. So we have sort of evenly July through
componenttext: We are expecting really more toward the back half of the year, starting in July through the rest of the year. Usually as Eric mentioned, the activity picks up as people are planning for their portfolios for the year. So we have sort of evenly July through the rest of the year, a deal a month for 6 months. I mean, there's no magic to that. That's just what we've assumed and we believe that the right thing to do right now.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just last one from me. Just based on the heavy lifting you've done in the sell side, I mean, would you say your more biased on the sale or to sell additional assets? Or pull back given how strong the transaction market is? And would you consider
componenttext: And then just last one from me. Just based on the heavy lifting you've done in the sell side, I mean, would you say your more biased on the sale or to sell additional assets? Or pull back given how strong the transaction market is? And would you consider selling more, I guess, to reduce leverage?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, at this point, we really accomplished a lot of the repositioning we were after with the portfolio. And so we don't have any sort of strategic agendas surrounding repositioning the portfolio at this point, other than a plan to just every year look at t
componenttext: No, at this point, we really accomplished a lot of the repositioning we were after with the portfolio. And so we don't have any sort of strategic agendas surrounding repositioning the portfolio at this point, other than a plan to just every year look at the opportunity to pull capital out of say 10 or 15 assets where we feel like the future growth prospects are not as robust as we could perhaps achieve with another alternative investment. And so it's really now at a point where we're just looking for a steady recycling program and really more focused on match funding that process and looking to keep the balance sheet strong and coverage metrics strong as we continue to do just build portfolio strength sort of through this sort of steady recycling effort going forward.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttextpreview: Let me give a little color, Nick. That's a great question on our guidance changes with a summary of it is we raised guidance FFO for the year $0.03 in total. That's comprised of really 2 things. We did add $0.06 per share to our operating performance, tha
componenttext: Let me give a little color, Nick. That's a great question on our guidance changes with a summary of it is we raised guidance FFO for the year $0.03 in total. That's comprised of really 2 things. We did add $0.06 per share to our operating performance, that's both same-store and non-same store, which both are doing well just several lease-up communities same-store. And so far work sort of in the first quarter and then so we have increased the back part of the year $0.02 and that's really continued similar trends that we have, pricing of 4.5% continued very full occupancy of 96.2% on average carrying through the year as we have projected on the fundamentals but albeit at a little higher level. Occupancy level and the rent level are coming off the Q1 was a little bit higher. That's expenses than offset by the change in volume and the timing of the transactions we talk as about ted offset that and takes us through that back for that year. That's where the net $0.03 comes from. And so we've maintained our same-store guidance range for the year but obviously be doing the math on that, we're not at the midpoint. We're moving toward at the top end of that range right now.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just going to say obviously, as we get more activity on leasing and we'll pay taxes and some of the pics I will take a look at that in the second quarter.
componenttext: I was just going to say obviously, as we get more activity on leasing and we'll pay taxes and some of the pics I will take a look at that in the second quarter.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the occupancy comment, you said basically flat at 96.2%. Do you expect any variance between the quarters? Or should we expect pretty flat occupancy quarter-to-quarter?
componenttext: And then in terms of the occupancy comment, you said basically flat at 96.2%. Do you expect any variance between the quarters? Or should we expect pretty flat occupancy quarter-to-quarter?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're assuming it's pretty to hold. I mean, we're full at 96.2% right now and we expect to hold that through the year right now. And the comps for prior year as we talked about, we'll get a little more challenging and the remaining 3 quarters of the year.
componenttext: We're assuming it's pretty to hold. I mean, we're full at 96.2% right now and we expect to hold that through the year right now. And the comps for prior year as we talked about, we'll get a little more challenging and the remaining 3 quarters of the year. I think last year Q2 was around 96.1%, Q3 was higher, 96.5%, 96.6% and the last quarter was 96.1% or 96.2%. So what we would expect is the whole 96.2% through the year and drop the pricing of 4% to 4.5% as we talked about and that will fall through the bottom line of NOI.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just last question, the spread between the large and secondary markets narrowed in the first quarter from what we saw in 2015. Do you expect that to continue to narrow?
componenttext: Just last question, the spread between the large and secondary markets narrowed in the first quarter from what we saw in 2015. Do you expect that to continue to narrow?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think at this point, we feel like it will tighten as things go up by but we wouldn't expect secondary markets to start outperforming the large markets. Right now, large job growth is so good and the situation is stable. And we would expect those to cont
componenttext: I think at this point, we feel like it will tighten as things go up by but we wouldn't expect secondary markets to start outperforming the large markets. Right now, large job growth is so good and the situation is stable. And we would expect those to continue to lead the way for us.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Rob Stevenson with Janie.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Rob Stevenson with Janie.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given your commentary around acquisitions and given where you started delivering more of the development pipeline, what's the sort of shadow pipeline that you have in terms of back half of '16 starts or '17 starts? And how active are you out there looking
componenttext: Given your commentary around acquisitions and given where you started delivering more of the development pipeline, what's the sort of shadow pipeline that you have in terms of back half of '16 starts or '17 starts? And how active are you out there looking for land or partners to do development projects with?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're pretty active talking to a lot of people, I will say this. I mean, we're -- our model and our strategy is not to bank land. And so we're not a true developer in the sense that we're going to go out and look for land going through zoning proces
componenttext: Well, we're pretty active talking to a lot of people, I will say this. I mean, we're -- our model and our strategy is not to bank land. And so we're not a true developer in the sense that we're going to go out and look for land going through zoning processes and go through the process that went typically have to go through from a full developer perspective. Our model is really built around looking for using the relationships that we've got, to work with developer that perhaps have, if you will, projects ready to go or looking to tie up an opportunity that we find particularly attractive and essentially go at it on a prepurchase basis. We're having a lot of those kind of conversations right now. Obviously, at this point in the cycle, we're pretty careful with our underwriting and our assumptions. We've looked at a number of them so far this year, and frankly, just couldn't get comfortable pulling the trigger on a number of deals believing that what the developer was anticipating in terms of rent levels and rent growth we couldn't get comfortable with it. But we're looking a lot of things right now. We'll see what the back of the year holds.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And given the commentary around acquisitions being difficult, et cetera, with this free cash flow, I mean, is there the ability to pull forward some of your redevelopment opportunities and get to them faster than you otherwise would have put additio
componenttext: Okay. And given the commentary around acquisitions being difficult, et cetera, with this free cash flow, I mean, is there the ability to pull forward some of your redevelopment opportunities and get to them faster than you otherwise would have put additional capital allowing you to drive rental rate higher in the interim?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, there is always the opportunity to do more, but there's not an opportunity to do it better. We really want to be very disciplined in our approach of allocating capital in that area. And what we want -- this is an area where it's very easy to look out
componenttext: Rob, there is always the opportunity to do more, but there's not an opportunity to do it better. We really want to be very disciplined in our approach of allocating capital in that area. And what we want -- this is an area where it's very easy to look out with rose-colored glasses. And what we are trying to do is turn the unit in redevelopment and make sure that another good is matched next to wait, so that we know that the market is telling us that we're getting that return that we're telling you all that we have the return. So we'll remain pretty methodical on that. And we're comfortable with our current pace and feel good about that.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Tom, realizing there's only 3.5% of your portfolio, can you sort of talk about what you're seeing in Houston? And is it certain submarkets that it is really didn't have hardest? Or is it just general malaise across the entire market?
componenttext: And then Tom, realizing there's only 3.5% of your portfolio, can you sort of talk about what you're seeing in Houston? And is it certain submarkets that it is really didn't have hardest? Or is it just general malaise across the entire market?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I mean, I will tell you, Houston in the quarter at 1.4%, and we're a little more out of the inner loop, if you will. I think the suburbs are holding up reasonably well. We have one community in the energy corregidor and it's a hair lower but as
componenttext: You know, I mean, I will tell you, Houston in the quarter at 1.4%, and we're a little more out of the inner loop, if you will. I think the suburbs are holding up reasonably well. We have one community in the energy corregidor and it's a hair lower but as a group, we're holding on to 96% occupancy. turnover there is down 4.4%. Delinquency trends are better and exposure is at 9%, which is a little higher than the company average. But it's hanging in there. Well, hanging in there is a wrong word, but it's pretty consistent across the board.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And then Al, what was the cap rate of the acquisition in the first quarter?

componenttextpreview: It was about the NOI yield was just over 6%, 6.1% and the cap rate which is economic was about 5.75%, 5.8%.
componenttext: It was about the NOI yield was just over 6%, 6.1% and the cap rate which is economic was about 5.75%, 5.8%.

componenttext: In your large markets, the expense growth was actually higher sequentially than it was year-over-year. I imagined a lot of that was due to taxes. But you did come ahead of your expectations and is there concern that expense growth may come in at the high end of your guidance range?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I'll give you on this. It's Tom will have some of this as well. There tends to be a lot of volatility sequentially on expenses, particularly from Q4 to Q1 and still puts your finger on taxes as the big issue. A lot of times, you have a favorable app
componenttext: John, I'll give you on this. It's Tom will have some of this as well. There tends to be a lot of volatility sequentially on expenses, particularly from Q4 to Q1 and still puts your finger on taxes as the big issue. A lot of times, you have a favorable appeals or final results coming in at the end of the prior year and into next year, you're starting with taxes which were 1/4 of your operating expense or more. And you're starting at a full run rate for the year. So that create did a lot of volatility that is one significant point that's probably the trend across the -- Tom, you may have...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, that's the point. I think we're quite confident in our ability to manage expenses and guidelines for the rest of the year on those items.
componenttext: John, that's the point. I think we're quite confident in our ability to manage expenses and guidelines for the rest of the year on those items.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I think, Tom, you mentioned that move-outs were low this period. What do you attribute this to? And is this sustainable?
componenttext: Okay. And then I think, Tom, you mentioned that move-outs were low this period. What do you attribute this to? And is this sustainable?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is not just sustainable. It's been going on for probably 4 straight years that we've seen declining turnover numbers. The driver again this year was the reduction in home buying where folks continue to appreciate the flexibility of leasing a home. Drop
componenttext: It is not just sustainable. It's been going on for probably 4 straight years that we've seen declining turnover numbers. The driver again this year was the reduction in home buying where folks continue to appreciate the flexibility of leasing a home. Drop transfer is the other reason for moving. It stayed fairly steady, but it's really home buying that's pushing the change.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Typically, John, I'll tell you that what I think probably cause this turnover to materially start to move up frankly is we start to see the economy start to heat up. Because as Tom alluded to, the 2 biggest factors that create turnover are people leading
componenttext: Typically, John, I'll tell you that what I think probably cause this turnover to materially start to move up frankly is we start to see the economy start to heat up. Because as Tom alluded to, the 2 biggest factors that create turnover are people leading us to buy a house, which is actually the #2 reason. The #1 reason people leave us is because a change in their employment and a job transfer and things of that nature. And what we typically see is when the economy starts to really get even more robust turnover can pick up a little bit. But, of course, with that improving economic environment, it also continues to create more demand for our product. And so we tend to think that as we see maybe a little pressure on turnover expenses that we likely will capture it on more robust growth if we do, in fact, see material pick up and turnover begin to occur.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So would you characterize employment growth as moderate and not very strong right now in your market?
componenttext: So would you characterize employment growth as moderate and not very strong right now in your market?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say it's better -- a little better than moderate, but we've seen it stronger. That's for sure. I think it's in pretty good position right now. And, of course, we're seeing people stay in our apartments longer than they ever have and lease terms ha
componenttext: I would say it's better -- a little better than moderate, but we've seen it stronger. That's for sure. I think it's in pretty good position right now. And, of course, we're seeing people stay in our apartments longer than they ever have and lease terms have lengthened out a good bit. So we -- it's hard to say anything right now that's going to materially change the turnover pattern absent a major change in sort of economic conditions.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So even though you're not saying it, anyone who is kind of listen to this calls is probably expecting a same-store guidance increase next quarter. And I can appreciate you holding off on doing that and certainly in the year. But what would it take for you
componenttext: So even though you're not saying it, anyone who is kind of listen to this calls is probably expecting a same-store guidance increase next quarter. And I can appreciate you holding off on doing that and certainly in the year. But what would it take for you to have to reiterate your 4% to 5% same-store NOI growth? And I'll just tell you we put in 4% average same-store NOI growth for the remaining 3 quarters of the year to get to just below 5% for the full year. You said you're confident expense control, so it's hard to imagine it won't go up. But I'm just curious what has to happen for it to stay the same.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you put your finger on it, Rich and your math, I would agree with that in terms of expectations for the remainder of the year. And I think what we're depending on or expecting is continue to stay very full in occupancy, 96.2% through the yea
componenttext: Well, I think you put your finger on it, Rich and your math, I would agree with that in terms of expectations for the remainder of the year. And I think what we're depending on or expecting is continue to stay very full in occupancy, 96.2% through the year and have pricing growth of 4% to 4.5% maybe a little above the midpoint on that that continues to go out well. And if those things occur, I think we're confident that the math that you indicated and the position range is correct. So we would have -- it would have to be a fall off in occupancy and rents as we push through that year. Obviously, expenses could be as well but I think we're more confident in the historical and current control of them.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the 2 biggest line items are the year-over-year change in occupancy and the year-over-year change in real estate taxes. And I think both of those line items get a lot more clarity over the next 3 months. And I think that that's really what comes d
componenttext: I think the 2 biggest line items are the year-over-year change in occupancy and the year-over-year change in real estate taxes. And I think both of those line items get a lot more clarity over the next 3 months. And I think that that's really what comes down to. The rent trends are there. And as long as we don't see any volatility beyond what we anticipate in terms of performance on the occupancy we'll be good and, of course, we don't really get the clarity of a real estate taxes and tell really late in the summer.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So saying the occupancy and tax there's more clarity because of a become more difficult comps?
componenttext: So saying the occupancy and tax there's more clarity because of a become more difficult comps?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, just because we get more information. We have obviously more of our leases expiring in the busy summer months than we typically do in the winter months. And so repricing and releasing those units with that greater lease exploration activity, that's a
componenttext: No, just because we get more information. We have obviously more of our leases expiring in the busy summer months than we typically do in the winter months. And so repricing and releasing those units with that greater lease exploration activity, that's a point of volatility, if you will. And then as I mentioned, we won't see clarity on real estate taxes until late Q2 or early Q3.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you comment on some of your of foreign core markets in particular, Orlando is really strong. And the reason what I'm asking about specific markets is because others have been pointing to Florida as an area of strength, but I'm not so su
componenttext: Okay. And then can you comment on some of your of foreign core markets in particular, Orlando is really strong. And the reason what I'm asking about specific markets is because others have been pointing to Florida as an area of strength, but I'm not so sure how long that will stay intact. And so I'm wondering if those are areas where you might consider pruning as long as it's really hot? And just a comment on your long-term prognosis of your plant in Florida and some of your key Florida markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will take the performance side of things. To us, Florida is moving along nicely and we expect that to continue. There's not a sign -- early sign that a slowdown is coming in Orlando, Tampa for Jacksonville or South Florida for that matter. So I feel lik
componenttext: I will take the performance side of things. To us, Florida is moving along nicely and we expect that to continue. There's not a sign -- early sign that a slowdown is coming in Orlando, Tampa for Jacksonville or South Florida for that matter. So I feel like those frankly were a little behind the Texas markets and Atlanta coming onboard strongly. So we feel like they've got a ways to run on that one.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Drew Babin from Robert W. Baird.

componenttext: Quick question on your LOI CapEx projects related to Colonial REIT. componenttext: I'll just give you an overall stroke on that, Drew and not on a property by project by project basis. But one thing you'll notice in our guidance this year is that our cash flow growth is partly built on the fact that our recurring CapEx needs go down a little bit this year. And that plan expected and it's a good part of our growth story. And so as we bought Colonial, we worked through some of those issues and have a little higher recurring CapEx for '14, a little bit in '15, so '16 is a better place to be. To kind of touch on some of your comments. I don't have it property by project or project the project think I look at it as an overall portfolio at this point but it certainly reflects the points that you're making.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: U.S. is 1 month. That thing was bought and really had 1 month of operation, call it, March and so $300,000 really represents of that 1 month, Drew, and you wouldn't read too much into that, that was really there to provide you the ability to pool that out for any people in purposes if you wanted to. headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ivy Zelman with the Zelman & Associates.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you're thinking about maybe the next few years and strategically some of the biggest opportunities that you're excited about and then maybe where you would be the most challenged and most concern, I know you don't have a crystal ball on the economy, bu
componenttext: As you're thinking about maybe the next few years and strategically some of the biggest opportunities that you're excited about and then maybe where you would be the most challenged and most concern, I know you don't have a crystal ball on the economy, but if you think about just from a competitive perspective or where you see that there is the greatest challenges present the greatest opportunities to see how you guys are thinking about.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ivy, this is Eric. I would tell you that I'm more excited about sort of the next 4 or 5 years and I can never remember. We think we have both the platform and the balance sheet in such a strong position that as the opportunity unfolds over the next
componenttext: Well, Ivy, this is Eric. I would tell you that I'm more excited about sort of the next 4 or 5 years and I can never remember. We think we have both the platform and the balance sheet in such a strong position that as the opportunity unfolds over the next 4 or 5 years, I think that the opportunity for us to capture new growth, new value, if you will, is going to get better. I think that the thing that you have to think about is that at some point over the next 4 or 5 years, interest rates will probably start to move up a little bit. I think we all hope, of course, the economy continues to move along but it is cyclical. And while we've had some great performance dynamics over the last 4 or 5 years, it probably does moderate at some point over the next 4 or 5 years. And as a consequence or rising rates and as a consequence of perhaps reaching more normalized sort of trends from an operating perspective, I think our competitive advantages in the markets where we focus our capital grow. And I think our ability to create value versus what these markets are -- versus what people typically associate with these markets growth. And at the end of the day, what were attempting to do is find a way to take shareholder capital and create a competitive advantage for both in terms of how are able to deploy capital and how are able to operate those investments once we make them. And I think both of those things get better for us over the next 4 or 5 years.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful, and I think the value add and what you're doing to drive cash flow is very impressive. So congratulations, guys.
componenttext: That's really helpful, and I think the value add and what you're doing to drive cash flow is very impressive. So congratulations, guys.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Neil Malcolm [ph] with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Neil Malcolm [ph] with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question. We've been hearing some rhetoric that now that supply is probably peaking and particularly in urban markets, now that comparatively land and pricing are more advantageous in the suburban areas, are you seeing any early indications that sup
componenttext: First question. We've been hearing some rhetoric that now that supply is probably peaking and particularly in urban markets, now that comparatively land and pricing are more advantageous in the suburban areas, are you seeing any early indications that supply maybe getting a little bit more elevated in some of our suburban markets that have performed well?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're really not, Neil. I think that the pressures on construction cost, the pressures on land cost, those pressures continue to exist in the suburban locations is much as they do in urban locations. And I would tell you, as I mentioned in my prepared
componenttext: No, we're really not, Neil. I think that the pressures on construction cost, the pressures on land cost, those pressures continue to exist in the suburban locations is much as they do in urban locations. And I would tell you, as I mentioned in my prepared comments, I mean, we see permitting so far this year is down significantly from what it's been for the last 2 years, 40% to 50% down. And so when you look at sort of the expectation of deliveries in contrast that against expect the job growth, next year looks stronger than this year. So we haven't seen any evidence suggesting that supply issues that have for supply that has been creating more issues in some of these more core markets in urban -- heavy urban oriented locations is not going to migrate to the suburbs. We certainly see no evidence of that at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then on the discontinuing supply elevated, are you seeing more opportunities to acquire developments that are at the end of completion or in lease-up Currently? Or is pricing just a little bit too aggressive for you?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then on the discontinuing supply elevated, are you seeing more opportunities to acquire developments that are at the end of completion or in lease-up Currently? Or is pricing just a little bit too aggressive for you?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I do think that that's where the biggest window of opportunity will continue to grow is those projects, new projects that are in the midst of lease-up. That is the point of sort of maximum pressure from a development perspective is when you
componenttext: Well, I mean, I do think that that's where the biggest window of opportunity will continue to grow is those projects, new projects that are in the midst of lease-up. That is the point of sort of maximum pressure from a development perspective is when you get to the point where most, if all the units have been delivered, you're no longer in a position to be capitalizing a lot of the cost. You're still in the lease-up mode, but yet you haven't reached stabilization of break even, if you will. Usually, you're late in the term of a construction financing. And if you're not getting rents and or if the lease-up is not going as fast as fast as you thought it would, that's where the most pressure is created. And frankly, that's where we think the better buying opportunities will continue to emerge. Now we've seen some of those, but we've also seen some very aggressive investors willing to come in and make some what we feel to be some very, very aggressive assumptions and by on that basis, which we're not going to do. But I do think that as we get later in the cycle and later this year into next year and a lot of the supply continues to come online, I think there could be some better buying opportunities.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then last from me, can you talk about what the new lease and renewal rates came in a in the first quarter? And how you're kind of seeing them and into second quarter?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then last from me, can you talk about what the new lease and renewal rates came in a in the first quarter? And how you're kind of seeing them and into second quarter?

componenttext: To be honest with you, I mean, we're not looking at what I would consider to be a lot of B assets or even lower C assets, so I can't really opine on that. But from a -- we continue to see that the higher-quality assets pricing being pretty aggressive, and that's the same whether it is large market or whether it is more of a secondary market. We've seen some very aggressive pricing in places like Charleston, Greenville, even Kansas City. We've seen comparable, in many cases, to what we see take place in the Dallas or Atlanta, even still Houston. I mean we've seen some assets based on our underwriting trade at sub 5 cap rate in Houston. So I think again for the higher-quality assets, which is what we tend to focus on from an acquisitions prospective.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's in full recovery mode, Tom. It is kind of a pleasure to walk recently. Both the 2 assets that were developed and have a Phase II are right on 95 corregidor and doing quite well. The Cobblestone Square project is unique. It is literally built right in
componenttext: It's in full recovery mode, Tom. It is kind of a pleasure to walk recently. Both the 2 assets that were developed and have a Phase II are right on 95 corregidor and doing quite well. The Cobblestone Square project is unique. It is literally built right in the -- Fredericksburg is one of the great satellite cities, and its sort of core is historic District that's very vibrant. We are right in the middle of that, very, very high demand from DC jobs. They're walking distance to rail line. And we are seeing positive rent growth, good occupancy, low exposure and demand on those 3 assets, so I feel good about the future of Fredericksburg.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And, I guess, following up on some comments earlier about the transaction market generally. As you guys just kind of seen the narrowing between large and secondary markets in terms of operating fundamentals, I know obviously some of y
componenttext: That's very helpful. And, I guess, following up on some comments earlier about the transaction market generally. As you guys just kind of seen the narrowing between large and secondary markets in terms of operating fundamentals, I know obviously some of your secondary markets don't have that many trades. But across the entire spectrum, are you guys seeing in the narrowing of cap rates between the large and secondary markets as well?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's been pretty consistent for the last year. So Tom, I would put the spread, the difference of roughly around 50 basis points and it's been that way. I mean if you go back a couple of years ago, it was probably closer to 75 basis points or maybe a
componenttext: Yes, it's been pretty consistent for the last year. So Tom, I would put the spread, the difference of roughly around 50 basis points and it's been that way. I mean if you go back a couple of years ago, it was probably closer to 75 basis points or maybe a little bit more than that. But what we saw over the starting of -- a little over a year ago was just as the cap rates and opportunities in the larger markets became so expensive, we saw capital getting more aggressive in the secondary markets. So that spread today is 50 basis points or less. And depending on the quality assets and the location, I mean, they can be almost right on top of each other frankly in some of the secondary markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do expect that spread to continue to narrow? Or [indiscernible]?
componenttext: We do expect that spread to continue to narrow? Or [indiscernible]?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's nothing that we're seeing right now suggesting that it's going to gap out and spread. I mean we're continuing to see a lot of investor interest in both large and secondary markets. I think that if you begin to see a meaningful increase in interest
componenttext: There's nothing that we're seeing right now suggesting that it's going to gap out and spread. I mean we're continuing to see a lot of investor interest in both large and secondary markets. I think that if you begin to see a meaningful increase in interest rates, you can begin to see it spread a little bit. But the fundamentals being as strong as they are, investor interest in the space being as strong as it is, there's certainly nothing to suggest near-term that we're going to see any real change in cap rates from what we.

componenttext: Most of my questions were answered. I just got one more. With the $90 million of kind of call it free cash flow you guys are expecting to generate an annual basis, as you sit here today, could you rank for us how you think about the options on how to use the incremental free cash flow you're spending off whether that's dividend increase or debt reduction, acquisition? How do you think about potential uses of that free cash?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our most accretive use of capital right now is frankly our redevelopment program. And we're going to, as Tom alluded to earlier, we're going to push that agenda as appropriately as we can. But if we push it too hard, we start to compromise returns.
componenttext: Well, our most accretive use of capital right now is frankly our redevelopment program. And we're going to, as Tom alluded to earlier, we're going to push that agenda as appropriately as we can. But if we push it too hard, we start to compromise returns. But absent that, I mean, frankly, we're comfortable with having the impact of the free cash flow for the moment at least showing up and just building balance sheet strength. As Al alluded to, we -- based on everything that we got right now and our projections, we'll see debt to gross assets decline another 150 basis points this year. That's on top of the comparable level of decline that we got last year. So I think this is a point where discipline is important and it always is important but particularly right now. And if we wind up just not being able to put as much money out from an external growth perspective, and, if you will, building capacity for the future opportunities, I mean, that's okay at some level. I mean we're at a point right now where we feel like our sort of annual long-term earnings growth rate from a cash flow perspective is approaching around 6% or so. We raised the dividend about 6% last quarter or last -- or for this year, if you will. And I've always believed that you want to sort of get the platform in a position where you can kind of compound cash flow and compound dividend growth sort of at comparable rate. So for the moment, we're just perfectly content to stay very active in the transaction market, stay disciplined. And if the net result is, we're just building balance sheet strength and capacity for the future as a fall out or a residual result, that's okay, we're good with that.

componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for participating in the MAA First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance. Mr. Argo, you may begin.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lindy. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, Senior VP of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO. Before we begin with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of
componenttext:
Thank you, Lindy. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, Senior VP of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO. 
Before we begin with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the discussion, company management will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from our projections. We encourage you to refer to the safe harbor language included in yesterday's press release and our '34 Act filings with the SEC, which describe risk factors that may impact future results. These reports, along with a copy of today's prepared comments and an audio copy of this morning's call, will be available on our website.
During this call, we will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures can be found in our earnings release and supplemental financial data. When we reach the question-and-answer portion of the call, I would ask for everyone to please limit their questions to no more than 2 in order to give everyone ample opportunity to participate. Should you have additional questions, please reenter the queue or you're certainly welcome to follow-up with us after we conclude the call. Thank you. 
I'll now turn the call over to Eric

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. As detailed in our earnings release, MAA started 2016 with solid first quarter operating results that were ahead of expectations. Average daily physical occupancy at 96.2% and effective rent growth at 4.5%, drove same store revenues higher th
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. As detailed in our earnings release, MAA started 2016 with solid first quarter operating results that were ahead of expectations. Average daily physical occupancy at 96.2% and effective rent growth at 4.5%, drove same store revenues higher than forecasted. We expect the solid momentum in leasing across our portfolio to continue over the balance of the year.
As Tom will outline in his comments, in the first quarter, our properties continued to post low resident turnover, strong occupancy and captured solid pricing performance. Importantly, we entered the busy summer leasing season with the portfolio well positioned to take advantage of the favorable leasing conditions.
Given the strong start to the year, we have raised the midpoint of our earnings guidance for Core FFO for the full year to $5.81 per share. Investor interest in apartment real estate remains high across our markets, and we continue to find the acquisition environment challenging with pricing reflecting strong demand from private and institutional buyers. Cap rates continue to hold up despite a higher volume and new supply coming into the market.
Our deal flow and transaction pipeline is more robust than we've seen over the last couple of years, and we're certainly underwriting a higher volume of opportunity. We continue to believe that as we work later into the cycle, we will find more opportunities that meet our underwriting criteria. Until then, we plan to remain disciplined and deploy capital only when we are comfortable with the value proposition and earnings accretion to be captured.
As Al will recap, our balance sheet is in a very strong position, and we continue to build capacity for future growth. As noted in our earnings release, Moody's recently moved MAA's current Baa2 rating to a positive outlook. We believe our established record of producing steady value growth and strong operating performance, coupled with credit and coverage metrics that are stronger than any point in our company history, has MAA well positioned to continue to build on long-term competitive advantages across our footprint.
After several years of strong operating performance, questions surrounding the sustainability of the current leasing environment is certainly a hot topic. Based on what we are experiencing across our portfolio, which is diversified across urban, inner loop, suburban and satellite city submarket locations, in both large and secondary markets, demand does not appear to be weakening and all indications are that we will continue to capture good leasing velocity over the next few quarters.
Conversations with a number of developers suggest that construction financing is becoming increasingly harder to secure, and those pressures coupled with higher land and construction costs, are raising the bar to justify new starts. It's worth noting that new construction permitting across our markets is down so far this year compared to the trends we've seen over the last 2 years. We continue to believe that new supply trends are unlikely to materially disrupt the positive momentum for apartment leasing within our submarkets.
Across our portfolio, the outlook for the ratio of new job growth to new apartment deliveries actually improves in 2017 as compared to this year. And while our crystal ball is certainly no better than anyone else's, I do still believe our business retains cyclical patterns. It's difficult to see any sort of near-term significant deterioration of leasing fundamentals. While our occupancy comparisons get tougher in the back half of the year, given the essentially full occupancy status of the portfolio last year, the rent trends remained encouraging.
So overall, our focus for the balance of the year remains centered on taking full advantage of the great operating fundamentals to drive earnings and build platform strength and capacity, while remaining very active in the transaction market and disciplined in our assessment of new growth opportunities.
Before turning the call over to Tom, I do want to thank our MAA associates for their focus and efforts in preparing for the upcoming busy summer leasing season. You have the portfolio well positioned, and I very much appreciate all of your hard work and great results. Tom?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our fourth quarter NOI performance of 7.1% was driven by revenue growth of 5.5% over the prior year and 1.1% sequentially. We have good momentum in rents and saw effective rents increase 4.5% on a year-over-yea
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our fourth quarter NOI performance of 7.1% was driven by revenue growth of 5.5% over the prior year and 1.1% sequentially. We have good momentum in rents and saw effective rents increase 4.5% on a year-over-year basis. Strong average physical occupancy contributed 60 basis of revenue growth over the prior year.
Overall, expenses remain in line, up just 2.9%. Expense discipline has been a hallmark of our operation for years. Our industry-leading initiatives such as our vendor owned inventory shops stocking program, which will be completed this year have allowed us to keep the expense line consistently in check. 
April demand trends continued the positive momentum. Average physical occupancy of 96.2% ran 40 basis points ahead of last year. Our 60-day exposure, which is current vacancy, plus all notices for a 60-day period, is just 8.2%, in line with the same time last year. April blended rents on a lease-over-lease basis are up 4.8%. Occupancy exposure and pricing are all in good shape as we head into our summer leasing season.
On the market front, the vibrant job growth of the large markets is driving strong revenue results of 5.9%. They were led by Orlando, Fort Worth, Atlanta and Charlotte. The secondary markets achieved 4.6% revenue growth. In these markets we're benefiting from improved job growth as well as a sophisticated operating platform that has competitive advantages across our footprint end markets. Revenue growth in Charleston, Greenville, Savannah and Jacksonville stood up -- stood out.
As mentioned above, momentum is strong across our markets with occupancy, rent growth and exposure all showing positive trends. Our only market worry bead is Houston, which represents just 3.5% of our portfolio. We will continue to monitor closely and protect occupancy in this market. 
Move-outs for the portfolio were down for the quarter by 4.4% over the prior year and turnover remained low at 52.2% on a rolling 12-month basis. Move-outs to home buying were down 4.6%. Move-outs to home rentals were also down 14% and represent less than 7% of our total move-outs.
Our focus on minimizing the time between occupants again paid off, the decrease in average days vacant between occupants for the quarter helped drive the first quarter average physical occupancy to 96.2%.
During the quarter, we completed over 1,400 interior unit upgrades. We expect the redevelopment of -- we expect to redevelop approximately 5,000 units this year. As a reminder, on average, we spend about $4,500 per unit and receive an average rent increase of $95 over a comparable nonrenovated unit. This generates a year one cash return of well over 20%.
Our active lease-up communities are performing well. You will notice in the supplemental data that we completed the construction of Station Square at Cosner's Corner II during the quarter. It's currently 94.2% occupied and due to the stronger-than-expected lease-up, we've moved the stabilization date forward one quarter to the third quarter of 2016. Cityscape at Market Center II is leasing well. They are 84% leased and expected to stabilize on schedule in the third quarter of this year.
We're off to a solid start and are well positioned as we head into the summer leasing season. Al?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's first quarter earnings performance, balance sheet position and then finally, on revised earnings guidance for 2016.Core FFO, which excludes certain nonc
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's first quarter earnings performance, balance sheet position and then finally, on revised earnings guidance for 2016.
Core FFO, which excludes certain noncash and nonroutine items, was $1.44 per share for the quarter, which represents a 9% increase over the prior year. And this performance was $0.05 per share above the midpoint of our previous guidance. The strong performance for the quarter was primarily produced by favorable property revenues, which was broad-based. Average occupancy, average effective rents, fees and collections were all slightly better than expectations for the quarter, producing about 2/3 of the favorability.
Operating expenses, interests and G&A expenses combined to produce the remainder of the favorability. 
During the first quarter, we acquired one new community located in Fredericksburg, Virginia for a total investment of $61 million, which was stabilized on acquisition. We also sold one commercial property during the first quarter, Colonial Promenade Nord du Lac, located in Covington, Louisiana, which included both operating retail and land parcels. Total proceeds for this disposition were $33.2 million, and we recorded a total gain on sale of $2.4 million related to the transaction. Also this property represented the final wholly-owned operating commercial assets acquired from Colonial.
During the quarter, we completed the construction of one new community, Station Square at Cosner's Corner Phase II located in Fredericksburg, which remains in lease-up and was 78% occupied at quarter end. We have 4 communities all Phase II expansions remaining under development at the end of the quarter. We funded an additional $13 million of construction costs during the quarter and expect to fund about $63 million to complete the current development communities over the next year or so. 
We continue to expect NOI yields in the 7% to 7.5% range for these communities once completed and stabilized. 
We also invested $6.2 million in our interior redevelopment program during the first quarter, capturing rent increases of 9% above nonrenovated units.
Our balance sheet remains in great shape. As Eric mentioned, during the quarter, Moody's affirmed MAA's unsecured debt rating of Baa2 and revised the outlook on the company to positive from stable. Now, 2 of the 3 primary rating agencies have a positive outlook on MAA, which further exhibits the strength of our balance sheet. 
At quarter end, our leverage defined as net debt to gross assets was 40.7% and defined as total debt to market cap was 29.7%. Our recurring EBITDA covered our fixed charges over 4.2x. At quarter end, 93% of our debt was fixed or hedged against rising interest rates at an average effective rate of just 3.7%, with well laddered maturities averaging 4.6 years. We also had over $645 million of total cash and credit available at quarter end, providing flexibility. 
And finally, as Eric mentioned, we are revising our earnings guidance for 2016 with this release. We're increasing our Core FFO projection by $0.03 per share at the midpoint, to reflect both the strength of the first quarter results and also the offsetting impact of revised transaction volume and timing.
Core FFO is now projected to be $5.71 to $5.91 per share or $5.81 at the midpoint, based on average shares and units outstanding of about $79.6 million. 
Core AFFO is projected to be $5.01 to $5.21 per share or $5.11 per share at the midpoint. You may notice in our release that we introduced one additional metric this quarter, Funds Available for Distribution or FAD, which represents Core FFO less all capital spending, including discretionary items such as, redevelopment and revenue-enhancing capital, as well as corporate and casualty loss expenditures. The intention is to show the overall strength of our earnings and cash flow. For the full year, we expect our FAD or FFO less all internal CapEx to be sufficient to cover our total annual dividend, with $90 million to $95 million remaining for investment or to build capacity for future growth. 
We are maintaining our guidance range for same-store NOI for the full year, along with the other components of previous guidance, with the one exception, our projected acquisition volume, which we now expect to be between $250 million and $350 million for the year. 
Our current plans do not include any need for new equity during 2016, and we now expect to the end the year with our leverage about 130 basis points below the 2015 year-end level.
So that's all we have in the way of prepared comments. So Lindy, we'll now turn the call over to you for questions.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, at this point, we continue to believe that we will be able to put some money to work later this year. We do have a group of properties teed up for disposition that we will look at later this year for possible sale. But it really comes down to findin
componenttext: Well, at this point, we continue to believe that we will be able to put some money to work later this year. We do have a group of properties teed up for disposition that we will look at later this year for possible sale. But it really comes down to finding an attractive use of capital right now, which is as I alluded to, is tough. But I can tell you, we closed the one deal earlier this year. We've got a couple of other properties that are currently under contract going through due diligence. So we continue to believe that as we get later in the year, that we may find more opportunities. But we just felt like, given where we were with the transaction volume so far this year, that -- and based on our earlier assumptions that pulled back just a tad from what we initially had thought was the right thing to do. But we'll see how the year plays out.
