componenttextpreview: We have been expecting really more toward the back-half of the year, starting in July through the rest of the year. Usually, as Eric mentioned, the activity picks up as people are playing for their portfolios for the year. So we have sort of evenly July t
componenttext: We have been expecting really more toward the back-half of the year, starting in July through the rest of the year. Usually, as Eric mentioned, the activity picks up as people are playing for their portfolios for the year. So we have sort of evenly July through the rest of the year, a deal a month for 6 months. I mean, there's no magic to that. That's just what we've assumed and we believe that's the right thing to do right now.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just last one from me. Just based on the heavy lifting you've done on the sell side, I mean, would you say you're more biased on the sell or to sell additional assets? Or pull back given how strong the transaction market is? And would you conside
componenttext: And then just last one from me. Just based on the heavy lifting you've done on the sell side, I mean, would you say you're more biased on the sell or to sell additional assets? Or pull back given how strong the transaction market is? And would you consider selling more, I guess, to reduce leverage?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, at this point, we've really accomplished a lot of the repositioning we were after with the portfolio. And so we don't have any sort of strategic agenda surrounding repositioning the portfolio at this point, other than a plan to just every year look at
componenttext: No, at this point, we've really accomplished a lot of the repositioning we were after with the portfolio. And so we don't have any sort of strategic agenda surrounding repositioning the portfolio at this point, other than a plan to just every year look at an opportunity to pull capital out of say 10 or 15 assets, where we feel like the future growth prospects are not as robust as we could perhaps achieve with another alternative investment. And so it's really now at a point where we're just looking for a steady recycling program and really more focused on match funding that process, and looking to keep the balance sheet strong, the coverage metric strong as we continue to just build portfolio strength sort of through this sort of steady recycling effort going forward.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Nick Joseph with Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Nick Joseph with Citigroup.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can talk about, where same-store is trending relative to initial guidance, recognizing you didn't change it but 1Q results were ahead of expectations, you now have April as well and some clarity into renewals at least for May and June
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can talk about, where same-store is trending relative to initial guidance, recognizing you didn't change it but 1Q results were ahead of expectations, you now have April as well and some clarity into renewals at least for May and June?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little color, Nick. That's a great question on our guidance change, so the summary of it is we raised guidance FFO for the year $0.03 in total. That's comprised of really 2 things. We did add $0.06 per share to our operating performance,
componenttext: Let me give you a little color, Nick. That's a great question on our guidance change, so the summary of it is we raised guidance FFO for the year $0.03 in total. That's comprised of really 2 things. We did add $0.06 per share to our operating performance, that's about same-store and non-same store, which both are doing well. There's several lease-up committees in non-same-store. And so for that sort of it was in the first quarter and then so we haven't increased that part of the year $0.02 and that's really continued similar trends that we have, pricing of 4.5% continued very full occupancy of 96.2% on average, carrying through the year as we have projected on the fundamentals, but albeit at a little bit higher level. I mean occupancy level and the rent level are coming off the Q1 performance was a little bit higher. That's $0.06 has been offset by the change in volume and the timing of the transactions we talked about that offsets that and takes $0.03 of that back for that year. That's where the net $0.03 comes from. And so, we've maintained our same-store guidance range for the year, but obviously doing the math on that, we're not at the midpoint, we're moving toward the top part of that range now.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just going to say, well, obviously, as we get more activity on leasing and real estate taxes and some of the big arms, we will take a look at that in the second quarter.
componenttext: I was just going to say, well, obviously, as we get more activity on leasing and real estate taxes and some of the big arms, we will take a look at that in the second quarter.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then in terms of the occupancy comment, you said basically flat at 96.2%. Do you expect any variance between the quarters? Or should we expect pretty flat occupancy quarter-to-quarter?
componenttext: Right. And then in terms of the occupancy comment, you said basically flat at 96.2%. Do you expect any variance between the quarters? Or should we expect pretty flat occupancy quarter-to-quarter?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're assuming it's pretty to hold.  [indiscernible] at 96.2% right now, and we expect to hold that through the year now. And the comps for prior year as we talked about, they'll get a little more challenging in the remaining 3 quarters of the year. I thi
componenttext: We're assuming it's pretty to hold.  [indiscernible] at 96.2% right now, and we expect to hold that through the year now. And the comps for prior year as we talked about, they'll get a little more challenging in the remaining 3 quarters of the year. I think last year Q2 was around 96.1%, Q3 was higher 96.5%, 96.6% maybe and the last quarter was 96.1% or 96.2%. So what we would expect is to hold 96.2% through the year and drop the pricing of 4% to 4.5% as we talked about and that will come fall to the bottom line of NOI.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just last question, the spread between the large and the secondary markets narrowed in the first quarter from what we saw in 2015. Do you expect that to continue to narrow?
componenttext: Just last question, the spread between the large and the secondary markets narrowed in the first quarter from what we saw in 2015. Do you expect that to continue to narrow?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think at this point, we feel like it will tighten as things go by, but we wouldn't expect secondary markets to start outperforming the large markets. Right now, large -- job growth is so good and the situation is stable that we would expect those to con
componenttext: I think at this point, we feel like it will tighten as things go by, but we wouldn't expect secondary markets to start outperforming the large markets. Right now, large -- job growth is so good and the situation is stable that we would expect those to continue to lead the way for us.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Rob Stevenson with Janie.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Rob Stevenson with Janie.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given your commentary around acquisitions and given where you started delivering more of the development pipeline, what's the sort of shadow pipeline that you have in terms of back half of '16 starts or '17 starts? And how active are you out there looking
componenttext: Given your commentary around acquisitions and given where you started delivering more of the development pipeline, what's the sort of shadow pipeline that you have in terms of back half of '16 starts or '17 starts? And how active are you out there looking for land or partners to do development projects with?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're pretty active talking to a lot of people, I will say this. I mean, we're -- our model and our strategy is not to bank land. And so we're not a true developer in the sense that we're going to go out and look for land and go through zoning proce
componenttext: Well, we're pretty active talking to a lot of people, I will say this. I mean, we're -- our model and our strategy is not to bank land. And so we're not a true developer in the sense that we're going to go out and look for land and go through zoning processes and go through the process that one typically has to go through from a full development perspective. Our model is really built around, looking for using the relationships that we've got to work with developers that perhaps have, if you will, projects ready to go or looking to tie up an opportunity that we find particularly attractive and essentially go at it on a prepurchase basis. We're having a lot of those kind of conversations right now. Obviously, at this point in the cycle, we're being pretty careful with our underwriting and our assumptions. We've looked at a number of them since so far this year, and frankly, just couldn't get comfortable pulling the trigger on a number of deals believing that what the developer was anticipating in terms of rent levels and rent growth, we couldn't get comfortable with it. But yes, we're looking a lot of things right now. We'll see what the back half of the year holds.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I mean, given the commentary around acquisitions being difficult, et cetera, with this free cash flow, I mean, is there the ability to pull forward some of your redevelopment opportunities and get to them faster than you otherwise would ha
componenttext: Okay. And then, I mean, given the commentary around acquisitions being difficult, et cetera, with this free cash flow, I mean, is there the ability to pull forward some of your redevelopment opportunities and get to them faster than you otherwise would have with the additional capital allowing you to drive rental rate higher in the interim?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, Rob, there is always the opportunity to do more, but there's not an opportunity to do it better. We really want to be very disciplined in our approach of allocating capital in that area. And what we want -- this is an area where it's very easy to
componenttext: I mean, Rob, there is always the opportunity to do more, but there's not an opportunity to do it better. We really want to be very disciplined in our approach of allocating capital in that area. And what we want -- this is an area where it's very easy to look out with rose-colored glasses. And what we're trying to do is turn a unit in redevelopment and make sure that another unit is matched next to it, so that we know that the market is telling us that we're getting that return that we're telling you all that we have the return. So we'll remain pretty methodical on that. And we're comfortable with our current pace and feel good about that.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Tom, realizing there's only 3.5% of your portfolio, can you sort of talk about what you're seeing in Houston? And is it certain submarkets there that are really getting hit hardest? Or is it just general malaise across the entire market?
componenttext: Okay. And then Tom, realizing there's only 3.5% of your portfolio, can you sort of talk about what you're seeing in Houston? And is it certain submarkets there that are really getting hit hardest? Or is it just general malaise across the entire market?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I will tell you, Houston during the quarter at 1.4%, and we're a little more out of the inner loop, if you will. I think the suburbs are holding up reasonably well. We have one community in the energy corridor and it's a hair lower, but as a g
componenttext: No. I mean, I will tell you, Houston during the quarter at 1.4%, and we're a little more out of the inner loop, if you will. I think the suburbs are holding up reasonably well. We have one community in the energy corridor and it's a hair lower, but as a group we're holding on to 96% occupancy. Turnover there is down 4.4%, delinquency trends are better and exposure is at 9%, which is a little higher than the company average. But it's hanging in there. Well, hanging in there is a wrong word, but it's pretty consistent across the board.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Al, what was the cap rate on the acquisition in the first quarter?
componenttext: And then Al, what was the cap rate on the acquisition in the first quarter?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was about -- I'll give you 2, the NOI yield was just over 6%, 6.1% and the cap rate, which is an economic was about 5.75%, 5.8%.
componenttext: It was about -- I'll give you 2, the NOI yield was just over 6%, 6.1% and the cap rate, which is an economic was about 5.75%, 5.8%.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your large markets, the expense growth was actually higher sequentially than it was year-over-year. I imagine a lot of that was due to taxes. But did this come in ahead of your expectations and is there a concern that expense growth might come in at th
componenttext: In your large markets, the expense growth was actually higher sequentially than it was year-over-year. I imagine a lot of that was due to taxes. But did this come in ahead of your expectations and is there a concern that expense growth might come in at the high-end of your guidance range?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I'll give you some of this and Tom might have some on this as well. But no, I mean the tax -- there tends to be a lot of volatility sequentially on expenses, particularly from Q4 to Q1 and you put your finger on taxes is a big issue. Lot of times, y
componenttext: John, I'll give you some of this and Tom might have some on this as well. But no, I mean the tax -- there tends to be a lot of volatility sequentially on expenses, particularly from Q4 to Q1 and you put your finger on taxes is a big issue. Lot of times, you have favorable appeals or final results coming in at the end of the prior year and then in the next year, you're starting with taxes, which are a 1/4 of your operating expenses or more. And you're starting on a full run rate for the year. So that created a lot of volatility, that is one significant point that's probably the trend across it. Tom, you may have...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, and also -- I mean, John, that's the point. I think we're quite confident in our ability to manage expenses and guidelines for the rest of the year on those items.
componenttext: No, and also -- I mean, John, that's the point. I think we're quite confident in our ability to manage expenses and guidelines for the rest of the year on those items.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I think, Tom, you mentioned that move-outs were low this period. What do you attribute this to? And is this sustainable?
componenttext: Okay. And then I think, Tom, you mentioned that move-outs were low this period. What do you attribute this to? And is this sustainable?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is not just sustainable. It's been going on for probably 4 straight years that we've seen declining turnover numbers. The driver again this year was the reduction in home buying where folks continue to appreciate the flexibility of leasing a home. Job
componenttext: It is not just sustainable. It's been going on for probably 4 straight years that we've seen declining turnover numbers. The driver again this year was the reduction in home buying where folks continue to appreciate the flexibility of leasing a home. Job transfer is the other reason for moving, it stayed fairly steady. But it's really home buying that's pushing the change.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Typically, John, I'd tell you that, what I think probably causes turnover to materially start to move up frankly, is we start to see the economy start to heat up. Because as Tom alluded to, the 2 biggest factors that create turnover, are people leaving us
componenttext: Typically, John, I'd tell you that, what I think probably causes turnover to materially start to move up frankly, is we start to see the economy start to heat up. Because as Tom alluded to, the 2 biggest factors that create turnover, are people leaving us to buy a house, or they're -- which is actually the #2 reason. The #1 reason people leave us is because of a change in their employment and a job transfer and things of that nature. And what we typically see is, when the economy starts to really get even more robust, turnover can pick up a little bit. But, of course, with that improving economic environment, it also continues to create more demand for our product. And so we tend to think that as we see maybe a little pressure on turnover expenses that we likely will capture it on in more robust rent growth, if we do, in fact, see material pick up and turnover begin to occur.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So would you characterize the employment growth as moderate and not very strong right now in your market?
componenttext: So would you characterize the employment growth as moderate and not very strong right now in your market?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say it's better then -- a little better than moderate, but we've seen it stronger, that's for sure. I think it's in pretty good position right now. And, of course, we're seeing people stay in our apartments longer than they ever have and lease ter
componenttext: I would say it's better then -- a little better than moderate, but we've seen it stronger, that's for sure. I think it's in pretty good position right now. And, of course, we're seeing people stay in our apartments longer than they ever have and lease terms have lengthened out, a good bit. So we -- it's hard to say anything right now that's going to materially change the turnover pattern absent a major change in sort of economic conditions.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So even though you're not saying it, anyone who's kind of listening to this calls is probably expecting a same-store guidance increase next quarter. And I could appreciate you holding off and doing that this early in the year. But what would it have -- wh
componenttext: So even though you're not saying it, anyone who's kind of listening to this calls is probably expecting a same-store guidance increase next quarter. And I could appreciate you holding off and doing that this early in the year. But what would it have -- what would it take for you to have to reiterate your 4% to 5% same-store NOI growth? And I'll just tell you, we put in 4% average same-store NOI growth for the remaining 3 quarters of the year to get you just below 5% for the full year. You said you're confident in expense control, so it's hard to imagine it won't go up. But I'm just curious what has to happen for it to stay the same?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you put your finger on it, Rich and your math is, I would agree with that in terms of expectations for the remainder of the year. And I think, what we're betting on or expecting is to continue to stay very full in occupancy, 96.2% through th
componenttext: Well, I think you put your finger on it, Rich and your math is, I would agree with that in terms of expectations for the remainder of the year. And I think, what we're betting on or expecting is to continue to stay very full in occupancy, 96.2% through the year and then to have pricing growth of 4% to 4.5% that would be little above the midpoint on that, that continues to go out well. And if those things occur, I think we're confident that the math that you indicated and the position range is correct. So we would have -- it would have to be a fall-off in occupancy and rents as we push through the year. Obviously, expenses could be as well, but I think we're more confident in the historical and current control events.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the 2 biggest line items are, the year-over-year change in occupancy and the year-over-year change in real estate taxes. And I think both of those line items get a lot more clarity over the next 3 months. And I think that, that's really what it co
componenttext: I think the 2 biggest line items are, the year-over-year change in occupancy and the year-over-year change in real estate taxes. And I think both of those line items get a lot more clarity over the next 3 months. And I think that, that's really what it comes down to. The rent trends are there. And as long as we don't see any volatility beyond what we anticipate in terms of performance on occupancy we'll be good. And of course, we don't really get good clarity on real estate taxes until really late in the summer.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're saying the occupancy and taxes become more -- there is more clarity because they become more difficult comps?
componenttext: So you're saying the occupancy and taxes become more -- there is more clarity because they become more difficult comps?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, just because we get more information. We have obviously more of our leases expiring in the busy summer months than we typically do in the winter months. And so repricing and releasing those units with that greater level of lease expiration activity, t
componenttext: No, just because we get more information. We have obviously more of our leases expiring in the busy summer months than we typically do in the winter months. And so repricing and releasing those units with that greater level of lease expiration activity, that's a point of volatility, if you will. And then as I mentioned, we won't see clarity on real estate taxes until late Q2 or early Q3.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you comment on some of your Florida markets, in particular Orlando was really strong. And the reason why I'm asking about specific market is because others have been pointing to Florida as an area of strength, and -- but I'm not so sure
componenttext: Okay. And then can you comment on some of your Florida markets, in particular Orlando was really strong. And the reason why I'm asking about specific market is because others have been pointing to Florida as an area of strength, and -- but I'm not so sure how long that will stay intact. And so I'm wondering if those are areas where you might consider pruning as long as it's really hot? And just a comment under long-term prognosis of your plan in Florida, in some of your key Florida markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will take the performance side of things. To us, Florida is moving along nicely and we expect that to continue. There's not a sign -- early sign that a slowdown is coming in Orlando, Tampa or Jacksonville or South Florida for that matter. So I feel like
componenttext: I will take the performance side of things. To us, Florida is moving along nicely and we expect that to continue. There's not a sign -- early sign that a slowdown is coming in Orlando, Tampa or Jacksonville or South Florida for that matter. So I feel like those frankly were a little behind the Texas markets and Atlanta coming on board strongly. So we feel like they've got a ways to run on that one.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Drew Babin with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the ROI CapEx projects related to Colonial. Now that some of those properties are now in their second year post renovation, is there any clarity on what year 2 cash flow yields may look like on those properties? Is it likely to look a lo
componenttext: Quick question on the ROI CapEx projects related to Colonial. Now that some of those properties are now in their second year post renovation, is there any clarity on what year 2 cash flow yields may look like on those properties? Is it likely to look a lot like year 1? Or is there some kind of diminishing benefit to the renovations?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just give you an overall stroke on that, Drew and not on a property but by project by project basis. But one thing you'll notice in our guidance this year is that our cash flow growth is partly built on the fact that our recurring CapEx needs go down
componenttext: I'll just give you an overall stroke on that, Drew and not on a property but by project by project basis. But one thing you'll notice in our guidance this year is that our cash flow growth is partly built on the fact that our recurring CapEx needs go down a little bit this year. And that's planned and expected and it's a good part of our growth story. And so as we bought Colonial, we worked through some of those issues and had a little higher recurring CapEx for 2014, a little bit in '15 and still '16 is a better place to be. To kind of touch on some of your comments, I don't have it property by property or project by project, I think we look at it as overall portfolio at this point, but it certainly reflects the points that you're making.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly on the Fredericksburg acquisition, I think you mentioned it was $61 million. I mean looking in the supplemental the year-to-date NOI of $300 million, I'm just curious, is there a renovation that was just completed? You said it was acquir
componenttext: And then secondly on the Fredericksburg acquisition, I think you mentioned it was $61 million. I mean looking in the supplemental the year-to-date NOI of $300 million, I'm just curious, is there a renovation that was just completed? You said it was acquired stabilized. So I'm just hoping to kind of square away where the cap rates come from.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's just one month, that thing was bought, really had one month of operation, call it, March. And so $300,000 really just represented that one month, Drew, so you wouldn't read too much into that. That was really there to provide you the ability to pul
componenttext: That's just one month, that thing was bought, really had one month of operation, call it, March. And so $300,000 really just represented that one month, Drew, so you wouldn't read too much into that. That was really there to provide you the ability to pull that out for NAB building purposes, if you wanted to. And so, you can -- you'd have to get a full year run rate that's accurate, which we can provide for you offline if we need to.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I mean, okay. I just thought that was a quarterly number, which would...
componenttext: Right. I mean, okay. I just thought that was a quarterly number, which would...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you could take that really times 12, probably and get close.
componenttext: Yes, you could take that really times 12, probably and get close.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ivy Zelman with Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ivy Zelman with Zelman & Associates.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you're thinking about maybe the next few years and strategically some of the biggest opportunities that you're excited about and then maybe where you would be the most challenged and most concerned, I know you don't have a crystal ball on the economy,
componenttext: If you're thinking about maybe the next few years and strategically some of the biggest opportunities that you're excited about and then maybe where you would be the most challenged and most concerned, I know you don't have a crystal ball on the economy, but as you think about it just from a competitive perspective or where you feel that there is the greatest challenges versus the greatest opportunities, just to see how you guys are thinking about.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ivy, this is Eric. I would tell you that, I'm more excited about sort of the next 4 or 5 years and I can ever remember. We think we have both the platform and the balance sheet in such a strong position that as the opportunity unfolds over the next
componenttext: Well, Ivy, this is Eric. I would tell you that, I'm more excited about sort of the next 4 or 5 years and I can ever remember. We think we have both the platform and the balance sheet in such a strong position that as the opportunity unfolds over the next 4 or 5 years, I think that the opportunity for us to capture new growth, new value, if you will, is going to get better. I think the thing that -- I think you have to think about is that at some point over the next 4 or 5 years, interest rates will probably start to move up a little bit. I think we all hope, of course, the economy continues to move along, but it is cyclical. And while we've had some great performance dynamics over the last 4 or 5 years, it probably does moderate at some point over the next 4 or 5 years. And as a consequence of rising rates and as a consequence of perhaps reaching more normalized sort of trends from an operating perspective, I think our competitive advantages in the markets where we focus are capital growth. And I think our ability to create value versus what these markets are -- versus what people typically associate with these markets grows. And at the end of the day, what we're attempting to do is find a way to take shareholder capital and create a competitive advantage for, both in terms of how we're able to deploy capital and then how we're able to operate those investments once we make them. And I think both of those things get better for us over the next 4 or 5 years.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's extremely helpful, and I think the value add and what you're doing to drive cash flow is very impressive. So congratulations, guys.
componenttext: That's extremely helpful, and I think the value add and what you're doing to drive cash flow is very impressive. So congratulations, guys.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Neil Malkin with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Neil Malkin with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question. We've been hearing some rhetoric that now the supply is probably peaking particularly in urban markets, now that comparatively land and pricing are more advantageous in the suburban areas, are you seeing any early indications that supply m
componenttext: First question. We've been hearing some rhetoric that now the supply is probably peaking particularly in urban markets, now that comparatively land and pricing are more advantageous in the suburban areas, are you seeing any early indications that supply maybe getting a little bit more elevated in some of your suburban markets that it performed well?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, really not, Neil. I mean, I think that the pressures on construction costs, the pressures on land costs, those pressures continue to exist in the suburban locations as much as they do in urban locations. And I would tell you, as I mentioned in my prep
componenttext: No, really not, Neil. I mean, I think that the pressures on construction costs, the pressures on land costs, those pressures continue to exist in the suburban locations as much as they do in urban locations. And I would tell you, as I mentioned in my prepared comments, I mean, we see permitting so far this year is down significantly from what it's been for the last 2 years, 40% to 50% down. And so -- and when you look at sort of the expectation of deliveries and contrast that against expected job growth, next year looks stronger than this year. So we haven't seen any evidence suggesting that supply issues that have -- or supply that has been creating more issues in some of these more core markets in urban -- heavy urban oriented locations is now going to migrate to the suburbs. We certainly see no evidence of that at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, on the -- just considering supply is elevated, are you seeing more opportunities to acquire developments that are at the end of completion or in lease-up currently? Or is pricing just a little bit too aggressive for you?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, on the -- just considering supply is elevated, are you seeing more opportunities to acquire developments that are at the end of completion or in lease-up currently? Or is pricing just a little bit too aggressive for you?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's -- I mean, that's -- I do think that that's where the biggest window of opportunity will continue to grow is those projects, new projects that are in the midst of lease-up. That is the point of sort of maximum pressure from a development pers
componenttext: Well, that's -- I mean, that's -- I do think that that's where the biggest window of opportunity will continue to grow is those projects, new projects that are in the midst of lease-up. That is the point of sort of maximum pressure from a development perspective is when you get to the point where most, of all the units have been delivered, you're no longer in a position to be capitalizing a lot of the cost, you're still in the lease-up mode, but yet you haven't reached stabilization or breakeven, if you will. Usually, you're late in the term of the construction financing. And if you're not getting the rents and/or the lease-up is not going as fast as fast as you thought it would, that's where the most pressure is created. And frankly, that's where we think the better buying opportunities will continue to emerge. Now we've seen some of those, but we've also seen some very aggressive investors willing to come in and make some, what we feel to be some very, very aggressive assumptions and buy on that basis, which we're not going to do. But I do think that as we get later in the cycle and later this year into next year and a lot of the supply continues to come online, I think there could be some better buying opportunities.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttextpreview: To be honest with you, I mean, we're not looking at what I would consider to be a lot of B assets or even lower C assets, so I can't really opine on that. But from a -- we continue to see that the higher-quality assets' pricing being pretty aggressive. An
componenttext: To be honest with you, I mean, we're not looking at what I would consider to be a lot of B assets or even lower C assets, so I can't really opine on that. But from a -- we continue to see that the higher-quality assets' pricing being pretty aggressive. And that's the same, whether it is large market or whether it's more of a secondary market. We've seen some very aggressive pricing in places like Charleston, Greenville, even Kansas City. We've seen comparable, in many cases, to what we see take place in the Dallas or Atlanta, even still Houston. I mean, we've seen some assets based on our underwriting trade at sub 5 cap rates in Houston. So I think it's again for the higher-quality assets, which is what we tend to focus on from an acquisitions prospective.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's in full recovery mode, Tom. It is kind of a pleasure to walk recently. Both the 2 assets that were developed and have the Phase II are right on 95% corridor, and doing quite well. The Cobblestone Square project is unique. It is literally built right
componenttext: It's in full recovery mode, Tom. It is kind of a pleasure to walk recently. Both the 2 assets that were developed and have the Phase II are right on 95% corridor, and doing quite well. The Cobblestone Square project is unique. It is literally built right in the Fredericksburg. Fredericksburg is one of those great satellite cities and its sort of core is historic district that's very vibrant. We are right in the middle of that, and very, very high demand from DC jobs. They're walking distance to rail line. And we are seeing a positive rent growth, good occupancy, well exposure and demand on those 3 assets. So I feel good about the future of Fredericksburg.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then I guess, following-up on some comments earlier about the transaction market generally. As you guys just kind of seen a narrowing between large and secondary markets in terms of operating fundamentals, I know obviously some of
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then I guess, following-up on some comments earlier about the transaction market generally. As you guys just kind of seen a narrowing between large and secondary markets in terms of operating fundamentals, I know obviously some of your secondary markets don't have as many trades, but across the entire spectrum, are you guys seeing a narrowing of cap rates between the large and secondary markets as well?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's been pretty consistent for the last year. So Tom, I would put the spread or the difference of roughly around 50 basis points and it's been that way. I mean, if you go back a couple of years ago, it was probably closer to 75 basis points or may b
componenttext: Yes, it's been pretty consistent for the last year. So Tom, I would put the spread or the difference of roughly around 50 basis points and it's been that way. I mean, if you go back a couple of years ago, it was probably closer to 75 basis points or may be a little bit more than that. But what we saw over the starting of -- a little over a year ago, was just as the cap rates and opportunities in the larger markets became so expensive, we saw capital getting more aggressive in the secondary market. So that spread today is 50 basis points or less. And depending on the quality of the assets and the location, I mean, they can be almost right on top of each other frankly in some of these secondary markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Would you expect that spread to continue to narrow, or kind of stay the same?
componenttext: Got it. Would you expect that spread to continue to narrow, or kind of stay the same?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's nothing that we're seeing right now suggesting that it's going to gap out and spread. I mean we continuing to see a lot of investor interest in both large and secondary markets. I think that, if you begin to see a meaningful increase in interest r
componenttext: There's nothing that we're seeing right now suggesting that it's going to gap out and spread. I mean we continuing to see a lot of investor interest in both large and secondary markets. I think that, if you begin to see a meaningful increase in interest rates, you could begin to see it spread a little bit. But the fundamentals being as strong as they are, investor interest in this space being as strong as it is, there's certainly nothing to suggest near-term that we're going to see any real change in cap rates from what we see.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Most of my questions are answered. I just got one more. With the $90 million of kind of call it free cash flow, you guys are expecting to generate on annual basis. As you sit here today, could you rank for us how you think about the options or how to use the incremental free cash flow you're spinning off, I mean, whether that's dividend increase or debt reduction or acquisition? How do you think about potential uses of that free cash?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our most accretive use of capital right now is frankly our redevelopment program. And we're going to, as Tom alluded to earlier, we're going to push that agenda as appropriately as we can. But if we push it too hard, we start to compromise returns.
componenttext: Well, our most accretive use of capital right now is frankly our redevelopment program. And we're going to, as Tom alluded to earlier, we're going to push that agenda as appropriately as we can. But if we push it too hard, we start to compromise returns. So -- but absent that, I mean, Buck, I mean, frankly, we're comfortable with having the impact of the free cash flow for the moment at least showing up and just building balance sheet strength. And as Al alluded to, we -- based on everything that we've got right now in our projections, we'll see debt to gross assets decline another 150 basis points this year. That's on top of the comparable level of decline that we got last year. So I think this is a point where discipline is important and it always is important but particularly right now. And if we wind up just not being able to put as much money out from an external growth perspective, and, if you will, building capacity for the future opportunities, I mean, that's okay at some level. I mean we're at a point right now where, we feel like our sort of annual long-term earnings growth rate for the -- from a cash flow perspective is approaching around 6% or so. We raised the dividend about 6% last quarter or last -- for this year, if you will. And I've always believed that you want to sort of get the platform into position where you can kind of compound cash flow and compound dividend growth sort of at a comparable rate. So for the moment, we're just perfectly content to stay very active in the transaction market, stay disciplined. And if the net result is, we're just building balance sheet strength and capacity for the future as a fall out or a residual result, that's okay, we're good with that.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
