componenttext: Okay. And then just in the second question is, do you feel like there are some sort of new paradigm emerging here? Obviously, your portfolio has always been thought to be low barrier, high risk supply markets offset by job growth, but the story today is a lot of urban development and maybe a causal factor to problems, do you expect this reverse back to more normalized conditions where your markets become the centerpiece of supply risk? Or do you think there are something changing in your world that actually makes you a little bit more supply more Teflon, I guess?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, I don't know. I will say this, we've always gone at this with a belief that we're trying to build a portfolio in markets and in submarkets and at price points that offer us the ability, and you've heard me say this for years, outperform over the ful
componenttext: Rich, I don't know. I will say this, we've always gone at this with a belief that we're trying to build a portfolio in markets and in submarkets and at price points that offer us the ability, and you've heard me say this for years, outperform over the full cycle. And market fads come and go. Cap rates come and go. But and we're not driven by those things. We're driven by recurring cash flow. We deploy capital with that thought. We allocate capital across the region with that thought. We like the strong job growth metrics of the Southeast markets. We can't do anything about supply per se other than just be sure we've got a very competitive platform and that we know how to operate very aggressively. And basically, we feel like we can compete with anybody, and we can compete superior to a lot of people we compete within these markets. So the supply will do what it does. What I really am more focused on is being sure deploying capital where demand is going to be, and we think that demand is largely a function of job growth and economic growth, and we liked the Southeast for that reason and...

componenttext: Okay. And then, Tom, Eric, I mean, what was the last time when you go back and look at the secondary markets actually outperformed your large markets for any like length of period of time. I know that you've gotten smaller as a percent gets you down to like 35% of NOI now. But I'm curious as to as you think about the profile going forward and sources of capital and things of that nature, whether or not that goes significantly lower because it seems like it's been a while since those markets are really outperformed?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You have to go back to really 2008, late 2008 throughout most of 2009 time frame when we saw obviously a fairly deep recession taking place in the country. We saw the markets really take a beating. And those kind averments, a recessionary ferment, where j
componenttext: You have to go back to really 2008, late 2008 throughout most of 2009 time frame when we saw obviously a fairly deep recession taking place in the country. We saw the markets really take a beating. And those kind averments, a recessionary ferment, where job loss is really driving sort of the economic landscape, that tends to be where the secondary markets hold up a lot better, and you can actually get to a point where the secondary markets are outperforming the large markets both in terms of occupancy and our ability to hold rents. So I think, I mean, they are really more for that purpose, for sort of severe economic or economic downturn conditions. I think that what you're going to see is that as we have continued to cycle capital out of some of the older investments that we've had, as you point out, a lot given the sort of base, origination of the company and where we sort of came from, a lot of the asset happen to be in some of the more tertiary markets of the portfolio, and that's we cycled a lot of exited close to 20 properties over the last several years, selling over 13,000 apartments. I think as we go forward, you'll see us continue with a primary focus on cycling out of some of the older assets where the CapEx requirements are growing and the after CapEx NOI is likely to show more moderation, and that will continue to, as an example, the 7 properties that we have under contract right now, 3 of them are North Carolina, one of them is in Greensboro, one of them is in Huntsville, and so I think that -- but having said that, you'll see us continue to look at opportunities in places like Charleston, Kansas City, Fredericksburg, clearly other secondary markets but we think and new assets we think the return on capital will be better over the next several years versus what we're selling.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we're very interested in pursuing opportunities. As I mentioned in my prepared comments, our deal flow is writing probably 30% higher than it was this time last year. We are pushing hard on underwriting and processing as much opportunity as
componenttext: Well, I mean, we're very interested in pursuing opportunities. As I mentioned in my prepared comments, our deal flow is writing probably 30% higher than it was this time last year. We are pushing hard on underwriting and processing as much opportunity as we can. I think that, as always, though, our focus is centered on an ability to make investment and ultimately capture a NOI yield and a cash flow growth rate out of that investment that is at or better than the long-term average that we are -- goal that we have for the company. And so we're not want to be -- I mean, while we certainly are aware of the concept surrounding a focus on capturing our spread between our current cost of capital and current cap rates, our focus is just always instead centered on have allocation model where the priority on capturing and NOI yield that meets or exceeds the long-term earnings growth for probably half of the company and an ability all the way to achieve and IRR or return of capital long haul that's better than what we think our investors are expecting.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: In the first quarter, it looks like you had a 40 basis point lift in your same property revenue growth and fees. So what was not accounted for rent growth and occupancy growth? Are you seeing different contribution there with that? Seem to be absent in the second quarter? And I was just wondering whether that was sort of a deceleration off of more rapid fee growth in past years or whether there's anything deliberate going on property level, maybe being a little less aggressive with these?

componenttextpreview: I'll give you some color and Tom can jump on that. If you think about the first quarter, Tom, we had a little bit remaining year-over-year occupancy lift in the first quarter. And as you build occupancy, fees come with that. And so that happened, I think,
componenttext: I'll give you some color and Tom can jump on that. If you think about the first quarter, Tom, we had a little bit remaining year-over-year occupancy lift in the first quarter. And as you build occupancy, fees come with that. And so that happened, I think, in the third quarter, fourth quarter and the first quarter to a smaller extent. So -- but that very fact is part of that the discussion earlier that's given us the tougher comps as we compare back to last year. We think this going forward are going to growth in our line in good normalized growth. We were having just a very high, very good growth last year related to the growing occupancy and the final --

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would say the other thing that has been a headwind on fees is really, frankly, in positive turnover down consistently. We're getting less and less in the way of termination in rate fees which work for us but those are material fees. And then se
componenttext: Yes. And I would say the other thing that has been a headwind on fees is really, frankly, in positive turnover down consistently. We're getting less and less in the way of termination in rate fees which work for us but those are material fees. And then secondly, in the first quarter, we had a sort of a lights out delinquency bad debt month and we're still very, very good where we are but not quite as good.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that all makes sense. And then one other question. Some of the markets you mentioned these those large markets and secondary markets, it seems like demand growth is continuing to track very well based on your comments. But it looks like just on the
componenttext: Okay, that all makes sense. And then one other question. Some of the markets you mentioned these those large markets and secondary markets, it seems like demand growth is continuing to track very well based on your comments. But it looks like just on the pure rank growth basis, there was a little bit of deceleration in a few of the markets. I was just wondering kind of -- was that -- is that a supply issue primarily? Not direct but indirect? Is that something that potentially could come off of the coming quarters? What is behind that?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of course, it's going to depend on the market we're talking about and so forth. But broadly, I would tell you that wherever we see any sort of, if you will, a deceleration on a quarter-over-quarter basis in a given market, more often than not, it's a func
componenttext: Of course, it's going to depend on the market we're talking about and so forth. But broadly, I would tell you that wherever we see any sort of, if you will, a deceleration on a quarter-over-quarter basis in a given market, more often than not, it's a function of supply issue in a particular submarket affecting a given property or something to that degree. I mean, fundamentally, the demand dynamics, job growth, population trends, all the other sort of factors that drive renters and leasing prospects to our properties, all those fundamentals continued to show evidence of sustained strength and consistent with what we've been seeing for some time. And where there's moderation, if you will, it's going to be pockets of supply here and there.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Tayo Okusanya from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Tayo Okusanya from Jefferies.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a quick question around supply. I know we've all kind of hard on this. It seems like acknowledging that some of your markets are seeing increased supply and that it's manageable. are There any markets where you start to worry that supply starts to
componenttext: So just a quick question around supply. I know we've all kind of hard on this. It seems like acknowledging that some of your markets are seeing increased supply and that it's manageable. are There any markets where you start to worry that supply starts to overwhelm the system and then you suddenly lose pricing power similar to what we're kind of seen in New York and San Francisco?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would tell you, Tayo, that I mean, obviously, we worry about it all the time. But 2 things that I would tell you is that, obviously, a lot of the supply that we are seeing in some of our markets, it's tending to be more concentrated in some of the
componenttext: Well, I would tell you, Tayo, that I mean, obviously, we worry about it all the time. But 2 things that I would tell you is that, obviously, a lot of the supply that we are seeing in some of our markets, it's tending to be more concentrated in some of the more urban core center areas, which happens to be where we don't have a lot of exposure. And so we don't see thing suggesting that anything different is likely to play out in the near term. So we continue to feel okay about that. I mean, we've been saying that supply has picked up over the last couple of years, so I mean we're not it's not like anything you think I mean it's just it happens to be in areas that we don't have a lot of concentration in. But I would tell you, if you are trying to get at what's going to change the country, what's going to change the dynamic, leasing dynamic and a materially, and put us into a scenario where we're having the same kind of pressures that some of these portfolios in San Francisco and New York are having from my perspective, the only thing that really materially weakens the chemistry for us, is that we see a material weakening on the demand side of the equation. We see some sort of economic recession take place and a material way that cost was job loss to come back into the equation and jobs to really searchable that. And absent some sort of major disruption on the demand side of the equation, right now, it's hard to see anything that's going to cause a material disruption in that positive leasing chemistry that continues to allow us to deliver, we think, pretty about long-term trend performance. It's moderated from what it was a couple of years ago. It's a consequence really of a little supply but, honestly, just tougher comps. And that's been -- that's where the pressure spend that the strong trends per se are going to continue from what we see today.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: No, I think Tayo as we talk about a little bit in the call, I mean, very good expense control, which is at time say hallmark and we're very proud to continue that. I think across the line as personnel, R&M, marketing for sure, very much under control. The 1 exception is real estate taxes we talked about. We did get majority of our evaluations come out in the second quarter, which is typical. Beginning of the year you sort of getting on that just based on trends, as so came out a little higher than we thought, particularly in Texas, as valuations, Dallas and Houston softened like we had thought it hope. I think as were the only pressure expense is we raise guidance of a percent at the midpoint on real estate tax guidance now we think it will grow by 5.5% to 6.5%. That's a 1/3 of the operating expenses. But even with that, we reduced we're able to reduce the midpoint of our expense expectations for the year of about 25 basis points. So summary of all that is we expect to be well under control.

componenttext: Wes, at this point, we have. I mean, obviously, we'll be taking a hard look at expectations for '17 as we work towards developing guidance and this guidance and so forth on that. But as we sit here today, we haven't seen any evidence that weakness in the employment trends are going to create any issues for us. Of course, the other thing that's strong underpinning to the demand component of our business is just all those sort of psychology surrounding home ownership versus renting their homes and all the demographic factors that are continuing to work in our favor. And so those powerful forces are there, and they're going to continue from everything that we see. What allows those powerful forces to really be unleashed, of course, is a good job employment scenario where people can get the jobs. And from what we see, employment transparent to generally some party for the larger markets around the Southeast tend to be at the high end relative to what we see elsewhere across the country. And that's largely, frankly, why we tend to focus on as much as we do on this region.

componenttext: We're talking about -- you're referring to comps as what's happening in the market. And we would have to -- we can get off-line and figure out a way to pull that up for you, Conor. But basically what we do is that when we do a renovate, we go into our system and we measure that the system knows that, that unit has had a capital infusion and that -- and therefore, when we look at market rate trends over the next 7, 8 years, we take our comparison and for our unit, and it has -- that premium markup has to be there on a continuous basis for 5 or 7 years. So in other words, whatever premium we got to target when we initially did the deal, we attracted to make sure that that premium stays in place over the life of the investment that we make, and there's -- we have classifications on by unit, where we can charge premiums for views, we can charge premiums for this upgrade, we can charge premiums for whatever. We got a lot of different premium levers on when we throw those levels, they stay there. And that becomes the benchmark that compares against the market.

Where the mortgage rates are at, what's happening I guess is there any signs in your incoming tenants whether it's average FICO or rental income or some other metrics that something is changing in the demo database or change in the propensity to renter preventing people from buying?

componenttextpreview: No, I mean, rents income ratio our folks balances between 17% and 18%. Our credit scores are very strong. These are folks that could go buy house tomorrow and are just choosing not to. And there's really nothing in our sort of what we're seeing in demogra
componenttext: No, I mean, rents income ratio our folks balances between 17% and 18%. Our credit scores are very strong. These are folks that could go buy house tomorrow and are just choosing not to. And there's really nothing in our sort of what we're seeing in demographics that makes us think that means it's 74% single right now are predominantly female. They just don't -- there just doesn't seem a lot of demand for owning their home out of our residence at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You researched this very well and you know a lot about this, these trends but I just think that it gets back to just the whole psychology of that 20 to -- late 20, early 30 year old today is just different than what it was years ago. And I think that as y
componenttext: You researched this very well and you know a lot about this, these trends but I just think that it gets back to just the whole psychology of that 20 to -- late 20, early 30 year old today is just different than what it was years ago. And I think that as you know, whether they're getting married later in life or starting family later in life, just life conditions are different today than they were years ago. And as a consequent of that, they're just more inclined to want to rent a housing as opposed to making the obligations surrounding buying a home. And it's hard for me to see how that's going to materially change. I think people are more motivated to make a decision to buy versus rent for lifestyle reasons and attractive financing and low interest notwithstanding. I don't think there is going to compel people to abandon a lifestyle choice just because it gets a little bit more affordable.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're still seeing very low 5, high 4 cap rates pretty routinely. We haven't seen any evidence that suggests that cap rates have materially changed. We are just seeing more opportunity and, of course, where we focus on some of these lease up opportun
componenttext: Yes, we're still seeing very low 5, high 4 cap rates pretty routinely. We haven't seen any evidence that suggests that cap rates have materially changed. We are just seeing more opportunity and, of course, where we focus on some of these lease up opportunities, as you know, those are situations that are a little bit more difficult to finance, and only the strongest buyers can really take on some of the initial dilution associated with acquiring a non-stabilized asset. And our ability to execute on an all-cash basis from an acquisitions perspective really gets us a lot of opportunity versus a lot of the other competitors that do run into. So we haven't seen anything that suggests that cap rates have changed in any way, we do see more opportunity and working that angle to our advantage.

componenttext: Houston is a very, very big market and it's going to vary a lot by submarket, and some of our suburban locations are going to hold up better than some of that stuff around the galleria and well inside the loop and so it's going to vary a little bit. But I think Houston has got another 3 or 4 quarters to go before I mean the good news supply has really stopped, dead stop. And I think that it's just not to work through the absorption over the next 3 or 4 quarters, and I think Houston becomes more of a recovery story for perhaps in late '17, certainly by the time we get to 2018.

componenttext: I think there's 2 factors. As we have sold off some of the older properties that we have over the last several years, a lot of those properties were in some of these smaller more tertiary markets, and some of those properties tended to be dominated by more of a military profile, where you tend to have a much higher turnover rate associated with the activity at the property. And I think that's a little bit updating our portfolio coupled with the other point comments, which is just renter psychology today is so much different than average length of stay in our portfolio is longer than it's even been. Average age is higher than it's been and I just think that the odds of getting back to 64%, 65% turnover. We just don't see anything that's likely to get us in that direction.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for participating in the MAA Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
At this time, we would like to turn the conference over to Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance. Mr. Argo, you may begin.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Leo. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, SVP of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO.Before we begin with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the disc
componenttext:
Thank you, Leo. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, SVP of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO.
Before we begin with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the discussion, company management will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from our projections. We encourage you to refer to the safe harbor language included in yesterday's press release and our 34-Act filings with SEC, which describe risk factors that may impact future results. These reports, along with a copy of today's prepared comments and an audio copy of this morning's call, will be available on our website.
During this call, we will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures can be found in our earnings release and supplemental financial data. When we reach the question-and-answer portion of the call, I would ask for everyone to please limit their questions to no more than 2 in order to give everyone an ample opportunity to participate. Should you have additional questions, please reenter the queue, or you're certainly welcome to follow up with us after we conclude the call. Thank you.
I'll now turn the call over to Eric.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. As outlined in yesterday's earnings release, second quarter results were ahead of expectations.Solid rent growth, supported by occupancy that matched last year's strong results, generated same-store net operating
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. As outlined in yesterday's earnings release, second quarter results were ahead of expectations.
Solid rent growth, supported by occupancy that matched last year's strong results, generated same-store net operating income that was ahead of our forecast. Core FFO per share of $1.49 was at the top end of our guidance with a favorable NOI performance driving the majority of the outperformance for the quarter. It's also worth noting that core AFFO was $1.25 per share for the second quarter or 16% ahead of the second quarter of last year. 
As a result of that better-than-expected second quarter performance, combined with our outlook that leasing conditions over the rest of the year will support continued solid rent growth and strong occupancy, we raised the expectation for core FFO for the full year. As discussed on our first quarter call, it's important to keep in mind that record level of occupancy that was captured in the back half of last year, particularly in the third quarter -- that will serve as this year's comparative benchmark. But to be clear, we anticipate that current strong occupancy and pricing trends will continue. 
For the full year, we continue to believe that we will capture average physical occupancy at 96.2%, slightly ahead of last year's record performance at 96.1% while also driving solid rent growth that supports the year-over-year gains in revenue, leading to our increased expectations for same-store NOI growth. Al will walk you through the more-detailed assumptions in his comments covering our revised and increased guidance for both same-store NOI and core FFO.
Same-store operating metrics remain strong with resident turnover in the second quarter down 4.6% as compared to the second quarter of last year. Daily physical occupancy averaged 96.2% throughout the quarter, matching last year's strong performance. Effective rent increase -- effective rent per unit increased 4.4% over the second quarter of last year and was up 1.4% on a sequential basis with all of our markets registering both positive year-over-year and sequential rent growth with the exception of Houston, which was down slightly by 0.2%. 
Tom will give you some additional insights on the operating trends we're seeing as well as outline performance differences across our markets, but overall, we are encouraged with the continued levels of growing demand that is clearly keeping pace with new supply delivery across our diversified portfolio and balance submarket strategy.
We continued to work through a very robust acquisition pipeline with deal flow running well ahead of last year. As outlined in our earnings release, we were successful in the second quarter with the acquisition of a new property and its initial lease-up in the Phoenix, Arizona, MSA. This particular acquisition is a good example of the sort of opportunities we target involving a new lease-up development with a local developer and motivated capital that enables both our operating and transaction execution capabilities to capture a high-quality opportunity at a price that we believe will add to future value per share. 
We expect to capture a stabilized NOI yield in the 6% range on this high-end new property once we complete the lease-up and execute on the other opportunities associated with on-site operations and revenue management practices. As new supply continues to come online in a number of our markets, we're optimistic that additional opportunities will be captured later this year.
So in summary, we like the market trends we're seeing, and the MAA team has the operating platform executing well. The balance sheet is in terrific shape. And our transaction pipeline is very busy. 
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter NOI performance of 5.7% was driven by revenue growth of 4.4% over the prior year and 1.2% sequentially.We have good momentum in rents as all in-place effective rents increased 4.4% from the
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter NOI performance of 5.7% was driven by revenue growth of 4.4% over the prior year and 1.2% sequentially.
We have good momentum in rents as all in-place effective rents increased 4.4% from the prior year. In the second quarter, new rents and renewal rents executed during the quarter increased 5% on a blended lease-over-lease basis. We also matched the strong average occupancy of the prior year.
Overall, same-store expenses remained in line, up just 2.3%. Expense discipline has been a hallmark of our operation for years. Our industry-leading initiatives, such as our vendor-owned shop-stocking program and our interactive marketing strategy have allowed us to keep the expense line consistently in check.
Third quarter trends continue the positive momentum. Average daily physical occupancy of 96.2% is in line with July of last year. Our 60-day exposure, which is current vacancy plus all notices for a 60-day period, is just 7% below our prior year by 50 basis points. New and renewal rents have built on the strong trends of the second quarter. On a blended lease-over-lease basis, our July rents increased 4.3%, and early indications are that August will increase to 5%.
On the market front, market [ph] job growth of the large markets is driving strong revenue results. They were led by Orlando, Fort Worth, Phoenix and Atlanta. The secondary markets continued to close the effective rent growth gap with the large markets. Since the third quarter of 2015, the rent growth gap between large and secondary markets has narrowed 60 basis points. Revenue growth in Jacksonville, Greeneville and Charleston stood up.
As mentioned, momentum is strong across our markets with occupancy, rent and exposure all showing positive trends. Our only market worry beat [ph] is Houston, which represents just 3.4% of our portfolio. We will continue to monitor closely and protect occupancy in this market. As we approach the end of July, our Houston market's daily occupancy is 95.2%, and 60-day exposure is just 6.6%.
Moveouts for the portfolio were down for the quarter by 4.6% on a prior -- over the prior year, and turnover remained low at 51.5% on a rolling 12-month basis. Moveouts to home buying were down 1%. Moveouts to home rental, which represents just over 7% of our total moveouts, were down 5%. Our focus on minimizing the time between occupants again paid off, and we were able to reduce by 1 day the average vacancy between occupants, which helped drive the second quarter average physical occupancy to 96.2%.
During the quarter, we completed over 1,800 interior unit upgrades, bringing our total units redeveloped this year to just over 3,200. We expect to redevelop over 5,000 units this year. Our redevelopment pipeline of 15,000 to 20,000 units remains robust. 
As a reminder, on average, we're spending $4,500 per unit and receiving an average rent increase of approximately $100 over our comparable nonrenovated units, generating a year 1 cash return of well over 20%.
Our lease-up communities are performing well. Station Square at Cosner's Corner II closed the quarter at 99% occupancy. Cityscape at Market center II is leasing well. They're currently 95.6% occupied and expected to stabilize on schedule in the third quarter of this year. River's Walk II in Charleston is 71% leased, and Colonial Grand at Randal Lakes in Orlando is 18% leased. Both are on schedule.
Our second quarter acquisition, Residences at Fountainhead in Phoenix, Arizona, is currently 78% occupied. At the midpoint of our summer season, we are on track and the portfolio is performing very well. Al?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's second quarter earnings performance and balance sheet activity and then finally on the revised earnings guidance for the full year.Core FFO for the quar
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's second quarter earnings performance and balance sheet activity and then finally on the revised earnings guidance for the full year.
Core FFO for the quarter was $1.49 per share, which represents a 10% increase over the prior year. The performance was $0.05 per share above the midpoint of our previous guidance. About 2/3 or $0.03 per share of this outperformance was related to favorable property operating results primarily due to operating expenses as both personnel and marketing costs were better than expected for the quarter. 
The remaining $0.02 per share was primarily related to gains on casualty income claim -- insurance claims sold during the quarter as shown in the core income statement. Strong rental pricing and continued high occupancy levels carried through the quarter as expected, supporting earnings performance.
As Eric mentioned, we acquired 1 new community during the second quarter, Residences at Fountainhead located in Phoenix, for a total investment of $69.5 million. The community was at lease-up on acquire and was 75.8% occupied at quarter-end. And as Tom mentioned, lease-up continues to progress well, and we expect the community to complete its initial lease-up early next year.
During the second quarter, we sold 3 parcels of commercial land at a remaining commercial JV property originally acquired in the Colonial merger for total proceeds of about $4.5 million, producing a small gains on sale of nondepreciable and depreciable assets reflected on the income statement for the quarter. 
We had 4 communities, all Phase II expansions of current properties, remaining under construction at the end of the quarter. We funded $16.1 million toward completion during the second quarter, and we have an additional $48 million on the $97 million total projected cost remaining to be funded.
We continue to expect stabilizing NOI deals of 7% to 7.5% on average for these communities once completed and stabilized. Our balance sheet remains in great shape. At quarter-end, our leverage defined as net debt to gross assets was 40.7%, 70 basis points below the prior year, while our net debt was only 5.7x recurring EBITDA.
At quarter-end, 92% of our debt was fixed or hedged against rising interest rates at an average effective interest rate of only 3.8% with well latter [ph] maturities averaging 4.7 years. At quarter-end, we had almost $600 million of combined cash and borrowing capacity under our unsecured credit facility, providing both strength and flexibility for growth. And given our current expectations for acquisitions and dispositions over the remainder of the year, along with our projections for excess cash of $90 million to $95 million, representing FAD less all dividends, we do not expect new equity this year, and we expect to end this year with our leverage slightly below current levels.
Finally, as Eric mentioned, we are again increasing our earnings guidance for 2016 due to stronger-than-projected performance. We're increasing our core FFO projection by $0.04 per share at the midpoint to reflect both the $0.05 per share second quarter outperformance and our revised expectations for real estate taxes for the year, now expected to cost us an additional $0.01 per share over the remainder of the year as valuations, mainly in Texas, came in a bit higher than expected.
Our forecast generally continues to be based on current strong occupancy levels carrying through the year with toughest comps in the third quarter combined with the pricing performance continuing in the 4% to 4.5% range. Core FFO is now projected to be $5.77 to $5.93 per share or $5.85 at the midpoint based on average shares and units outstanding of 79.6 million.
Core AFFO is now projected to be $5.07 to $5.23 per share or $5.15 at the midpoint, which produces the strong 64% AFFO payout ratio for the year. We also increased our same-store NOI guidance to an expected range of 4.75% to 5.25% for the full year based on higher revenue growth, increased range to 4% to 4.5% and lower operating expense growth, decreased range to 2.5% to 3.5%, which includes impact of the higher real estate taxes now projected to grow 5.5% to 6.5% compared to the prior year.
The other major components, including transaction and financing assumptions, remain similar to our previous guidance. So that's all we have in the way of prepared comments. So, Leo, we'll turn the call back over to you for questions.

And I know a lot of this new delivery doesn't really compete with your asset directly, but I'm just wondering if there any markets that concern you as far as too much supply coming to the market.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, not at this point, John. And Charlotte and Austin are good ones to talk about. I mean, they've both been delivering a fairly high level of supply in Charlotte. That is quite isolated to sort of the urban core, where just 3 of our assets are. Expect Charlotte to continue to be strong. In Austin, the development has largely been scattered, most concentrated in the downtown area but scattered across the MSA. But it is largely -- we'll have a property that has a little bit of pressure from a single asset going up across the street and then it will abate. And honestly, we've seen sort of similar things in Dallas as well. But I think overall, the fundamental underlying [ph] situation of strong job growth is continuing, and it's allowing us to work through those deliveries.

componenttext: So you're kind of putting a positive spin on new supply coming online because it opens up acquisition opportunities, as you described, Eric. But I mean, how should we think about that? headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that -- I mean, obviously, supply in a market brings into question your ability to raise rents and just operating fundamentals. But as Tom was just going through there -- as we look at it today, permitting across our portfolio in 2017 is forec
componenttext: No, I think that -- I mean, obviously, supply in a market brings into question your ability to raise rents and just operating fundamentals. But as Tom was just going through there -- as we look at it today, permitting across our portfolio in 2017 is forecast to be down 10% from what it is this year. So on balance, given the strong job environment that we continue to see across our region, from an operating perspective, while we're not getting the sort of trends that we saw 2 years ago, we're still doing very well. And as we tried to emphasize, the trends that we've seen strong early this year, we expect those trends to continue. So from an operating perspective, we're not nervous about supply trends at this point, but...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess -- of course, supply is a risk. I get that. But I was just wondering if there's a optimal amount of supply that gives you these acquisition opportunities, and if you actually welcome some level to feed...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do. I mean, on the acquisition side of the equation, yes, absolutely right. And what we like to see, particularly as more supply comes online, particularly when it's concentrated in certain submarkets and so forth, which it often tends to be, we o
componenttext: Yes, we do. I mean, on the acquisition side of the equation, yes, absolutely right. And what we like to see, particularly as more supply comes online, particularly when it's concentrated in certain submarkets and so forth, which it often tends to be, we often see situations where -- like the situation I described that we just acquired in Phoenix where it's a local developer, it's a third-party managed situation. They're really not in the business of leasing, operating in a manner similar to what we're able to do. And you throw a little supply pressure into that submarket where they're trying to eke out a lease-up, pressure them out, and buying opportunities emerge out of that. And I mean, all the deals that we've acquired over the past year or so are very much along these lines where there are lease-up situations, and we've got 4 or 5 deals in the hopper right now that we're underwriting pretty aggressively that are all very much along the same lines. So I continue to feel that as -- over the next 3 or 4 quarters, that we're going to see some good opportunities.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the second question is, do you feel like there's some sort of new paradigm emerging here? Obviously, your portfolio has always been thought to be low-barrier, high-risk supply markets offset by job growth, but the story today is a lot
componenttext: Okay. And then just the second question is, do you feel like there's some sort of new paradigm emerging here? Obviously, your portfolio has always been thought to be low-barrier, high-risk supply markets offset by job growth, but the story today is a lot of urban development and maybe a causal factor to EQR's problems. Do you expect this to reverse back to more normalized conditions where your markets become the centerpiece of supply risk? Or do you think that there's something changing in your world that actually makes you a little bit more supply -- more Teflon, I guess?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, I don't know. I will say this. We've always gone at this with a belief that we're trying to build a portfolio in markets and in submarkets and at price points that offer us the ability -- and you've heard me say this for years, outperform over the f
componenttext: Rich, I don't know. I will say this. We've always gone at this with a belief that we're trying to build a portfolio in markets and in submarkets and at price points that offer us the ability -- and you've heard me say this for years, outperform over the full cycle. And market fads come and go. Cap rates come and go. But -- and we're not driven by those things. We're driven by recurring cash flow. We deploy capital with that thought. We allocate capital across the region with that thought. We like the strong job growth metrics of the Southeast markets. We can't do anything about supply, per se, other than just be sure we've got a very competitive platform and that we know how to operate very aggressively. And basically, we feel like we can compete with anybody, and we can compete superior to a lot of people we compete within these markets. So the supply will do what it does. What I really -- I'm more focused on is being sure we're deploying capital where demand is going to be, and we think that demand is largely a function of job growth and economic growth, and we like the Southeast for that reason and...

componenttextpreview: Al, I'm wondering if you can give a little more detail on the underlying assumptions that go into the back half of the year for same-store revenue growth guidance. You did 4.9% in the first half. The back half at the midpoint assumes 3.6% growth. You ment
componenttext: Al, I'm wondering if you can give a little more detail on the underlying assumptions that go into the back half of the year for same-store revenue growth guidance. You did 4.9% in the first half. The back half at the midpoint assumes 3.6% growth. You mentioned rent growth should be maintained at about 4% to 4.5%. There's the occupancy headwind of about 20 basis points. So what else is driving -- what are the other headwinds there to get from maybe that 4% down to the 3.6% implied by guidance?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nick, sure, I can give you some color on that. As first, why don't we just start with just underlying what you mentioned. We are not projecting the core fundamentals to decelerate in the back half, and the core fundamentals to us are occupancy that w
componenttext: Yes, Nick, sure, I can give you some color on that. As first, why don't we just start with just underlying what you mentioned. We are not projecting the core fundamentals to decelerate in the back half, and the core fundamentals to us are occupancy that will continue at the record 96.2% and the pricing growth that we expect to be in the 4% to 4.5%. We're certainly seeing that and expect to continue to see that through the back half. As you compare back to the prior year, the comps are more difficult in 2 areas: primarily, the third quarter and both the occupancy and your fees and our fees and fee reimbursements that we have in our program, that's a $30 million line item. So you put those 2 things together, that's giving you from call it the 4% to 4.5% growth rate down to the 3.5% to 4% that's projected over the back half of the year. That is just math related to the comps to comps for last year but the fundamentals of the business are strong, and we expect that to continue.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's a good run rate for fee growth going forward?
componenttext: What's a good run rate for fee growth going forward?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say the issue with it for the back half is it was growing -- those 2 line items together were growing, call it, 7% to 8% last year. This year -- and into the future, 3%, more of a normalized growth rate. It's just that last year, as we're building
componenttext: I would say the issue with it for the back half is it was growing -- those 2 line items together were growing, call it, 7% to 8% last year. This year -- and into the future, 3%, more of a normalized growth rate. It's just that last year, as we're building occupancy, we just had -- as we talked about, we had very -- and we're capturing the final vestiges was called at the colonial, we had very strong performance in those line items. So comparing back to 7% growth rate, you'll end the perpetuity long term. It's just not -- so 3%, something in the normal range is what we expect, and it's pretty big line items that's causing that comparison.

componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Touching a little bit on Nick's question or building off of that. I mean turnover's really down again this quarter. Do you feel like you've taken your foot off the gas at all on rental rate growth given trying to manage a little bit of the more difficult occupancy comps you face in the back half of the year? And then could you also give us what the rental rate growth was last year for July and August?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For answering your first question, no, we don't think we've taken the foot off the gas at all. Turnover for moveouts to rent increase moved from 14% of our moveouts to 13%, so that's immaterial, and we're getting a 6.5% rent growth on that. We feel pretty
componenttext: For answering your first question, no, we don't think we've taken the foot off the gas at all. Turnover for moveouts to rent increase moved from 14% of our moveouts to 13%, so that's immaterial, and we're getting a 6.5% rent growth on that. We feel pretty good about that and haven't backed off at all on that. And then remind me your second question, Austin?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just comparing the 4.3% increase you got in July and the 5% you expect in August. What were those numbers last year?
componenttext: Yes, just comparing the 4.3% increase you got in July and the 5% you expect in August. What were those numbers last year?

componenttext: They were in the range last year, we -- I'm digging for numbers, going increase over increase over last year, it's within 50 basis points of last year on a blended basis.

componenttext: 96.2% and to follow on Nick's point, I think it was -- we had a record high of 96.6% in the third quarter -- last year's call and some of the -- I think the back half average last year was probably 96.4% given that.

componenttextpreview: Slight headwind just from a comp, but we have very strong -- still 96.2% for the year is a record level. It's actually 10 basis points above 96.1% that was a record level last year, so that's how we look at it. So we're going to continue strong occupancy,
componenttext: Slight headwind just from a comp, but we have very strong -- still 96.2% for the year is a record level. It's actually 10 basis points above 96.1% that was a record level last year, so that's how we look at it. So we're going to continue strong occupancy, continue to push price, and we believe that forecast back half is good.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Well, we're currently actually working on a number of those transactions. We actually have 7 properties currently in contract that we're working through due diligence on and would expect -- assuming everything plays out as we think it will, expect to close on those -- all those, most of those in the third quarter with the others probably in Q4.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then going back to acquisitions, I was wondering if you could comment on -- if you've seen any distressed product in the market as a result of tightening lending standards?
componenttext: Okay. And then going back to acquisitions, I was wondering if you could comment on -- if you've seen any distressed product in the market as a result of tightening lending standards?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. What we are seeing are more evidence that some of the lease-up velocity that was taken place last year at some of these new properties is slowing a little bit, and so some of the properties that were brought out of the ground early this ye
componenttext: No, not really. What we are seeing are more evidence that some of the lease-up velocity that was taken place last year at some of these new properties is slowing a little bit, and so some of the properties that were brought out of the ground early this year that sort of get to that 50%, 60%, 70% leased status, that's typically where you start to run into the most headwind. We have more of those in the market today, and therefore, that's where our belief that we'll see more opportunities, that's where that originates from.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess last follow-up, are there any markets where you're using more of that product? Or it's market-wide in your market.
componenttext: And I guess last follow-up, are there any markets where you're using more of that product? Or it's market-wide in your market.

componenttext: It's pretty consistent across the board. I wouldn't point to anything unique. We're seeing, I mean, Houston is a market where folks have been very focused on trying to find some great buying opportunities, but we continue to see pretty firm pricing in that market. So it's pretty consistent across the board.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Rob Stevenson of Janney.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Rob Stevenson of Janney.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, is there any of your top 10 markets, other than maybe Houston, where redevelopment isn't penciling today? Were you not able to get the returns that you'd want in order for capital to work?
componenttext: Tom, is there any of your top 10 markets, other than maybe Houston, where redevelopment isn't penciling today? Were you not able to get the returns that you'd want in order for capital to work?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the redevelopment program is going strong, Rob. And it's generally not sort of a market-by-market decision. So it's asset by asset, and those assets are working. Every now and then, we will test a property to see if it works, then back off pr
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the redevelopment program is going strong, Rob. And it's generally not sort of a market-by-market decision. So it's asset by asset, and those assets are working. Every now and then, we will test a property to see if it works, then back off pretty quickly, but there are no ongoing redevelopment jobs that we have backed off on or aren't penciling. And on the tests that we do, we're generally seeing the same go-forward rate as we had in the past. So that is a place where new development does help us a little bit. An asset that's 10 years old and they build right next to it the latest and greatest and charge $500 more, we can pop out the nice formica countertops and put in granite and charge 200 or something like that. It gives us an opportunity to grow that program.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Tom or Eric, I mean, when was the last time when you go back and looked at the secondary markets actually outperformed your large markets for any length of period of time. I mean, I know that it's gotten smaller as a percent. I guess you'r
componenttext: Okay. And then, Tom or Eric, I mean, when was the last time when you go back and looked at the secondary markets actually outperformed your large markets for any length of period of time. I mean, I know that it's gotten smaller as a percent. I guess you're down to like 35% of NOI now. But I'm just curious as to -- as you think about the portfolio going forward and sources of capital and things of that nature, whether or not that goes significantly lower because it seems like it's been a while since those markets have really outperformed.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You have to go back to really 2008, late 2008 throughout most of 2009 time frame when we saw, obviously, a fairly deep recession taking place in the country. We saw the employment markets really take a beating. And those kind of environments, a recessiona
componenttext: You have to go back to really 2008, late 2008 throughout most of 2009 time frame when we saw, obviously, a fairly deep recession taking place in the country. We saw the employment markets really take a beating. And those kind of environments, a recessionary environment where job loss is really driving sort of the economic landscape, that tends to be where the secondary markets hold up a lot better, and you can actually get to a point where the secondary markets are outperforming the large markets both in terms of occupancy and our ability to hold rents. So I think -- I mean, they're there really more for that purpose, for sort of severe economic or economic downturn conditions. I think that what you're going to see is that, as we have continued to cycle capital out of some of the older investments that we've had, as you point out, a lot given the sort of base origination of the company and where we sort of came from, a lot of the older assets happen to be in some of the more tertiary markets of the portfolio, and that's where we cycled out a lot of -- we exited close to 20 properties over the last several years, selling over 13,000 apartments. I think as we go forward, you'll see us continue with a primary focus on cycling out of some of the older assets where the CapEx requirements are growing and the after CapEx NOI is likely to show more moderation, and that will continue to, as an example, the 7 properties that we have under contract right now, 3 of them are Winston-Salem, North Carolina. One of them is in Greensboro. One of them is in Huntsville. And so I think that -- but, having said that, you'll see us continue to look at opportunities in places like Charleston, Kansas City, Fredericksburg, clearly, other secondary markets, but we think -- and newer assets where we think the return on capital will be better over the next several years versus what we're selling.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Thomas Lesnick of Capital One.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Thomas Lesnick of Capital One.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, I was just curious how is June across your markets? And I guess, in that context, could you provide a little insight on what the quarter trends were like? Were they consistent across all 3 months? Or was there some choppiness there?
componenttext: I guess, first, I was just curious how is June across your markets? And I guess, in that context, could you provide a little insight on what the quarter trends were like? Were they consistent across all 3 months? Or was there some choppiness there?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean. Tom, they were really pretty consistent in terms of how rents went -- blended rents went through. So June fits in line with what the quarterly average was. And I mean, I guess, they're just wasn't a lot of difference between May, June and July
componenttext: No, I mean. Tom, they were really pretty consistent in terms of how rents went -- blended rents went through. So June fits in line with what the quarterly average was. And I mean, I guess, they're just wasn't a lot of difference between May, June and July and what the second quarter was, to answer you on a market level.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And my second question, what's your view on the fragmentation opportunity today across apartments in the Southeast? I mean, I guess, when you look where your stock price is today in the current premium to NAV, with that, what's your a
componenttext: That's very helpful. And my second question, what's your view on the fragmentation opportunity today across apartments in the Southeast? I mean, I guess, when you look where your stock price is today in the current premium to NAV, with that, what's your appetite for acquisitions and scale at this point?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we're very interested in pursuing opportunities. As I mentioned in my prepared comments, our deal flow is running probably 30% higher than it was this time last year. We are pushing hard on underwriting and processing as much opportunity as
componenttext: Well, I mean, we're very interested in pursuing opportunities. As I mentioned in my prepared comments, our deal flow is running probably 30% higher than it was this time last year. We are pushing hard on underwriting and processing as much opportunity as we can. I think that, as always, though, our focus is centered on an ability to make an investment and ultimately capture a NOI yield and a cash flow growth rate out of that investment that is at or better than the long-term average that we are -- our goal that we have for the company. And so we're not one to be -- I mean, while we certainly are aware and sensitive to the concepts surrounding our focus on capturing our spread between our current cost of capital and current cap rates, our focus is just always instead centered on a capital allocation model with a priority on capturing an NOI yield that meets or exceeds the long-term earnings growth profile we have for the company and an ability ultimately to achieve an IRR, a return on capital for the long haul that's better than what we think our investors are expecting.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Drew Babin from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is from Drew Babin from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the first quarter, it looks like you had about a 40 basis point lift in your same-property revenue growth from fees. So what wasn't accounted for by rent growth and occupancy growth? There seemed to be some contribution there that seemed to be absent i
componenttext: In the first quarter, it looks like you had about a 40 basis point lift in your same-property revenue growth from fees. So what wasn't accounted for by rent growth and occupancy growth? There seemed to be some contribution there that seemed to be absent in the second quarter. And I was just wondering whether that was sort of a deceleration off of more rapid fee growth in past years or whether there's anything deliberate going on at the property level, maybe being a little less aggressive with these.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll give you some color, and then Tom can jump on that. If you think about the first quarter, Tom, we had a little bit remaining year-over-year occupancy lift in the first quarter. And as you build occupancy, fees come with that. And so that happened, I
componenttext: I'll give you some color, and then Tom can jump on that. If you think about the first quarter, Tom, we had a little bit remaining year-over-year occupancy lift in the first quarter. And as you build occupancy, fees come with that. And so that happened, I think, in the third quarter, fourth quarter and the first quarter to a smaller extent. So -- but that very fact is part of that fee discussion earlier that's given us the tougher comps as we compare back to last year. We think fees going forward are going to grow in line and be in good normalized growth. We were having just a very high, very good growth last year related to the growing occupancy and the final vestiges of the Colonial...

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would say the other thing that has been a headwind on fees that's really, frankly, a net positive is that with turnover down consistently, we're getting less and less in the way of termination in lease break fees, which work for us, but those a
componenttext: Yes. And I would say the other thing that has been a headwind on fees that's really, frankly, a net positive is that with turnover down consistently, we're getting less and less in the way of termination in lease break fees, which work for us, but those are material fees. And then secondly, in the first quarter, we had a sort of a lights-out delinquency bad debt month. We're still very, very good where we are but not quite as good.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that all makes sense. And then one other question. Some of the markets you mentioned throughout the Southeast, those large markets and secondary markets, it seems like demand growth is continuing to track very well based on your comments. But it loo
componenttext: Okay, that all makes sense. And then one other question. Some of the markets you mentioned throughout the Southeast, those large markets and secondary markets, it seems like demand growth is continuing to track very well based on your comments. But it looks like just on the pure rank growth basis, there was a little bit of deceleration in a few of the markets. I was just wondering kind of -- was that -- is that a supply issue primarily, not direct but indirect? Is that something that potentially could burn off over coming quarters? What is behind that?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of course, it's going to depend on the market we're talking about and so forth, but broadly, I would tell you that, wherever we see any sort of, if you will, a deceleration on a quarter-over-quarter basis in a given market, more often than not, it's a fun
componenttext: Of course, it's going to depend on the market we're talking about and so forth, but broadly, I would tell you that, wherever we see any sort of, if you will, a deceleration on a quarter-over-quarter basis in a given market, more often than not, it's a function of a supply issue in a particular submarket affecting a given property or something to that degree. I mean, fundamentally, the demand dynamics, job growth, population trends, all the other sort of factors that drive renters and leasing prospects to our properties, all those fundamentals continue to show evidence of sustained strength and consistent with what we've been seeing for some time. And where there's moderation, if you will, it's going to be pockets of supply here and there.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Tayo Okusanya of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Tayo Okusanya of Jefferies.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a quick question around supply. I know we've all kind of harped on this. It seems like you guys are acknowledging that some of your markets are seeing increased supply and that it's manageable, but are there any markets where you start to worry th
componenttext: So just a quick question around supply. I know we've all kind of harped on this. It seems like you guys are acknowledging that some of your markets are seeing increased supply and that it's manageable, but are there any markets where you start to worry that supply starts to overwhelm the system and then you suddenly lose pricing power similar to what we're kind of seen in New York and San Francisco?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would tell you, Tayo, that I mean, obviously, we worry about it all the time. But 2 things that I would tell you is that, obviously, a lot of the supply that we are seeing in some of our markets, it's tending to be more concentrated in some of the
componenttext: Well, I would tell you, Tayo, that I mean, obviously, we worry about it all the time. But 2 things that I would tell you is that, obviously, a lot of the supply that we are seeing in some of our markets, it's tending to be more concentrated in some of the more urban core center areas, which happens to be where we don't have a lot of exposure. And so we don't see anything suggesting that anything different is likely to play out in the near term. So we continue to feel okay about that. I mean, we've been saying that supply has picked up over the last couple years, so I mean we're not -- it's not like it's a new thing. I mean, it's just, it happens to be in areas that we don't have a lot of concentration in. But I would tell you, if you're trying to get at what's going to change the chemistry, what's going to change the dynamic, leasing dynamic in a material way and put us into a scenario where we're having the same kind of pressures that some of these portfolios in San Francisco and New York are having, from my perspective, the only thing that really materially weakens the chemistry for us is that we see a material weakening on the demand side of the equation. We see some sort of economic recession take place in a material way that causes job loss to come back into the equation and jobs to really start to pull back. And absent some sort of major disruption on the demand side of the equation, right now, it's hard to see anything that's going to cause a material disruption in the positive leasing chemistry that continues to allow us to deliver, we think, pretty above long-term trend performance. It's moderated from what it was a couple years ago as a consequence really of a little supply but, honestly, just tougher comps. And that's been -- that's where the pressure has been, but the strong trends, per se, are going to continue from what we see today.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then, Al, just again, thanks for some of the comments on the back half of the year and what it could look like. Apart from some of the revenue pressures that you discussed, anything on the operating expense side that results in weaker
componenttext: That's helpful. And then, Al, just again, thanks for some of the comments on the back half of the year and what it could look like. Apart from some of the revenue pressures that you discussed, anything on the operating expense side that results in weaker same-store NOI growth in the back half of '16 versus the back half of '15?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think, Tayo, as we talked about a little bit in the call, I mean, we're very good at expense control, which is, as Tom said, one of the hallmarks, and we're very proud to continue that. I think, across the line, it's personnel, R&M, marketing for su
componenttext: No, I think, Tayo, as we talked about a little bit in the call, I mean, we're very good at expense control, which is, as Tom said, one of the hallmarks, and we're very proud to continue that. I think, across the line, it's personnel, R&M, marketing for sure, very much under control. The one exception is real estate tax as we talked about. We did get majority of our valuations come out in the second quarter, which is typical. Beginning of the year, you're sort of guessing on that just based on trends, and so it came out a little higher than we thought, particularly in Texas, as valuations. Dallas and Houston didn't soften like we had thought -- hoped it would -- any. So I think that's where the only pressure on expense is, so we raised our guidance 1% at the midpoint. On real estate tax guidance, now we think it'll grow 5.5% to 6.5%. That's 1/3 of your operating expenses. But even with that, we reduced -- were able to reduce the midpoint of our expense expectations for the year about 25 basis points. So summary of all that is now we expect to be well under control.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Wes Golladay of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Wes Golladay of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at the demand side, job growth in the U.S. has tapered off a bit. Have you changed your outlook for demand for your portfolio?
componenttext: Looking at the demand side, job growth in the U.S. has tapered off a bit. Have you changed your outlook for demand for your portfolio?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wes, at this point, we haven't. I mean, obviously, we'll be taking a hard look at the expectations for '17 as we work towards developing guidance -- initial guidance and so forth on that. But as we sit here today, we haven't seen any evidence that weaknes
componenttext: Wes, at this point, we haven't. I mean, obviously, we'll be taking a hard look at the expectations for '17 as we work towards developing guidance -- initial guidance and so forth on that. But as we sit here today, we haven't seen any evidence that weakness in the employment trends are going to create any issues for us. Of course, the other thing that's a strong underpinning to the demand component of our business is just all this sort of psychology surrounding homeownership versus renting their homes and all the demographic factors that are continuing to work in our favor. And so those powerful forces are there, and they're going to continue from everything that we see. What allows those powerful forces to really be unleashed, of course, is the good job employment scenario where people can get the jobs. And from what we see, employment trends tended generally -- in some of these particularly larger markets across the Southeast tend to be at the high end relative to what we see elsewhere across the country. And that's largely, frankly, why we tend to focus on as much as we do on this region.

componenttext: Okay. We're talking about -- Tom's referring to comps being nonrenovated units at the community. You're referring to comps as what's happening in the market. And we would have to -- we can get offline and figure out a way to pull that for you, Conor. But basically, what we do is that when we do a renovate, we go into our system and we make sure that the system knows that, that unit has had a capital infusion and that -- and therefore, when we look at market rate trends over the next 7, 8 years, we take our comparison in for our unit, and it has to -- that premium markup has to be there on a continuous basis for 5 or 7 years. So in other words, whatever premium we got to target when we initially did the deal, we track it to make sure that, that premium stays in place over the life of the investment that we make, and there's -- we have classifications on -- by unit, where we can charge premiums for views. We can charge premiums for this upgrade. We can charge premiums for whatever -- we got a lot of different premium levers then. When we throw those levers, they stay there. And that becomes the benchmark that compares against the market.

componenttextpreview: I was just perusing some of these stats. Just hit the tape [ph] from the Census Bureau talking about 1 million new households being formed, all of them renters in the last quarter, at least on a year-over-year basis. And it looks like the homeownership ra
componenttext: I was just perusing some of these stats. Just hit the tape [ph] from the Census Bureau talking about 1 million new households being formed, all of them renters in the last quarter, at least on a year-over-year basis. And it looks like the homeownership rate just hit the lowest level since 1965. I guess my question is, are you guys surprised at this point in the cycle that moveouts to homeownership are not going up at this point, where the mortgage rates are at, and what's happening out there? I guess, is there any signs in your incoming tenants, whether it's average FICO or rent to income or some other metrics that something's changed in the demographics or changed in the propensity to rent or preventing people from buying?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, Buck, the rent to income ratio of our folks bounces between 17% and 18%. Their credit scores are very strong. These are folks that could go buy a house tomorrow and are just choosing not to. And there's really nothing in our sort of what we're
componenttext: No, I mean, Buck, the rent to income ratio of our folks bounces between 17% and 18%. Their credit scores are very strong. These are folks that could go buy a house tomorrow and are just choosing not to. And there's really nothing in our sort of what we're seeing in demographics that makes us think that, I means, it's 74% single right now are predominantly female. They just don't -- there just doesn't seem to be a lot of demand for owning their home out of our -- or residence at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Buck, you researched this very well and you know a lot about this, but -- these trends, but I just think that it gets back to just the whole psychology of that 20 to -- late 20, early 30-year-old today is just different than what it was years ago. And I t
componenttext: Buck, you researched this very well and you know a lot about this, but -- these trends, but I just think that it gets back to just the whole psychology of that 20 to -- late 20, early 30-year-old today is just different than what it was years ago. And I think that, as you know, whether they're getting married later in life or starting family later in life, just life conditions are different today than they were years ago. And as a consequence of that. They're just more inclined to want to rent their housing as opposed to making the obligations surrounding buying a home. And it's hard for me to see how that's going to materially change. I think people are more motivated to make a decision to buy versus rent for lifestyle reasons. And the attractive financing and low interest rate notwithstanding, I don't think it's going to compel people to abandon a lifestyle choice just because it gets a little bit more affordable.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

What are cap rates for well-located property in your markets, roughly?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're still seeing very low 5, high 4 cap rates, pretty routinely. We haven't seen any evidence that suggest that cap rates have materially changed. We are just seeing more opportunity and, of course, where we focus on some of these lease-up opportun
componenttext: Yes, we're still seeing very low 5, high 4 cap rates, pretty routinely. We haven't seen any evidence that suggest that cap rates have materially changed. We are just seeing more opportunity and, of course, where we focus on some of these lease-up opportunities, as you know, those are situations that are a little bit more difficult to finance, and only the strongest buyers can really take on some of the initial dilution associated with acquiring a nonstabilized asset. And our ability to execute on an all-cash basis from an acquisitions perspective really gets us a lot of opportunity versus a lot of the other competitors that we run into. So we haven't seen any evidence that suggests that cap rates have changed in any way. We're just seeing more opportunity and working that angle to our benefit.
