headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, SVP of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO.Before we begin with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the di
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, SVP of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO.
Before we begin with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the discussion, company management will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from our projections. We encourage you to refer to the safe harbor language included in yesterday's press release and our 34 Act filings with SEC, which describe risk factors that may impact future results. These reports, along with a copy of today's prepared comments and an audio copy of this morning's call, will be available on our website. 
During this call, we will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures can be found in our earnings release and supplemental financial data. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. 
I'll now turn the call over to Eric.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning. Third quarter results were at the top-end of our guidance, solid same-store results, which were captured against a record occupancy performance of last year, coupled with favorable trends in G&A and interest expense drove co
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning. Third quarter results were at the top-end of our guidance, solid same-store results, which were captured against a record occupancy performance of last year, coupled with favorable trends in G&A and interest expense drove core FFO per share of $1.49 representing an 8% jump, as compared to Q3 of last year. As outlined in our earnings release, we have raised full year guidance for core FFO to a range of $5.86 to $5.96 per share. We continue to capture solid leasing trends across the portfolio. Average daily occupancy within the same-store portfolio in the third quarter was a very strong 96.4% compared to the likewise, very strong 96.5% occupancy in Q3 of last year. Effective rent per unit increased 4.2% with higher performances coming from Orlando, Tampa, Atlanta, Charlotte, and Fort Worth.  
As noted in our release, we were successful in closing 2 acquisitions during Q3, 1 in Houston and 1 in Greenville, South Carolina, both transactions are newly constructed properties and represent compelling long-term investment opportunities for those 2 markets.
We are also successful in completing the disposition of 7 older properties in the third quarter, as part of our efforts to steadily recycle capital to protect and enhance MAA's long-term earnings profile. Additionally, we currently have 5 other properties under contract for disposition and expect to close on these transactions in the fourth quarter. 
Our merger with Post Properties is making good progress, both companies have shareholder meetings scheduled for November 10. And we anticipate a closing of the merger effective December 1. Processes associated with integration of the 2 companies are well underway with the go-forward organization structure and team members now in place. As outlined in our announcement of the merger, we anticipate that upon completion of integration activities by the end of 2017, we expect to capture overhead synergies of $20 million. Specific line items and decisions associated with capturing this opportunity have been identified and we remain very confident in achieving this performance benchmark. As we continue to engage in the more detailed tasks surrounding the integration of the 2 companies, we remain very enthused and confident about capturing the improved operating margins and NOI lift from the legacy post portfolio that is important to the overall value proposition of the merger. 
Our work to date associated with inventorying and comparing the more detailed operating practices of the 2 platforms, further assessing opportunities surrounding our larger scale and enhanced market efficiencies and evaluating the redevelopment opportunities, all combined to have us also feeling very confident about this aspect of the value proposition.  We will begin to layout more details upon closing the merger, as part of providing our initial guidance for calendar year 2017. 
Before turning the call over to Tom, I want to express my appreciation and thanks to the associates working at both MAA and Post for their hard work and great support during the past few weeks, as we have worked through the difficult task of merging the organizational structures and preparing for consolidated operations, while also taking care of our residents and existing operations. Our newly combined company will have a number of strong attributes that position us well for the future. The professionalism and dedication that our combined team of associates demonstrate each day are key among these qualities. And now, I'll turn it over to Tom. Tom?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter NOI performance of 3.7% was driven by revenue growth of 3.6% over the prior year. Revenues were up 1.5% sequentially, which is 30 basis points higher than the sequential change last quarter.
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter NOI performance of 3.7% was driven by revenue growth of 3.6% over the prior year. Revenues were up 1.5% sequentially, which is 30 basis points higher than the sequential change last quarter. We had good momentum in rents, as all in place effective rents increased 4.2% from the prior year. In the third quarter, new rents and renewal rents executed during the quarter, increased 4.3% on a blended lease over lease basis. We achieved 96.4% average daily occupancy, which is strong on an absolute basis, but slightly lower than last year's record performance. Fourth quarter trends continue the positive momentum. October's average daily physical occupancy of 96.1 is in line with October of last year. Our 60-day exposure, which is current vacancy plus all notices for a 60-day period is just 6.6%, below the prior year about 55 basis points. New and renewal rents have built on the strong trends of the third quarter. On a blended lease-over-lease basis, October rents have increased a seasonally strong 3.3%. 
On the market front, the vibrant job growth in the large markets is driving strong revenue results, and they were led by Fort Worth, Orlando and Atlanta. The secondary markets continue to close the effective rent gap with the large markets. Since the third quarter of 2015, the rent growth gap between large and secondary markets has narrowed 80 basis points. Revenue growth in Jacksonville, Charleston and Memphis all stood out. As mentioned, momentum is strong across our markets with occupancy and rent growth and exposure all showing positive trends. Our only market worry bead is Houston, which represents just 4% of our current portfolio. It's worth noting that Houston will drop to less than 4% of NOI after the merger. We continue to closely monitor and protect occupancy in this market.  As we approach the end of October, Houston's average daily occupancy is 95.9% and 60-day exposure is just 6.1%.
Our customer base remained stable. Move outs for the portfolio were down for the quarter by 1.4% over a prior year and turnover remained low at 51.3% on a rolling 12-month basis. Move outs to home buying remained at 20% of total move outs. There's also a little change in move outs to home rental, which represents just over 7% of move outs. 
During the quarter, we completed over 2,400 interior unit upgrades, bringing our total units redeveloped this year to just over 5,400. Our premerger redevelopment pipeline of 15,000 to 20,000 units remained robust. As a reminder, on average, we're spending about $4,500 per unit and receiving average rent increases of approximately $100 over a comparable non-renovated unit, generating a year 1 cash return of well over 20%. 
Work is underway defining the scale and scope of the redevelopment opportunity for the Post portfolio. Indications are that it will be a significant value creation opportunity. We are excited about adding units from the Post portfolio to our redevelopment pipeline. Our lease-up communities are performing well. Station Square at  Cosner's Corner II and Cityscape at Market Center II both stabilized on schedule during the third quarter. Rivers Walk II will stabilize on schedule in the fourth quarter. Colonial Grand at Randal Lakes II in Orlando, is 30% leased, and on schedule to stabilize at the end of next year. Our 3 new acquisition communities in Tempe, Greenville and Houston are all on track. We are pleased with our progress thus far on the post merger. 
The operating structure of the combined companies has been finalized and communicated. There is a high degree of overlap in both systems and markets. We have enjoyed meeting the Post on-site teams and believe that adding these solid teams as well as excellent product and locations to our operating platform will create value for all of our stakeholders. We're in good shape for the fourth quarter and set up well for 2017. Al?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's third quarter earnings performance, balance sheet position and then finally, on the revised earnings guidance for the full year. Net income available fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's third quarter earnings performance, balance sheet position and then finally, on the revised earnings guidance for the full year. 
Net income available for common shareholders was $1.12 per diluted common share for the quarter. Core FFO for the quarter was $1.49 per share, which represents an 8% increase over the prior year. This performance was $0.04 per share above the midpoint of our previous guidance. Our same-store performance continued to be solid, which was in line with our expectations. About half of the outperformance or $0.02 per share was related to the favorable impact from the timing of our planned bond deal, which we previously projected for the third quarter, which is then postponed to early next year due to our merger activity. And we'll talk a little bit more about that in a moment. An additional penny per share is related to the timing of our transaction activity during the quarter and the final penny per share is related to the favorable G&A expenses for the quarter. 
As Eric mentioned, we acquired 2 new communities during the third quarter. We invested a total of $133 million for these 2 new communities, bringing our total acquisition by year-to-date to $264 million. We also sold 7 communities averaging 22 years of [ph] during the quarter for gross proceeds of $152 million, which represented a 6.3% cap rate. We also exited 2 additional secondary markets with the sale of Winston Salem and Greensboro, North Carolina. Our plans for the year included selling an 5 additional communities, which are expected to close during the fourth quarter.
We completed 1 community during the quarter,  River's Walk phase II in Charleston, and we had 3 communities, all expansions of current properties remaining under construction at the end of the quarter. We funded $13 million of construction cost during the quarter and have an additional $33 million to be funded on the existing pipeline. We continue to expect average NOI yields of about 7.5% for these communities once completed and fully stabilized. 
During the quarter, we paid all $75 million of maturing public bonds, which we expect to refinance as part of a large public bond offering early next year. Also during the third quarter, Fitch upgraded our senior unsecured rating to BBB plus with a stable outlook, and S&P placed our credit ratings currently at BBB flat on positive credit watch to reflect the anticipated increased strength of the balance sheet from the announced post transaction. Given the merger announcement and related activities, we have postponed our original plans for bond later this year in order to allow the merger to close, which we expect to provide support for financing early next year.
Our balance sheet remains in great shape at quarter end. Our leverage, defined as net debt to gross assets, was 39.7%, which is 100 basis points below the prior year. Our net debt was only 5.6x recurring EBITDA. At quarter end, 89% of our debt was fixed or hedged against rising interest rates at an average effective interest rate of only 3.9% with well laddered maturities averaging over 4 years. 
At quarter end, we had almost $570 million of combined cash and borrowing capacity under our unsecured credit facility, providing both strength and flexibility. Given our current expectations for acquisitions and disposition over the remainder of the year, along with our projection for excess cash, we do not expect any new equity needs other than the shares issued for the merger transaction this year. Also we expect our leverage to decline up on the closing of the merger with Post ending the year in the mid-30s as a percentage of gross asset value. 
Finally, as Eric mentioned, we are again increasing our earnings guidance for 2016, due to the stronger than projected performance. We're increasing our core FFO projection by $0.06 per share at the midpoint to reflect both the $0.04 per share third quarter outperformance and $0.02 per share for our revised expectations for the remainder of the year.
We expect interest expense for the fourth quarter to be about $0.03 per share favorable due to the late timing of the planned bond deal offset by about a penny per share of costs relating to cleanup from Hurricane Matthew. We are very fortunate to avoid significant damage from this recent storm, but we will incur some cost during Q4 for repairs and cleanup. 
Core FFO is now projected to be $586 to $596 per share or $591 at the midpoint based on average shares and units outstanding of 79.7 million. Core AFFO is now projected to be $516 to $526 per share or $521 at the midpoint. The major components of our guidance including same-store growth, transactions and financing assumptions remain similar to our prior guidance with 1 exception of the bond deal timing as discussed.
As mentioned in our release, given the merger transaction is not yet approved, this guidance does not reflect the anticipated impact of the transaction. If the transaction closes as planned, we expect to end the year within this current guidance range, although near the lower end given the initial dilution expected from the merger transaction. We expect to provide guidance for 2017 in more detail regarding the merger transaction with our fourth quarter press release. 
As discussed during our merger announcement call, we plan to capture synergies and additional earnings opportunities from the merger with Post that will recapture this initial dilution from the transaction over the first 12 to 18 months. And what we've seen thus far continues to support this expectation. 
We plan to outline this further with our fourth quarter release. That's all that we have in the way of prepared comments. David, so we'll now turn it over to you for questions.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, help me -- help frame the thought process as you go forward between the large markets and the secondary markets in terms of how do you -- it seems like most of the sales keep coming from the secondary markets. Do you turn using the Post platform and
componenttext: Eric, help me -- help frame the thought process as you go forward between the large markets and the secondary markets in terms of how do you -- it seems like most of the sales keep coming from the secondary markets. Do you turn using the Post platform and do development in some of these secondary markets to maintain the exposure, as this cycle gets late in the 2, because that's typically been where your stability has been during down cycles. Is it just a factor of post Post? You're going to be much more large markets. I mean, how should we be thinking about that, as the Mid-America platform moves forward in terms of market distribution?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rob, I would tell you, we remain very committed to the overreaching objective of keeping a diversified and balanced attribute to our earnings stream. And we think in our region of the country, high job growth region of the country, one of the best ways
componenttext: So Rob, I would tell you, we remain very committed to the overreaching objective of keeping a diversified and balanced attribute to our earnings stream. And we think in our region of the country, high job growth region of the country, one of the best ways to create that full cycle profile, if you will, is maintaining a healthy allocation between both large and secondary markets, higher growth large and secondary markets. As of today, we have about 65% waiting in large markets and 35% waiting in secondary markets. After the close of the merger, it will be more along the lines of 75%, 25%. Now you're right in that a lot of the asset sales have taken place have come out of the secondary markets, but primarily that's a function of prioritizing disposition focused on older assets, where the after CapEx margins are starting to show signs of moderating, and we feel like we can pull money out of those specific properties and recycle into better margin, better growth opportunities. And so, given the history of our company, it just so happens a lot of the older assets were in some of the more secondary or tertiary markets. So just as a consequence of our overall recycling objective, we have seen the allocation between large and secondary and of course, the Post transaction is going to change it. I would tell you this going forward, you will probably see the 75%, 25% revert back to closer to, call it a 60% 40% waiting, 65%, 35% waiting kind of where we are today. We are going to continue to look for opportunistic acquisitions as well as opportunistic development opportunities in both large and secondary markets, as exemplified by this quarter. We've bought 1 in Houston, 1 in Greenville. So we did one in each segment. So we remain very committed to the whole strategy that really defined us for the last 20 years. And we will ebb and flow a little bit just as a consequence of recycling in market opportunities, but fundamentally, we don't plan to change who we are.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Tom, you talked about the redevelopment in the portfolio, I mean, you guys have done close to 55, 100 units in the existing Mid-America portfolio, when you look forward to '17, '18, '19, assuming the market is cooperative and no recession,
componenttext: Okay. And then Tom, you talked about the redevelopment in the portfolio, I mean, you guys have done close to 55, 100 units in the existing Mid-America portfolio, when you look forward to '17, '18, '19, assuming the market is cooperative and no recession, et cetera, what's the remaining opportunity in core Mid-America portfolio? componenttext: Sure. On the MAA side, Rob, we've got north of 15,000 units remaining and would expect to see next year in the range of what we did this year. We are really working through. We're in the sweet spot of the Colonial portfolio at this point. On the post side, it is still early, but we are very excited about those locations and how the interiors of those units lineup against the market norms in those locations. And what that opportunity is. And so I would tell you right now it looks like its 10,000 units or better.

But we're still mapping out those opportunities. But really excited about the conditions of property, the locations and the opportunity there.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just again sticking on the Post transaction, as you've combed through that portfolio, how are you thinking about asset sales on the combined portfolio into 2017? And particularly, interested in maybe some markets,
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just again sticking on the Post transaction, as you've combed through that portfolio, how are you thinking about asset sales on the combined portfolio into 2017? And particularly, interested in maybe some markets, where you're going to have a much bigger presence for example, in Atlanta? And then I'd also be interested in any updated thoughts on what you're intending to do with the D.C. portfolio, either keep or potentially selling those assets?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would tell you that we are just really starting to dig in a lot on our plans regarding portfolio. Any sort of capital recycling that we got to be doing and putting our plans together for next year, and really for the next 3 years. I would tell you t
componenttext: No, I would tell you that we are just really starting to dig in a lot on our plans regarding portfolio. Any sort of capital recycling that we got to be doing and putting our plans together for next year, and really for the next 3 years. I would tell you that probably my biggest priority exist on recycling some capital probably out of Dallas, and Atlanta. Those 2 markets are going to comprise a fairly healthy percentage of overall portfolio concentration. And that's -- both would be a little bit higher than I think we want to maintain over the long haul. So there probably would be some recycling opportunity in those 2 markets, would be more of a priority for us. D.C., we were up there last week and starting to really understand more about that opportunity. As I think you know, the D.C. market is starting to finally show some signs of recovery. And bottom line is we're going to be patient with our analysis and thinking about what to do up there. We think that holding onto those assets at this point makes a lot of sense, particularly, given where we are in the recovery cycle of that market. And things that they bring, again a different kind of earnings profile, element to the portfolio and with our objective of really aiming to create balance in our earnings stream. We think those assets are good for the portfolio at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Well, again, we'll get into more specifics, as we get the transaction closed, and we start to put out our 2017 guidance. We're really digging in on the mechanics and the details of policies and practices on everything from how we manage and utilize LRO to how we manage and turn apartments to everything. And I will just say that we feel very optimistic about what we're seeing at this point. And feel very confident in the overall value proposition.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just last question from me. On the Houston acquisition. Just curious about how you guys underwrote that and how you're thinking about market rent growth in Houston over the next, call it 12 to 18 months?
componenttext: Great. And then just last question from me. On the Houston acquisition. Just curious about how you guys underwrote that and how you're thinking about market rent growth in Houston over the next, call it 12 to 18 months?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is a very opportunistic situation that was presented to us off-market with a developer and a capital equity partner that we know very well, we've done business with over the past. They were motivated to cycle out of the investment. This is -- H
componenttext: Well, this is a very opportunistic situation that was presented to us off-market with a developer and a capital equity partner that we know very well, we've done business with over the past. They were motivated to cycle out of the investment. This is -- Houston Heights District is a very high-end area, just northwest of Downtown, but 3 miles northwest of the CBD of Houston, very restrictive covenants about supply in this particular little submarket. In fact, this is the first community delivered in that submarket since 2008, which is saying something when you're talking about Houston. But we went in there very conservatively. We basically assume no rent growth for the next 2 years, 1.5% rent growth in the third year. I believe Houston will likely do better than that, but that's what we assumed. And on that basis it underwrote at a level that we felt pretty good about 5, 6 stabilized NOI yield first year, based on what I consider to be kind of probably lower rents than certainly what we will see long-term. So we felt it was a pretty opportunistic buy at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Robert Wagner with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Conor. Bob couldn't be with us today. Just overall, Eric, if you could continue commenting on Houston, have you seen other deals where, I know you guys have been looking there for a while, where sellers have been less willing or just overall the t
componenttext: This is Conor. Bob couldn't be with us today. Just overall, Eric, if you could continue commenting on Houston, have you seen other deals where, I know you guys have been looking there for a while, where sellers have been less willing or just overall the transaction market, is this deal indicative that the transaction market in Houston is opening up or sellers still trying to wait for better pricing?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably not indicative of where the market is right now, Conor. I think that, as you say, we have been looking at a lot of opportunity, trying to chase opportunity there for last couple of years and haven't really found. We've seen a few tra
componenttext: I think it's probably not indicative of where the market is right now, Conor. I think that, as you say, we have been looking at a lot of opportunity, trying to chase opportunity there for last couple of years and haven't really found. We've seen a few transactions take place but not much. And this was just a unique situation that was presented to us. And we jumped on it. I think that everybody is fully aware that supply trends and new permitting trends have pulled way back in Houston, and I think we got to get through 2017. But I think anybody that's got the wherewithal and ability and/or the interest in holding onto 2018, is going to do that. So I think Houston, we're going to continue to keep an eye on that market and like it long-term, but I think that it's probably too early to suggest that this transaction is indicative of anything really turning there in terms of transaction activity.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you mentioned supply issues in Houston supply, any markets next year, where you're more concerned about supply growth or any -- conversely any markets where supply growth picture becomes more favorable?
componenttext: Great. And then you mentioned supply issues in Houston supply, any markets next year, where you're more concerned about supply growth or any -- conversely any markets where supply growth picture becomes more favorable?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Conor. I think in general, we're sensing that 2017 looks a lot like 2016 in terms of supply that developers are beginning to have trouble with financing or lining items up in that area and that it probably peaks in '17 and backs off in '18. As Eric me
componenttext: No, Conor. I think in general, we're sensing that 2017 looks a lot like 2016 in terms of supply that developers are beginning to have trouble with financing or lining items up in that area and that it probably peaks in '17 and backs off in '18. As Eric mentioned, Houston deliveries will be roughly half, will see half of the levels that they were this year. And Atlanta, Dallas and Nashville will see modest increases. But job growth remains very strong in that area. And then really the remainder is in line with '16.

componenttext: Yes, actually yes. So on the Colonial transaction, you guys included the debt mark-to-market add back in your definition of core FFO and some of that's still tapering off. Do you guys have any estimates of what that would be based on where rates are today on the Post portfolio?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, we do. We talked about that a little bit. I'll tell you, I think the bigger point is we are really looking at how we're going to handle that with this transaction, given all the -- there is a lot of discussion in the industry about non-core measures
componenttext: Tom, we do. We talked about that a little bit. I'll tell you, I think the bigger point is we are really looking at how we're going to handle that with this transaction, given all the -- there is a lot of discussion in the industry about non-core measures and handling of that, SEC is very focused on that, and of course the REIT industry is right in the bull's eye on that. So I think what you're seeing, we're going to take a look at that and most likely what we're going to do going forward next year is focus more on NAREIT FFO and discuss the transaction merger integration cost. So that means that the fair market value adjustable will be included in that instead of pulling it out as part of core FFO, I think, meaning our peers do include that, we're going to go ahead and do that and line that up within NAREIT FFO. Having said that, I think the numbers around $35 million or something like that in total that we've talked about and we will get more details on that, when we give guidance for 2017.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question from Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.
componenttext: We will take our next question from Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just along the lines of the Post merger, apart from the $25 million of synergies that you guys have talked about. You have also kind of now talked about these redevelopment opportunities within the portfolio. Anything also kind of targeting out there that
componenttext: Just along the lines of the Post merger, apart from the $25 million of synergies that you guys have talked about. You have also kind of now talked about these redevelopment opportunities within the portfolio. Anything also kind of targeting out there that should give the investors much more confidence about the amount of synergies overall they could get from the deal of 2 to 3 year holding period?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would tell you, Tayo, First, let me make sure, its $20 million of overhead, not $25 million. But $25 million was on Colonial, $20 million on Post. But as far as the areas of opportunity and sort of the opportunity to recover earnings dilution, first of
componenttext:
I would tell you, Tayo, First, let me make sure, its $20 million of overhead, not $25 million. But $25 million was on Colonial, $20 million on Post. But as far as the areas of opportunity and sort of the opportunity to recover earnings dilution, first of all, it's important to recognize that we're taking on the Post portfolio and what's going to happen is the dilution that we see will be frankly, at its highest point at the very first month or 2 and then it begins to taper off over the coming 12 to 18 months. And so, we think that by the time we get to the end of 2017 that the recovery associated with overhead synergy that $20 million number will be fully realized by the time we get to the end of 2017. Beyond that, there are really 3 other sort of big areas of opportunity. First and foremost is the development pipeline that Post has. Again, we're taking that development pipeline on at frankly, it's most dilutive point. And we will see, as these properties come online and the earnings contribution starts to grow, that will start to really show up really towards the end of next year and really into 2018, as these construction projects finish. But that's going to be a meaningful area of opportunity. Thirdly, is, what Tom was talking about a moment ago, the redevelopment, that's a 2 or 3-year process. We see tremendous opportunity there. These are terrific locations that we think are just absolutely right for our redevelopment program. And we think that, that potentially is going to be much more significant, frankly, than what we had contemplated going into this. And then finally, the fourth area is, we just refer to it generally as NOI lift, and it's a combination of a bunch of things.
It ranges all the way from how we execute with LRO, yield management practices, just I was saying earlier how we turn apartments, capturing the full benefits surrounding the scale that we have. And frankly, those benefits regarding scale and efficiencies, there is going to be some benefit accrued to the existing legacy MAA portfolio as a consequence of this combination as well. So that particular opportunity is still being mapped out in detail, but we think that over the next 12 to 18 months, that it likewise, is a very significant opportunity. When you pull it all together, when you look at sort of the -- there is a lot of different ways to think about the sort of the value proposition here, but certainly when you look at the pricing paid versus the upside that we think is going to be realized over the next couple of years or so, much in the same way we saw with Colonial. We think this one here with Post was going to be frankly, more upside than what we saw with Colonial.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And just one more for the road. Just in regards to some of your secondary markets, there was also some week same-store NOI growth there, Savannah, San Antonio, Greenville and Birmingham, -- I'm sorry, Birmingham and  Little Rock
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And just one more for the road. Just in regards to some of your secondary markets, there was also some week same-store NOI growth there, Savannah, San Antonio, Greenville and Birmingham, -- I'm sorry, Birmingham and  Little Rock, Arkansas. How should we be kind of thinking about those markets, since we don't really talk about them, but some of their numbers are also pretty weak.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd tell you, I mean, it's a little bit different stories on some, on those first couple that you mentioned. They had very strong year-over-year occupancy growth this time last year and it tapered out a little bit. But Savannah, we feel good about long-te
componenttext: I'd tell you, I mean, it's a little bit different stories on some, on those first couple that you mentioned. They had very strong year-over-year occupancy growth this time last year and it tapered out a little bit. But Savannah, we feel good about long-term, their job growth is north of 2%. There they're managing through some deliveries in the [ph] submarket, but I mean frankly that is a -- become an aviation aerospace hub almost sort of a smaller version of Charleston. And then on Little Rock and Birmingham, I think they continue to improve, a limited supply there in job growth, in recovery mode. But they do not have quite the strength in job growth that places like Savannah, Charleston and Greenville do.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on your comments on redevelopment opportunities within the Post portfolio. I was wondering, if you could comment on your thoughts on using the Post brand, I know on the merger call, you said that you're still evaluating how you're going to do
componenttext: Following up on your comments on redevelopment opportunities within the Post portfolio. I was wondering, if you could comment on your thoughts on using the Post brand, I know on the merger call, you said that you're still evaluating how you're going to do the integration with 2 different brands, do you have any update on that?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's something we're going to be very careful with and very thoughtful about. We think that the Post brand has value. We think it's particularly important in the Atlanta market. We are going to -- you'll see no change initially whatsoever. All the
componenttext: Well, that's something we're going to be very careful with and very thoughtful about. We think that the Post brand has value. We think it's particularly important in the Atlanta market. We are going to -- you'll see no change initially whatsoever. All the Post property names will continue just as they are and we have no near-term plans to modify anything along these lines. But over the course of the coming year, we will be looking at opportunities to get a little bit alignment, some degree of alignment between sort of the Post brand and the MAA brand and see if we can come up with something that makes sense. But above all, we are absolutely committed to doing all we can to protect the -- I think very high rating that the Post brand maintains in a number of markets, Dallas included, but particularly, Atlanta, I think is very important in as well as frankly lot of the other markets we're in. So more to come on that, but we understand the value of the brand and are very interested and want to be certain that we don't lose that.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think you highlighted Atlanta and Dallas as couple of markets where you may be over allocated post-merger and you may plan to recycle capital. Are there any markets post-merger that you're feeling you're under allocated and where you plan to put t
componenttext: Okay. I think you highlighted Atlanta and Dallas as couple of markets where you may be over allocated post-merger and you may plan to recycle capital. Are there any markets post-merger that you're feeling you're under allocated and where you plan to put that capital?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, frankly, really just about any other market that we're in at the moment has capacity, if you will. So we're going to continue to -- all the existing market that we're in, continue to look for opportunities. I think we will continue to, as we have ta
componenttext: Well, frankly, really just about any other market that we're in at the moment has capacity, if you will. So we're going to continue to -- all the existing market that we're in, continue to look for opportunities. I think we will continue to, as we have talked about with our recycling effort, we will continue to look at older assets. We still have a few, but not much left in that regard, but we have a couple of one-off opportunities here and there that we will probably look at next year. But in terms of -- but I think overall, the markets that we are in and certainly the -- we like them and we would be happy to recycle capital in any of those markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: We will take our next question from Neil Malkin with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, some anecdotal evidence relative to single-family homes and trends. It seems like the first time homebuyers, that data is at pretty high levels or is accelerating. So I'm wondering, if particularly, in your secondary markets, you're seeing any pres
componenttext: First, some anecdotal evidence relative to single-family homes and trends. It seems like the first time homebuyers, that data is at pretty high levels or is accelerating. So I'm wondering, if particularly, in your secondary markets, you're seeing any pressure on move outs due to home purchase. Any type of that activity going on, just given the price point of your assets?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: We are not. And actually in our secondary markets group. The move outs are lower in secondary markets than in the large markets group. I mean, it's in -- so nothing there.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then other 1, you've been receiving pretty good renewal increases relative to new leases, new lease rate increases. I'm wondering, at the current time what -- is there a gain or loss to lease in your portfolio. And have you kind of looked
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then other 1, you've been receiving pretty good renewal increases relative to new leases, new lease rate increases. I'm wondering, at the current time what -- is there a gain or loss to lease in your portfolio. And have you kind of looked at the balance or the marriage between the 2 to not get too ahead of the market?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the way we really look at it is that we monitor the gap between the absolute dollar value of the renewal and the absolute dollar value of the new lease, and what you find is it has some seasonal attributes to it. And so it is -- it will be as litt
componenttext: Yes, so the way we really look at it is that we monitor the gap between the absolute dollar value of the renewal and the absolute dollar value of the new lease, and what you find is it has some seasonal attributes to it. And so it is -- it will be as little as $2 or $3 in the summer months when leasing is full bore [ph]. And then as it begins to wind down, it will open up to about $25 at this point. But right now, the way that it works is just in general, at some point, if those become divergent and stay that way and inhibits new lease price growth, but the dollar value between the 2 has remained narrow for the last couple of years. And thus we are continuing to be aggressive on renewals.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. So I guess, in other way, if you were to reset all your leases to market, would you grow up or down?
componenttext: Okay. Great. So I guess, in other way, if you were to reset all your leases to market, would you grow up or down?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'd grow up. It's about a 3.5% to 4% loss to lease in our portfolio right now. So actually, that's right out of the shoOptus.
componenttext: We'd grow up. It's about a 3.5% to 4% loss to lease in our portfolio right now. So actually, that's right out of the shoOptus.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And we'll take our last question from Buck Horne with Raymond James.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question actually was on the renewable numbers, well that 6 6 seems pretty strong. Just maybe a little color on it. Just how did it trend throughout the quarter. If there was any significant change from month to month and maybe what you're going out wi
componenttext: My question actually was on the renewable numbers, well that 6 6 seems pretty strong. Just maybe a little color on it. Just how did it trend throughout the quarter. If there was any significant change from month to month and maybe what you're going out with on renewal offers for November and December?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, what we're doing that has stayed pretty steady as it goes to be honest with you Buck, renewals have been a bright spot for us for some time. So August was 6 5, September was 5 9, October 6 2. And then the fourth quarter will be a hair lower t
componenttext: Yes, I mean, what we're doing that has stayed pretty steady as it goes to be honest with you Buck, renewals have been a bright spot for us for some time. So August was 6 5, September was 5 9, October 6 2. And then the fourth quarter will be a hair lower than that, upper fives, just because we try not to force -- we try to force as little turnover as possible in the slower months. But frankly, our lease expiration management was in very good shape, which has allowed us to continue to ask for what we are worth. I mean, we have great customer service on-site and the markets are reasonable. So we continue to work successfully with the renewals at that rate.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sounds good. And my last question is on cost a little bit, maybe Al, if you could help us understand some of the movements, maybe start with real estate taxes and sort of explain -- you had a little bit of a comp issue this quarter. And looks like the gui
componenttext: Sounds good. And my last question is on cost a little bit, maybe Al, if you could help us understand some of the movements, maybe start with real estate taxes and sort of explain -- you had a little bit of a comp issue this quarter. And looks like the guidance is forecasting for the fourth quarter to be little bit easier for you on real estate tax pressure. And maybe just also if you foresee any other items coming up over the coming year, particularly, maybe personnel cost, are you seeing any pressure on personnel to retain on-site teams or anything like that?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I guess it's a good question on real estate taxes, I think it's important to focus on exactly what you did there with the full year guidance we put out, it's 5.5% to 6.5%, don't expect that to change. Taxes, you get a lot of volatility sometimes in q
componenttext: Well I guess it's a good question on real estate taxes, I think it's important to focus on exactly what you did there with the full year guidance we put out, it's 5.5% to 6.5%, don't expect that to change. Taxes, you get a lot of volatility sometimes in quarterly comparisons because there is a couple of things that happen and you get -- timing of getting your information during the year can change from year to year -- and the timing of you getting appeals successful or not successful can change year to year. I think the story for the third quarter is that last year in third quarter, we got a lot of information and some favorable appeals that were very favorable and really helped us in our expansion. So we are really facing a tough comp this year in the third quarter, but our trajectory for the whole year is much more stable this year. Every bit of information we've gotten seems to support our initial expectation, and so we feel good about the 5.5% to 6.5% pressure coming from the same places we talked about in Texas and Georgia, as they aggressively chase values in some of those areas and have a lot of transactions to support it. So that's really what's going on there. In other areas, no, we really don't expect at this point a lot of pressure going into the fourth quarter. In terms of our -- what we put out and what's in our guidance, continued expense and personnel, continued expense in other areas in line with what our expectations were. So there is nothing --  only unusual item I think of right now, we've mentioned a little bit, a little bit of storm cost cleanup in the fourth quarter, Hurricane Matthew, certainly very unfortunate, we will have a little bit of cost in the fourth quarter to clean that up. But other than that, nothing unusual we expected.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And we have no further questions at this time.

componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for participating in the MAA Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, we would like to turn the conference over to Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance. Mr. Argo, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for participating in the MAA Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, we would like to turn the conference over to Tim Argo, Senior Vice President of Finance. Mr. Argo, you may begin.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, SVP of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO.Before we begin with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the di
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Good morning. This is Tim Argo, SVP of Finance for MAA. With me are Eric Bolton, our CEO; Al Campbell, our CFO; and Tom Grimes, our COO.
Before we begin with our prepared comments this morning, I want to point out that as part of the discussion, company management will be making forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from our projections. We encourage you to refer to the safe harbor language included in yesterday's press release and our 34 Act filings with SEC, which describe risk factors that may impact future results. These reports, along with a copy of today's prepared comments and an audio copy of this morning's call, will be available on our website. 
During this call, we will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations to comparable GAAP measures can be found in our earnings release and supplemental financial data. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. 
I'll now turn the call over to Eric.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning. Third quarter results were at the top-end of our guidance, solid same-store results, which were captured against a record occupancy performance of last year, coupled with favorable trends in G&A and interest expense drove co
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning. Third quarter results were at the top-end of our guidance, solid same-store results, which were captured against a record occupancy performance of last year, coupled with favorable trends in G&A and interest expense drove core FFO per share of $1.49 representing an 8% jump, as compared to Q3 of last year. As outlined in our earnings release, we have raised full year guidance for core FFO to a range of $5.86 to $5.96 per share. We continue to capture solid leasing trends across the portfolio. Average daily occupancy within the same-store portfolio in the third quarter was a very strong 96.4% compared to the likewise, very strong 96.5% occupancy in Q3 of last year. Effective rent per unit increased 4.2% with higher performances coming from Orlando, Tampa, Atlanta, Charlotte, and Fort Worth.  
As noted in our release, we were successful in closing 2 acquisitions during Q3, 1 in Houston and 1 in Greenville, South Carolina, both transactions are newly constructed properties and represent compelling long-term investment opportunities for those 2 markets.
We are also successful in completing the disposition of 7 older properties in the third quarter, as part of our efforts to steadily recycle capital to protect and enhance MAA's long-term earnings profile. Additionally, we currently have 5 other properties under contract for disposition and expect to close on these transactions in the fourth quarter. 
Our merger with Post Properties is making good progress, both companies have shareholder meetings scheduled for November 10. And we anticipate a closing of the merger effective December 1. Processes associated with integration of the 2 companies are well underway with the go-forward organization structure and team members now in place. As outlined in our announcement of the merger, we anticipate that upon completion of integration activities by the end of 2017, we expect to capture overhead synergies of $20 million. Specific line items and decisions associated with capturing this opportunity have been identified and we remain very confident in achieving this performance benchmark. As we continue to engage in the more detailed tasks surrounding the integration of the 2 companies, we remain very enthused and confident about capturing the improved operating margins and NOI lift from the legacy post portfolio that is important to the overall value proposition of the merger. 
Our work to date associated with inventorying and comparing the more detailed operating practices of the 2 platforms, further assessing opportunities surrounding our larger scale and enhanced market efficiencies and evaluating the redevelopment opportunities, all combined to have us also feeling very confident about this aspect of the value proposition.  We will begin to lay out more details upon closing the merger, as part of providing our initial guidance for calendar year 2017. 
Before turning the call over to Tom, I want to express my appreciation and thanks to the associates working at both MAA and Post for their hard work and great support during the past few weeks, as we have worked through the difficult task of merging the organizational structures and preparing for consolidated operations, while also taking care of our residents and existing operations. Our newly combined company will have a number of strong attributes that position us well for the future. The professionalism and dedication that our combined team of associates demonstrate each day are key among these qualities. And now, I'll turn it over to Tom. Tom?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter NOI performance of 3.7% was driven by revenue growth of 3.6% over the prior year. Revenues were up 1.5% sequentially, which is 30 basis points higher than the sequential change last quarter.
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter NOI performance of 3.7% was driven by revenue growth of 3.6% over the prior year. Revenues were up 1.5% sequentially, which is 30 basis points higher than the sequential change last quarter. We had good momentum in rents, as all in place effective rents increased 4.2% from the prior year. In the third quarter, new rents and renewal rents executed during the quarter, increased 4.3% on a blended lease over lease basis. We achieved 96.4% average daily occupancy, which is strong on an absolute basis, but slightly lower than last year's record performance. Fourth quarter trends continue the positive momentum. October's average daily physical occupancy of 96.1 is in line with October of last year. Our 60-day exposure, which is current vacancy plus all notices for a 60-day period is just 6.6%, below the prior year about 55 basis points. New and renewal rents have built on the strong trends of the third quarter. On a blended lease-over-lease basis, October rents have increased a seasonally strong 3.3%. 
On the market front, the vibrant job growth in the large markets is driving strong revenue results, and they were led by Fort Worth, Orlando and Atlanta. The secondary markets continue to close the effective rent gap with the large markets. Since the third quarter of 2015, the rent growth gap between large and secondary markets has narrowed 80 basis points. Revenue growth in Jacksonville, Charleston and Memphis all stood out. As mentioned, momentum is strong across our markets with occupancy and rent growth and exposure all showing positive trends. Our only market worry bead is Houston, which represents just 4% of our current portfolio. It's worth noting that Houston will drop to less than 4% of NOI after the merger. We continue to closely monitor and protect occupancy in this market.  As we approach the end of October, Houston's average daily occupancy is 95.9% and 60-day exposure is just 6.1%.
Our customer base remained stable. Moveouts for the portfolio were down for the quarter by 1.4% over a prior year and turnover remained low at 51.3% on a rolling 12-month basis. Moveouts to home buying remained at 20% of total moveouts. There's also a little change in moveouts to home rental, which represents just over 7% of moveouts. 
During the quarter, we completed over 2,400 interior unit upgrades, bringing our total units redeveloped this year to just over 5,400. Our premerger redevelopment pipeline of 15,000 to 20,000 units remained robust. As a reminder, on average, we're spending about $4,500 per unit and receiving average rent increases of approximately $100 over a comparable non-renovated unit, generating a year 1 cash return of well over 20%. 
Work is underway defining the scale and scope of the redevelopment opportunity for the Post portfolio. Indications are that it will be a significant value creation opportunity. We are excited about adding units from the Post portfolio to our redevelopment pipeline. Our lease-up communities are performing well. Station Square at  Cosner's Corner II and Cityscape at Market Center II both stabilized on schedule during the third quarter. Rivers Walk II will stabilize on schedule in the fourth quarter. Colonial Grand at Randal Lakes II in Orlando, is 30% leased, and on schedule to stabilize at the end of next year. Our 3 new acquisition communities in Tempe, Greenville and Houston are all on track. We are pleased with our progress thus far on the post merger. 
The operating structure of the combined companies has been finalized and communicated. There is a high degree of overlap in both systems and markets. We have enjoyed meeting the Post on-site teams and believe that adding these solid teams as well as excellent product and locations to our operating platform will create value for all of our stakeholders. We're in good shape for the fourth quarter and set up well for 2017. Al?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's third quarter earnings performance, balance sheet position and then finally, on the revised earnings guidance for the full year. Net income available fo
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. I'll provide some additional commentary on the company's third quarter earnings performance, balance sheet position and then finally, on the revised earnings guidance for the full year. 
Net income available for common shareholders was $1.12 per diluted common share for the quarter. Core FFO for the quarter was $1.49 per share, which represents an 8% increase over the prior year. This performance was $0.04 per share above the midpoint of our previous guidance. Our same-store performance continued to be solid, which was in line with our expectations. About half of the outperformance or $0.02 per share was related to the favorable impact from the timing of our planned bond deal, which we previously projected for the third quarter, which is then postponed to early next year due to our merger activity. And we'll talk a little bit more about that in a moment. An additional penny per share is related to the timing of our transaction activity during the quarter and the final penny per share is related to the favorable G&A expenses for the quarter. 
As Eric mentioned, we acquired 2 new communities during the third quarter. We invested a total of $133 million for these 2 new communities, bringing our total acquisition by year-to-date to $264 million. We also sold 7 communities averaging 22 years of [ph] during the quarter for gross proceeds of $152 million, which represented a 6.3% cap rate. We also exited 2 additional secondary markets with the sale of Winston Salem and Greensboro, North Carolina. Our plans for the year included selling an 5 additional communities, which are expected to close during the fourth quarter.
We completed 1 community during the quarter,  River's Walk phase II in Charleston, and we had 3 communities, all expansions of current properties remaining under construction at the end of the quarter. We funded $13 million of construction cost during the quarter and have an additional $33 million to be funded on the existing pipeline. We continue to expect average NOI yields of about 7.5% for these communities once completed and fully stabilized. 
During the quarter, we paid all $75 million of maturing public bonds, which we expect to refinance as part of a large public bond offering early next year. Also during the third quarter, Fitch upgraded our senior unsecured rating to BBB plus with a stable outlook, and S&P placed our credit ratings currently at BBB flat on positive credit watch to reflect the anticipated increased strength of the balance sheet from the announced post transaction. Given the merger announcement and related activities, we have postponed our original plans for bond later this year in order to allow the merger to close, which we expect to provide support for financing early next year.
Our balance sheet remains in great shape at quarter end. Our leverage, defined as net debt to gross assets, was 39.7%, which is 100 basis points below the prior year. Our net debt was only 5.6x recurring EBITDA. At quarter end, 89% of our debt was fixed or hedged against rising interest rates at an average effective interest rate of only 3.9% with well laddered maturities averaging over 4 years. 
At quarter end, we had almost $570 million of combined cash and borrowing capacity under our unsecured credit facility, providing both strength and flexibility. Given our current expectations for acquisitions and disposition over the remainder of the year, along with our projection for excess cash, we do not expect any new equity needs other than the shares issued for the merger transaction this year. Also we expect our leverage to decline up on the closing of the merger with Post ending the year in the mid-30s as a percentage of gross asset value. 
Finally, as Eric mentioned, we are again increasing our earnings guidance for 2016, due to the stronger than projected performance. We're increasing our core FFO projection by $0.06 per share at the midpoint to reflect both the $0.04 per share third quarter outperformance and $0.02 per share for our revised expectations for the remainder of the year.
We expect interest expense for the fourth quarter to be about $0.03 per share favorable due to the late timing of the planned bond deal offset by about a penny per share of costs relating to cleanup from Hurricane Matthew. We are very fortunate to avoid significant damage from this recent storm, but we will incur some cost during Q4 for repairs and cleanup. 
Core FFO is now projected to be $586 to $596 per share or $591 at the midpoint based on average shares and units outstanding of 79.7 million. Core AFFO is now projected to be $516 to $526 per share or $521 at the midpoint. The major components of our guidance including same-store growth, transactions and financing assumptions remain similar to our prior guidance with 1 exception of the bond deal timing as discussed.
As mentioned in our release, given the merger transaction is not yet approved, this guidance does not reflect the anticipated impact of the transaction. If the transaction closes as planned, we expect to end the year within this current guidance range, although near the lower end given the initial dilution expected from the merger transaction. We expect to provide guidance for 2017 in more detail regarding the merger transaction with our fourth quarter press release. 
As discussed during our merger announcement call, we plan to capture synergies and additional earnings opportunities from the merger with Post that will recapture this initial dilution from the transaction over the first 12 to 18 months. And what we've seen thus far continues to support this expectation. 
We plan to outline this further with our fourth quarter release. That's all that we have in the way of prepared comments. David, so we'll now turn it over to you for questions.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, help me -- help frame the thought process as you go forward between the large markets and the secondary markets in terms of how do you -- it seems like most of the sales keep coming from the secondary markets. Do you turn using the Post platform and
componenttext: Eric, help me -- help frame the thought process as you go forward between the large markets and the secondary markets in terms of how do you -- it seems like most of the sales keep coming from the secondary markets. Do you turn using the Post platform and do development in some of these secondary markets to maintain the exposure, as this cycle gets late in the 2, because that's typically been where your stability has been during down cycles. Is it just a factor of post Post? You're going to be much more large markets. I mean, how should we be thinking about that, as the Mid-America platform moves forward in terms of market distribution?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rob, I would tell you, we remain very committed to the overreaching objective of keeping a diversified and balanced attribute to our earnings stream. And we think in our region of the country, high job growth region of the country, one of the best ways
componenttext: So Rob, I would tell you, we remain very committed to the overreaching objective of keeping a diversified and balanced attribute to our earnings stream. And we think in our region of the country, high job growth region of the country, one of the best ways to create that full cycle profile, if you will, is maintaining a healthy allocation between both large and secondary markets, higher growth large and secondary markets. As of today, we have about 65% waiting in large markets and 35% waiting in secondary markets. After the close of the merger, it will be more along the lines of 75%, 25%. Now you're right in that a lot of the asset sales have taken place have come out of the secondary markets, but primarily that's a function of prioritizing disposition focused on older assets, where the after CapEx margins are starting to show signs of moderating, and we feel like we can pull money out of those specific properties and recycle into better margin, better growth opportunities. And so, given the history of our company, it just so happens a lot of the older assets were in some of the more secondary or tertiary markets. So just as a consequence of our overall recycling objective, we have seen the allocation between large and secondary and of course, the Post transaction is going to change it. I would tell you this going forward, you will probably see the 75%, 25% revert back to closer to, call it a 60% 40% waiting, 65%, 35% waiting kind of where we are today. We are going to continue to look for opportunistic acquisitions as well as opportunistic development opportunities in both large and secondary markets, as exemplified by this quarter. We've bought 1 in Houston, 1 in Greenville. So we did one in each segment. So we remain very committed to the whole strategy that really defined us for the last 20 years. And we will ebb and flow a little bit just as a consequence of recycling in market opportunities, but fundamentally, we don't plan to change who we are.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Tom, you talked about the redevelopment in the portfolio, I mean, you guys have done close to 55, 100 units in the existing Mid-America portfolio, when you look forward to '17, '18, '19, assuming the market is cooperative and no recession,
componenttext: Okay. componenttext: Sure. On the MAA side, Rob, we've got north of 15,000 units remaining and would expect to see next year in the range of what we did this year. We are really working through. We're in the sweet spot of the Colonial portfolio at this point. On the post side, it is still early, but we are very excited about those locations and how the interiors of those units lineup against the market norms in those locations. And what that opportunity is. And so I would tell you right now it looks like its 10,000 units or better.

Now there are inside of that, that's what we call a heavy and a light and there will be some opportunities to do some granite and stainless upgrades as well as some light fixture changes as well, meaning just doing floors and fixtures and some items like that. But we're still mapping out those opportunities. But really excited about the conditions of property, the locations and the opportunity there.

componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just again sticking on the Post transaction, as you've combed through that portfolio, how are you thinking about asset sales on the combined portfolio into 2017? And particularly, interested in maybe some markets,
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just again sticking on the Post transaction, as you've combed through that portfolio, how are you thinking about asset sales on the combined portfolio into 2017? And particularly, interested in maybe some markets, where you're going to have a much bigger presence for example, in Atlanta? And then I'd also be interested in any updated thoughts on what you're intending to do with the D.C. portfolio, either keep or potentially selling those assets?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would tell you that we are just really starting to dig in a lot on our plans regarding portfolio. Any sort of capital recycling that we got to be doing and putting our plans together for next year, and really for the next 3 years. I would tell you t
componenttext: No, I would tell you that we are just really starting to dig in a lot on our plans regarding portfolio. Any sort of capital recycling that we got to be doing and putting our plans together for next year, and really for the next 3 years. I would tell you that probably my biggest priority exist on recycling some capital probably out of Dallas, and Atlanta. Those 2 markets are going to comprise a fairly healthy percentage of overall portfolio concentration. And that's -- both would be a little bit higher than I think we want to maintain over the long haul. So there probably would be some recycling opportunity in those 2 markets, would be more of a priority for us. D.C., we were up there last week and starting to really understand more about that opportunity. As I think you know, the D.C. market is starting to finally show some signs of recovery. And bottom line is we're going to be patient with our analysis and thinking about what to do up there. We think that holding onto those assets at this point makes a lot of sense, particularly, given where we are in the recovery cycle of that market. And things that they bring, again a different kind of earnings profile, element to the portfolio and with our objective of really aiming to create balance in our earnings stream. We think those assets are good for the portfolio at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is a very opportunistic situation that was presented to us off-market with a developer and a capital equity partner that we know very well, we've done business with over the past. They were motivated to cycle out of the investment. This is -- H
componenttext: Well, this is a very opportunistic situation that was presented to us off-market with a developer and a capital equity partner that we know very well, we've done business with over the past. They were motivated to cycle out of the investment. This is -- Houston Heights District is a very high-end area, just northwest of Downtown, but 3 miles northwest of the CBD of Houston, very restrictive covenants about supply in this particular little submarket. In fact, this is the first community delivered in that submarket since 2008, which is saying something when you're talking about Houston. But we went in there very conservatively. We basically assume no rent growth for the next 2 years, 1.5% rent growth in the third year. I believe Houston will likely do better than that, but that's what we assumed. And on that basis it underwrote at a level that we felt pretty good about 5, 6 stabilized NOI yield first year, based on what I consider to be kind of probably lower rents than certainly what we will see long-term. So we felt it was a pretty opportunistic buy at this point.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Conor. Bob couldn't be with us today. Just overall, Eric, if you could continue commenting on Houston, have you seen other deals where, I know you guys have been looking there for a while, where sellers have been less willing or just overall the t
componenttext: This is Conor. Bob couldn't be with us today. Just overall, Eric, if you could continue commenting on Houston, have you seen other deals where, I know you guys have been looking there for a while, where sellers have been less willing or just overall the transaction market, is this deal indicative that the transaction market in Houston is opening up or sellers still trying to wait for better pricing?

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably not indicative of where the market is right now, Conor. I think that, as you say, we have been looking at a lot of opportunity, trying to chase opportunity there for last couple of years and haven't really found. We've seen a few tra
componenttext: I think it's probably not indicative of where the market is right now, Conor. I think that, as you say, we have been looking at a lot of opportunity, trying to chase opportunity there for last couple of years and haven't really found. We've seen a few transactions take place but not much. And this was just a unique situation that was presented to us. And we jumped on it. I think that everybody is fully aware that supply trends and new permitting trends have pulled way back in Houston, and I think we got to get through 2017. But I think anybody that's got the wherewithal and ability and/or the interest in holding onto 2018, is going to do that. So I think Houston, we're going to continue to keep an eye on that market and like it long-term, but I think that it's probably too early to suggest that this transaction is indicative of anything really turning there in terms of transaction activity.

headline: Mid-America Apartment Communities Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you mentioned supply issues in Houston supply, any markets next year, where you're more concerned about supply growth or any -- conversely any markets where supply growth picture becomes more favorable?

componenttext: No, Conor. I think in general, we're sensing that 2017 looks a lot like 2016 in terms of supply that developers are beginning to have trouble with financing or lining items up in that area and that it probably peaks in '17 and backs off in '18. As Eric mentioned, Houston deliveries will be roughly half, will see half of the levels that they were this year. And Atlanta, Dallas and Nashville will see modest increases. But job growth remains very strong in that area. And then really the remainder is in line with '16.
